title: Talbot schools welcome back teachers and staff
author: KONNER METZ kmetz@chespub.com
content:
Talbot schools welcome back teachers and staff

 August 22, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: KONNER METZ kmetz@chespub.com | Section: Local News 
 
 510
 Words 

 Read News Document

 EASTON — Hundreds of teachers and staff gathered in the Easton High School auditorium Thursday morning to celebrate the dawn of a new school year.Talbot County Public Schools hosted its annual Opening Day celebration, welcoming new teachers and presenting staff members with special awards before school begins Monday. Bands from the district's schools joined together to welcome staff, and many other students performed and introduced speakers for the gathering.
Jeremy Hillyard, the district's 2024-2025 Teacher of the Year, and Rosario Steele, the district's 2024-2025 Support Staff of the Year, were each presented with a 2025 Chevrolet Trax from Hertrich Chevy Buick GMC of Easton.
General Manager Pat Papineau thanked Hillyard, Steele and all of the district's teachers for their dedication to their professions.
"I imagine that a lot of people think that your guys' job starts a few minutes before the kids get there and ends a few minutes after the kids leave," Papineau said. "That couldn't be farther from the truth. … It's pretty much nonstop. You're continuously trying to improve yourself, you're continuously investing in yourself, you're continuously investing in your students."
Hillyard, a Spanish and English second language math teacher at Easton High, and Steele, an instructional assistant for English second language students, both delivered speeches to the crowd.
"Each of us in this room plays an important role in our students' stories," Hillyard said. "And it's our job and up to us to make that role a supporting one by always having their backs."
"This job has been the most rewarding experience in my life," Steele said. "I have witnessed those students that start as ninth graders with very little English inspire me when I see them in the community after graduation."
Many other awards were handed out during the event. AJ Rojas, the district's facilitator of interpretation and translation, was presented with the Wardell Brine Multicultural Award. Robin Werner, director of teaching and learning, was named winner of the Brewster Merrill Technology Award.
Named after a past superintendent, the J. Sam Meek Unsung Hero Award was presented to three staff members: Charlotte Compton and Heather Ewing, teachers at Easton Elementary, and George Larrimore, a bus driver since 2010.
MOVING FORWARDDistrict Superintendent Sharon Pepukayi closed Thursday morning's festivities with a speech indicating major areas for the district to focus on. Some examples were staffing, transportation, dress code and student behavior.
"I believe in bite-sized chunks and taking it slow, so that it's not a lot and it doesn't seem overwhelming," Pepukayi said.
She noted that adding mentors for incoming teachers and math coaches has been successful for the district. Pepukayi said the district will begin working on a new four-year strategic plan, as the current plan wraps up in 2025.
At the end of her speech, Pepukayi indicated the district is maintaining its three priorities of improvement heading into the 2024-2025 school year: academic equity in math, an "engaging" environment for students and staff, and recruiting and retaining a more diverse staff.
"We're going to stay the course with these three priorities as we continue to move into this next year of transforming and performing together," Pepukayi said.

title: Courage needed by Blueprint Accountability Board
author: KALMAN HETTLEMAN
content:
Courage needed by Blueprint Accountability Board

 August 24, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: KALMAN HETTLEMAN | Section: Columns 
 
 952
 Words 

 Read News Document

 The Blueprint Accountability and Implementation Board has done a remarkably praiseworthy job of fulfilling its mandate to hold state and local educators accountable for carrying out the sweeping demands of the Blueprint for Maryland's Future.Do you know who the AIB is not holding accountable? The governor and General Assembly, although it has the power and duty to do so.
Annapolis is ignoring growing evidence that the Blueprint is in deep trouble as a result of inadequate funding. It's not the only implementation problem but it is the one that most endangers the long-run success of the Blueprint.
Funding shortfalls have been obvious for at least three years. They include a lack of funding for classroom essentials, interventions for struggling learners, career and technology education, and special populations and a crushing burden on local governments. When local education agencies were asked their greatest challenges in implementing the Blueprint, funding was high on their lists.
Yet the governor and legislators have not confronted the scope and magnitude of the dangers ahead.
Is there anything the board can do to prod action even though its members are appointed by the governor? The answer is yes. The AIB has a lever to force Annapolis to pay attention — if it has the political courage to use it.
Under the Blueprint, the Accountability and Implementation Board is charged not just with planning for implementation and exercising oversight. Little-known but crystal-clear provisions in the Blueprint require it to recommend "legislative changes, including any changes necessary to ensure that the implementations have adequate resources." A further section requires it to determine whether "funds provided by the state and local governments are consistent with the Board's estimate of what is necessary to fully implement" the Blueprint.
To track compliance with these and other provisions, the Accountability and Implementation Board must file reports by Nov. 1 each year. Its 2022 and 2023 reports are silent on whether Blueprint funding is adequate. The board says it's laying the groundwork to do so: It has established benchmarks to measure progress and will use this data over the next few years to assess funding sufficiency.
But that's too late. The evidence of inadequacy is plain and painful to see.
The denial of reality was displayed at a recent joint meeting of the Accountability and Implementation Board and the state Board of Education. They were wrestling with setting targets for Blueprint progress, like the numbers of students achieving proficiency in reading and math. The targets were "aggressive" and "ambitious," all agreed.
But questions about whether there were enough resources for the targets to be met were brushed aside without specific answers.
It was evident in two recent meetings of the state board. In one, it was reviewing Blueprint provisions calling for students to meet high career and college standards by the end of the 10th grade. The discussion focused on interventions in the 11th and 12th grades for students who don't meet the standards. Fortunately, state Superintendent Carey Wright interjected that "a pre-K to 12 strategy is required … we can't wait until high school." In fact, the Blueprint compels intensive interventions in all grades.
At the most recent meeting, the superintendent's proposal to retain third graders who don't achieve grade level in reading — a feature of her remarkable success as state superintendent in Mississippi — ran into trouble. Several board members and local educators argued that there was too little funding for interventions in grades K-3 to avoid retention for large numbers of students.
They're right. The Blueprint only includes a small amount of money for interventions, mainly for struggling readers, in grades K-3, and that expires in fiscal 2026-2027. And there is no funding at all for interventions for students below grade level in grades 4-12.
Why this disconnect between the Blueprint's ambitions and the resources to enable it to succeed?
Of course, the big political reason is the unwillingness in Annapolis to face up to the need to raise taxes to pay for adequacy. This applies even to paying for the current (inadequate) price tag, which rises to $4 billion annually in 2033.
No doubt, raising revenue is harder these days given the state's projected budget deficits in the years ahead. Still, there's no alternative if the state is to fulfill its constitutional mandate to provide an adequate education for all our schoolchildren.
And despite Annapolis's reluctance, Maryland has the wealth to raise a lot more revenues if it has the political will.
The steep political climb must begin by telling the truth about the lack of resources. State and local educators shy away from truth-telling because they fear incurring the displeasure of the governor and General Assembly. So it's up to Accountability and Implementation Board to do its statutory duty. It must, without delay, at least sound the alarm over the most obvious and critical fiscal hole in the Blueprint: timely interventions for struggling learners.
At the same time, educators must convince Annapolis and the public that Blueprint money will be well spent. Better management is as important to the Blueprint's success as more money. Still, mistrust can be overcome if state and local educators show that current funding is being spent efficiently.
On that score, the Maryland State Department of Education is demonstrating a promising new capacity to ensure effective implementation. The Accountability and Implementation Board, to its great credit, has fully enabled and supported the state education department's renaissance. But now it's fiscal crunch time, the ball is in the Accountability and Implementation Board's court, and it must talk the Blueprint truth to Annapolis power.
Kalman Hettleman was a member of the Maryland Commission on Innovation and Excellence in Education, also known as the Kirwan Commission, a former Baltimore City school board member, a former deputy mayor of Baltimore and a former Maryland secretary of Human Resources.

title: Chapel District Elementary breaks ground on renovation project
author: KONNER METZ kmetz@chespub.com
content:
Chapel District Elementary breaks ground on renovation project

 August 24, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: KONNER METZ kmetz@chespub.com | Section: Local News 
 
 423
 Words 

 Read News Document

 CORDOVA — With the school year set to begin Monday, construction at Chapel District Elementary School is in full swing.Administrators, teachers, county representatives and students celebrated a groundbreaking for renovation work at the school on Friday afternoon. The Whiting-Turner Contracting Company is leading construction, which started Aug. 5.
A short ceremony outside the school provided attendees insight into the renovations and what benefits will follow. Speakers included Talbot County Public Schools Superintendent Sharon Pepukayi, Principal Kari Clow, Talbot County Council President Chuck Callahan, Board of Education President Emily Jackson, Critchlow Adkins Children's Centers Executive Director Cristy Morrell and two students, Abdiel Santamaria and Laney Childress.
"This groundbreaking ceremony symbolizes not just the start of construction, but the beginning of a vision coming to life," Clow said. "A vision of a school that will provide an environment where our students can thrive, learn and grow into the leaders of tomorrow."
Construction on the multimillion-dollar project is expected to take a couple years. The school was built in 1952 and last renovated in 1994.
During Friday's groundbreaking ceremony, Pepukayi thanked the school's teachers and staff and emphasized safety is a top priority as the school year begins and construction continues.
"Together the Chapel District Elementary School staff has shown patience and flexibility to work with Whiting-Turner and associates, keeping safety a priority while the project moves forward," Pepukayi said.
The Talbot County Council allocated a projected $26.9 million in capital project funding to Talbot County Public Schools for the renovations. That funding is expected to span across both fiscal years 2025 and 2026.
This April, the state's Interagency Commission on School Construction unanimously approved a $3.8 million funding request for the project. Lisa Vaughn, capital project manager for the commission, said on Friday that the "kids are worth every penny."
According to previous Star Democrat reporting, the project includes a full renovation of the existing building and around 16,000 square feet of additions. There will be additional learning space for the school, as well as the Critchlow Adkins Children's Centers site located in the building.
The school's media center is moving to the center of the building, and the playground is also under renovation.
On behalf of the board, Jackson thanked the county and state for funding the renovation.
"Funding these improvements for our cherished elementary school shows the collective commitment, not only to education, not only to rural education, but to rural education for our earliest learners," Jackson said. "It does not go unappreciated or unnoticed."
Following the ceremony, administrators, teachers, staff and students took turns shoveling the dirt to commemorate the beginning of construction.

title: Students head back to school in Talbot County
author: Tom McCall
content:
Students head back to school in Talbot County

 August 26, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 EASTON — Easton Elementary School was lit up with colorful backpacks and beaming smiles as students returned to campus Monday morning, ready for a new school year.Teachers were welcoming the students back from summer break, as was principal Lisa Devaric, who greeted students as they streamed in.
"We have been preparing for this day for weeks," Devaric said, "actually since the last day of school. What goes into class lists, and transportation and cleaning the building, new teachers. I am proud to say that we are fully staffed, all certified positions. There are 189 people on staff."
She added enthusiasm to the effort.
"I am so excited and energized. This is why we do what we do to see these sweet little faces coming through our building every day. It is a happy day," Devaric said.
Superintendent of Talbot County Schools Sharon Pepukayi had a welcome sign and was waving to families as they arrived.
"Our theme this year is transforming and performing together. After two years, going into my third, we realized we are better together," Pepukayi said, referring to the amount of time she has served as superintendent.
Getting ready does not start on the first day of school, she said.
"We have been working hard this summer with a lot of professional development we put it in place based on feedback we have received from staff but also internal data," Pepukayi said.
These efforts included training and preparations to accommodate multilingual learners.
"The school district is not an isolated entity. The whole community comes together for our families. I want the kids to walk in feeling confident, walking in with a sense of belonging, that they can use their voice to ask for what they need instead of being afraid," she said.
Amy Dodson, the Talbot County Board of Education School Board member for District 3, dropped off her three kids at Easton Elementary Monday morning.
"As a mom you are always a little anxious the first day, but they are in great hands," she said. "The took off. They are going to do great."

title: State test scores: Local districts increase in English and math, dip in science
author: KONNER METZ kmetz@chespub.com
content:
State test scores: Local districts increase in English and math, dip in science

 August 27, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: KONNER METZ kmetz@chespub.com | Section: Local News 
 
 481
 Words 

 Read News Document

 The Maryland State Department of Education released 2023-2024 test scores Tuesday morning, indicating slight statewide increases in English and math proficiency.Test results from the Maryland Comprehensive Assessment Program for the 2023-2024 school year were presented at Tuesday's Maryland State Board of Education meeting. Results showed a 0.5% statewide increase in English proficiency and a 0.8% statewide increase in math proficiency. 48.4% of students tested proficient in English, and 24.1% of students tested proficient in math.
Talbot, Caroline and Dorchester counties all fall below these state averages, though those three districts did increase in English and math proficiency from the 2022-2023 school year.
TALBOTThe 2023-2024 results show Talbot County Public Schools saw an increase in English and math proficiency, while following state trends with dips in science scores.
English proficiency increased 2.8% to be 47.3% proficient, which ranks 14th in the state out of 24 districts. Math proficiency increased 1.1% to be 18.3% proficient, which ranks 18th in the state.
Science levels for TCPS dropped along with the state, as Talbot County fell from 29.5% to 16.9% proficiency in fifth grade science. The county dropped from 30% to 20.1% in eighth grade science. District-wide rankings fell four spots for each category, as Talbot is now 19th in fifth grade science and 16th in eighth grade science.
"The 23-24 Maryland Comprehensive Assessment results showed modest improvement across all MD Districts," Talbot County Public Schools Superintendent Sharon Pepukayi said in a statement emailed to the Star Democrat. "In Talbot County, our overall margin of progress as a district was slightly larger than what the State achieved as a whole. These results will inform our continued work on the initiatives that we put in place to provide our educators with the resources needed to ensure student success. We also know that student success is measured by many indicators in addition to state assessment scores."
CAROLINETendencies for Caroline County Public Schools in math and reading proficiency align with state trends. However, like Talbot, Caroline County dropped in rankings for science proficiency.
English proficiency rose 2.1% to 45.3%. Math proficiency rose 3.9% to 19.7%. Both rankings slot Caroline County at 15th statewide.
Caroline County's proficiency marks went from 34.4% to 17% in fifth grade science and 22.1% to 19.3% in eighth grade science. The district's rankings fell from 13th to 18th in fifth grade science and 15th to 17th in eighth grade science.
DORCHESTERWhile Dorchester County Public Schools still ranks in the bottom four for English and math proficiency rates, the district did see year-to-year increases in those two categories.
In English, the district rose 1.4% to 33.7% proficiency, which ranks 22nd in the state. In math, the district rose 1% to 12.3% proficiency, which ranks 21st in the state.
Dorchester County's science proficiency marks went from 23.5% to 14.4% at the fifth grade level, and from 19.1% to 15.3% at the eighth grade level. Its fifth grade science ranking, though, did increase from 22nd to 20th.

title: Pastoral Ponderings: Back to school
author: PASTOR KEVIN WALL Greater Impact
content:
Pastoral Ponderings: Back to school

 August 27, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: PASTOR KEVIN WALL Greater Impact | Section: Columns 
 
 283
 Words 

 Read News Document

 So school is starting or has started for almost everyone, and we all have the same question — how do I prepare myself and my child for another year?We get lists from our children's schools and teachers about things they need like, paper, pencils, notebooks, calculators and computers, including paper towels and disinfectant wipes. With all the "back-to-school" sales, getting these things for the best price can be really time-consuming.
Once you have all those physical things ready, how do you prepare yourself and your child?
In her article "How To Spiritually Prepare for Back To School," Shelby Turner suggests that we need to do more. She says that we need to commit to diligently praying for our children. We need to pray for their safety, friendships, academic success and character growth. We have to remember that school makes a massive impression on our children.
Here are a few prompts and scriptures to help you:
For faith, pray Ephesians 3:14-19 and ask God to firmly establish your children in the love of Christ.
For friends, pray over them Romans 12:2 asking God to bring godly friends into their lives.
For academics, pray Proverbs 2:6 asking God to give them the passion they need to gain wisdom.
For character, pray Deuteronomy 31:6 praying that the Lord will give them the courage to try new things, make new friends and be a witness for you.
And finally, for safety and success, pray Psalms 91:1 and Colossians 3:23 asking God to keep them safe and to work in all things not for man's glory for the glory of the Lord.
So, get the physical taken care of and continue to work on the spiritual daily for the entire 180 days of this school year.

title: Plans to address test scores, cell phones shared by district staff at Moms for Liberty meeting
author: Veronica Fernandez-Alvarado
content:
Plans to address test scores, cell phones shared by district staff at Moms for Liberty meeting

 August 28, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Veronica Fernandez-Alvarado | Section: Local News 
 
 686
 Words 

 Read News Document

 EASTON — On Monday evening, Talbot County's chapter of Moms for Liberty, a nationwide conservative political organization, held a meeting with Sharon Pepukayi, superintendent of Talbot County Public Schools, and other district professionals.During this meeting, attendees shared their concerns about the state of education in Talbot County, including low math scores, and student cell phone use.
Jan Greenhawk, chapter chair for Moms for Liberty, expressed gratitude for the attendance of the district representatives, including Debbie Gardner, director of communications for Talbot County Public Schools; Helga Einhorn, assistant superintendent for school leadership and Student Success; and Vulieka Jarmon-Horsey, assistant superintendent of administrative services, systems and strategies.
"Y'all don't realize what a privilege it is to have a superintendent and a school board and her staff that will come in and talk to your group and answer questions," Greenhawk said. "Believe me when I say that because I have friends who are chapter chairs on the western shore. That does not happen."
Greenhawk noted there may be times "we disagree, and that's okay, but we can talk through issues."
During the meeting, Pepukayi shared news of a research-based math and English language arts curriculums that will be implemented in schools.
In addition to the new curriculum, the county has added some positions to help, such as math coaches. According to Pepukayi, while these changes are important, it is essential to roll it out slowly so as to not overwhelm teachers.
Pepukayi's emphasis on changes to the math curriculum comes after an anonymous countywide postcard was mailed to county residents criticizing Talbot County Public Schools.
The 14-by-8.5-inch, two-sided post cards were sent out to the residents of Talbot County last week. The flyers included a screenshot from the U.S. News & World Report's web page on the district's finances, and on the other side they shared that Talbot County students' math proficiency stands 17.2% below the state average.
Shari Wilcoxon, an attendee of the meeting, expressed concern over the postcards that were sent to residents. She told representatives in the meeting that there will be "multiple other ones coming out."
The following morning, a second round of similar postcards arrived in residents' mailboxes. Instead of addressing math scores, this postcard addressed English proficiency, stating that 59% of students in third through eighth grade are not proficient in English.
CELL PHONE USE
During the question-and-answer portion of the meeting, several attendees asked for the district's overall stance on student cell phone usage during school hours. Pepukayi shared the district's policy on cell phone usage may be different from what is practiced in the classroom.
Pepukayi said the district is piloting a new program called YONDER as a way to limit cell phone usage in the classroom.
"It's a cell phone pouch, and what it is is a student comes into school, they put their cell phone in this pouch, and it locks," Pepukayi said.
According to Pepukayi, the pouches will stay with the students and will be locked all day until they leave and press the pouch up against a magnet, which will allow them access to their cell phones.
Pepukayi said the roll out of the pouches have not begun yet. The district would need to communicate the plan with families and have a board presentation on it. The draft plan is to start rollout after Thanksgiving.
Robert Jurrius, a math teacher at Easton Middle School, said it is difficult for students to stay off their cell phones, but it is made worse by parents who text their kids during school hours.
"I'm going to say with all authority that I can muster, (parents) need to break that addiction that you have to be able to reach a child every time anything occurs," Jurrius said.
Toward the end of the meeting, Pepukayi said it was important for her to take the time to talk to community groups and hear their concerns. It falls under the district's theme of "transforming and performing together."
"I'm a big proponent of people knowing the facts, and number two, making sure we're partnering with anyone who wants to help our Talbot County Public students be successful," Pepukayi said. "And so whatever that looks like, we'll partner and we'll talk about the issues."

title: Leonard Hall Junior Naval Academy prepares for move after a century
author: Michael Reid mreid@somdnews.com
content:
Leonard Hall Junior Naval Academy prepares for move after a century

 August 28, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Michael Reid mreid@somdnews.com | Section: News 
 
 655
 Words 

 Read News Document

 Following a difficult several months, Leonard Hall Junior Naval Academy is finally righting the ship and looking to leave its long-time port.The academy, which currently has just 15 students in grades 6 through 12, did not have its lease renewed by the St. Mary's County commissioners earlier this year and is looking for a new home.
"We are working closely with the commissioners to find the right place for us," said Leonard Hall Junior Naval Academy Board of Trustees President Amie Milan, who said the academy was currently on a month-to-month lease and is looking at a few locations in the county, though she wouldn't say which ones. "If we need more time, we'll work with the county and we'll build on that time and then move when it is appropriate."
Milan said a move from where the academy has been for the past 115 years would require "a lot of logistics. You just have to be prepared."
She added that a move could be made as early as this fall.
"I'd love to stay here because of our history, but no matter where we are, we're still Leonard Hall," Anita Drury, a Leonard Hall graduate and historian of the school, said.
In January, the county commissioners voted to terminate the academy's lease as of June 30 this year.
The situation became even more awkward when a letter about the premature closing of the school was sent out at the time.
"I've heard the incredible impact the school has had in helping students turn their lives around," Commissioner Eric Colvin (R) said in January.
The commissioners eventually agreed to the month-to-month lease after the school temporarily closed following the January decision.
On Monday, Milan said, "We recognize [the commissioners] have no ill will toward the school."
The academy had 40 students in January, but ended the school year with less than 10.
"It's been challenging," Drury said. "We've gone through all the emotions you'd expect us to go through."
During Leonard Hall's open house on Monday afternoon, Jemi Camlin of Charles County said her son Israel "was just very dismissive, had a bad attitude and he used to talk back."
"He went from failing summer school to a 4.0 [GPA] in 18 months," at the Leonard Hall, Camlin said, adding he is now in his third year and a squad leader. "I love just the discipline, I love the organization, that they can be more accountable, the family aspect and the small and individualized classrooms."
Milan's son, eighth-grader Rex Bothwell, said he earned all Ds and Fs in public school, but after transferring to Leonard Hall had all As and one B so far.
"I like the etiquette and how they teach," he said. "I like the establishment about the military and how they do things around here. I like how they establish classes and they give us a timely manner to us to get things done. It's really made an impact on my grades."
Leonard Hall, which is a nonprofit that depends on funding from tuition and donations, currently has 15 students and six teachers.
"Right now we need to clear the air because there's a lot of misinformation out there," Milan said. "A lot of people still think we're closed. [We want to] communicate the positive aspects and try and put that [last] year behind us ... We want to focus on the kids that are here today and make sure they have the best opportunity to learn in the military and academic environment we've established, regardless of the facility we're in."
Milan added she would like to get enrollment up to 100, which she said "is doable."
"If we could have a solid, stable year for these kids, I think that's probably the bigger impact," Milan said. "We've all gone through the stages of frustration, of anger, of is this going to work, is it not going to work? Then we get calls from parents saying, 'We need you. My kids need Leonard Hall,' and that's what keeps us going."

title: "ArtScene | the Podcast" kicks off new season, new school year
author: Staff Writer
content:
"ArtScene | the Podcast" kicks off new season, new school year

 August 29, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Staff Writer | Section: Entertainment 
 
 413

 "ArtScene | The Podcast" — which features Centreville Middle School art teacher Jackie Jablecki — launched a new episode Sept. 1 to kickoff the 2024-2025 school year.Jablecki shares her compelling journey from personal loss to professional triumph, illustrating how her passion for art and education has shaped her career and touched the lives of her students.
Jablecki began her teaching career at Kent Island Elementary before transitioning to middle school, and she has always felt a deep connection to art—a passion she inherited from her father, a skilled glass artist. Her path has been anything but straightforward, marked by significant personal challenges, including the loss of her father at a young age and her own battle with a rare genetic mutation, which led to life-altering surgeries. Despite these hurdles, Jablecki's love for adventure and art has driven her to excel in her career and inspire her students.
In this episode, Jablecki discusses the transformative power of art education, especially within a TAB (Teaching for Artistic Behavior) classroom. She shares how her student-centered approach empowers young artists to explore their creativity and develop confidence. Jablecki recalls a particularly touching success story about a seventh grade student who, initially struggling with a self-portrait assignment, ultimately produced work that exceeded all expectations—demonstrating the profound impact of perseverance and support in the classroom.
Jablecki also speaks about her involvement with the Art of Education University, where she recently completed her Master's degree and is involved in an exciting project documenting "A Year in the Life of an Art Teacher" as a YouTube Vlog series. This achievement, alongside her dedication to continuous professional development, underscores her commitment to providing the best educational experience for her students. Her enthusiasm for visual journaling and choice-based art education has made her classroom a haven for creativity, where every student is encouraged to trust the process and embrace artistic challenges.
An adventurer at heart, Jablecki also shares stories of her travels, including a recent trip through France and Spain. This experience, she says, was not just about seeing new places but about connecting her students with the wider world through the lens of art.
"ArtScene | The Podcast" is dedicated to exploring the personal lives of our teachers, providing a glimpse into their world and the stories of who inspires our communities.

title: Time to reframe conversation about literacy
author: LISA BLOTTENBERGER and TRISH BRENNAN-GAC
content:
Time to reframe conversation about literacy

 August 31, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: LISA BLOTTENBERGER and TRISH BRENNAN-GAC | Section: Columns 
 
 774
 Words 

 Read News Document

 The Maryland State Department of Education's draft literacy policy aims to establish a framework to support students and teachers. Yet, the conversation around this policy has been dominated by the issue of retention. By doing so, we are overlooking its broader intent: creating a robust support system.With the Maryland State Board of Education discussing this policy last Tuesday, it's time we shift our focus to what truly matters: preparing and empowering our children to become fluent readers.
MSDE's draft policy seeks to tackle the reading crisis by addressing far more than the potential retention of students. It seeks to equip teachers with the tools, training and resources they need to foster foundational reading skills in every child, track their progress and provide strategic, targeted interventions when necessary. The draft policy includes several critical components designed to achieve this goal, yet these have been largely overlooked in the public discourse.
One of the most vital aspects of the draft policy is how it leverages the Ready to Read Act with its emphasis on early screening and assessment. Historically, teachers have lacked resources and guidance to identify and address reading deficiencies early on. The draft policy aims to change that by providing a step-by-step guide that helps teachers flag students who may be at risk, identify the specific skills they need to develop, and target the support students need.
Another cornerstone of the policy is the emphasis on professional learning and coaching. Diagnostics are only effective if teachers know how to use the results to inform instruction.
The draft policy outlines a plan for ongoing professional development to equip teachers with the knowledge and skills they need to support students at every stage. Training and support, with regard to the science of reading, must be provided to all teachers of reading, pre-K to 12 in order for the data to translate into improved student outcomes.
The draft policy also introduces the concept of a Student Reading Improvement Plan. This plan is designed to be a collaborative effort between teachers and parents, ensuring that everyone involved in a child's education is on the same page. To bridge the gap between the technical language used by educators and what parents can easily understand, MSDE is developing a toolkit that educators can use to communicate more effectively with parents.
While much of the debate has centered on retention, it's crucial to understand that this policy is as much about prevention as it is about intervention. Perhaps retaining students may indeed prevent those who lack foundational reading skills from advancing and ultimately falling through the cracks. We say "may" because we acknowledge the research is complex and the findings are mixed.
However, if the state adopts a retention approach, it must be implemented with great care. Retention should be strategically designed as a last-resort intervention, after all other support measures have been exhausted.
In some cases, retention might be a more effective short-term solution than advancing students who are not prepared, as long as additional time and support are provided. And, we should recognize that the retention component of the policy may incentivize districts to collaborate closely with the MSDE, ensuring shared responsibility for implementing a comprehensive system of support for all students.
Finally, if we are serious about addressing the reading crisis, we need to extend our focus beyond early elementary grades. Middle and high school students who lack foundational reading skills require targeted interventions to help them catch up. This will extend to students who may be advancing to high grades without the foundational skills needed to master challenging texts. The conversation about retention should therefore include discussions about how we support older students who have fallen behind.
MSDE's draft literacy policy represents a comprehensive statewide approach to improving literacy. However, the public discourse has been too narrowly focused on the issue of retention, neglecting the critical support that the policy seeks to provide. It's time we change this conversation and recognize the full scope of the policy's potential. It's a straightforward approach that, if implemented correctly, could have a significant impact on literacy outcomes for all Maryland students.
By focusing on assessments, comprehensive professional development and coaching, and better parental engagement, we can create a system that not only addresses the reading crisis but also ensures that every child in Maryland has the opportunity to become a fluent, confident reader. An ongoing dialogue with MSDE to learn how they are responding to the feedback they received is essential to building public trust and educators' buy-in to the final policy.
Lisa Blottenberger is the founder of Boundless Expectations Inc., a Maryland READS board member and co-founder of Decoding Dyslexia Maryland. Trish Brennan-Gac is the executive director of Maryland READS.

title: Aiming to fly: Civil Air Patrol holds open house for young, aspiring pilots
author: Michael Reid mreid@somdnews.com
content:
Aiming to fly: Civil Air Patrol holds open house for young, aspiring pilots

 September 4, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Michael Reid mreid@somdnews.com | Section: News 
 
 671
 Words 

 Read News Document

 Ainsley Taylor always dreamed of being a pilot, but the highest the homeschooled 14–year-old had ever been was when she rode rollercoasters at amusement parks."I've always wanted to fly," said Taylor, who lives in Lexington Park. "I love the adrenaline rush of being up high and going really fast."
Taylor, who joined the Civil Air Patrol two years ago, is reaching her goal of elevating more than the highest loops at Six Flags after having flown in a Cessna four times. She also recently was able to take a ride in a C-130 military transport.
"I know I really want to be an F-35 pilot," she said.
The Civil Air Patrol held an open house Aug. 28 at the St. Mary's County Regional Airport, welcoming young potential members from the community.
"We're here to tell members of the general public about our program," Wing Cadet Program Director David Trick said of the CAP cadet program, which is open to members in Grade 6 through 21 years of age. "Of course a lot of folks that are here this evening are here to hear about our cadet program [which offers] career exploration in the United States military as well as careers in aviation. It's a fantastic program that gives folks the opportunity to learn to fly, explore careers in aviation, perform search and rescue, perform community service and do a variety of other things that are beneficial to themselves and their community."
Cadets usually stay in the program, which is an auxiliary of the Air Force, from ages 12 to 17, though they are able to remain until they are 21. The program's core values are integrity, excellence, volunteer service and respect.
There are squadrons in Calvert, St. Mary's and Charles counties.
The program is exactly why Charles and Emma David stopped by with their 11-year-old daughter Amelia.
Charles, who retired three months ago following a 20-year career in the U.S. Marine Corps and Army National Guard, said he and his wife found out about the CAP during a middle school orientation.
"We both kind of thought, 'This would be a great thing where we can do father-daughter things together,'" he said. "I think it's a great opportunity for students of all ages to be able to participate in their county, their community and have a hand in civil service."
Emma David said she likes "that they're giving children of this age structure, values and they're striving for excellence. Just to have that in a world of chaos to have something very structured like this and can instill good values in children for the future. I don't think you can go wrong with that."
Amelia, who attends Margaret Brent Middle School, said she liked what she saw.
"I think it's amazing for kids to have an opportunity like this at such a young age to be able to have different opportunities like flying planes, getting to do emergency rescue service and getting able to survive in the wilderness for a week," she said. "Getting to do all these fun things at 11 just sounds fun."
Inside, a large throng of parents and their children browsed through literature and listened to testimonies by current members.
Taylor's brother Eric joined CAP before her and at first Taylor thought the idea of joining was a "hard no."
"I didn't think I'd be interested in it or that it wouldn't be for me," the cadet master sergeant said. "And then I learned I could fly and get my pilot's license and I thought, 'Oh, that's really cool.'"
Evelyn Roulhand's father was an F-18 pilot at Naval Air Station Patuxent River, and a friend suggested she check out the program.
"I know a lot of people where [the military aspect] was not their forte, but they came and really enjoyed it," said the 16-year-old St. Inigoes resident. "There are so many branches in this program that it's almost a certainty you will find something."
And does Roulhand even envision herself leaving the Civil Air Patrol after almost four years?
"No sir, I don't," she said.
For more information on the Civil Air Patrol, go to www.gocivilairpatrol.com.

title: School lunches through the years
author: MARIE SAVAGE Country Cooking
content:
School lunches through the years

 September 10, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: MARIE SAVAGE Country Cooking | Section: Food 
 
 1055
 Words 

 Read News Document

 School lunches have changed through the years, but students have always looked forward to that middle-of-the-day break.Talking with friends and sharing events and stories is most important to a young student who may have limited access to conversing with friends outside the school day. I know times have changed, but some policies have remained intact from my school days. I was an elementary student in the 1950s — no talking anywhere in that building. But during recess, we screamed and hollered until downtown Bishopville heard us.
School lunch is important for students to have a successful day at school. Not all kids eat or even want breakfast — whether at home or the ones served at school each day, so a nutritious lunch is very important. Some students like to have packed lunches from home.
Now what was packed in my lunch box? In the winter, Mom would sometimes put homemade soup, and in the spring she put Kool-Aid drink. The sandwiches were usually the favorite in the 1950s, bologna with mustard and sometimes cheese, but mostly bologna. Sometimes we took a homemade biscuit with a piece of fried ham leftover from supper the night before.
Let's explore some lunches today's students like — either from home or the lunch line.
BBQ CHICKEN CUPS1 roll of Pillsbury Grands biscuits (usually the Southern style works best but you can use any flavor your child likes), 3 lbs chicken breast, 1 cup chicken broth, 1 tsp salt, 1 tsp pepper, 1 tsp garlic powder, 1 tsp onion powder, barbecue sauce.
Place chicken breasts in the bottom of the crockpot. Pour chicken broth and seasonings over chicken. Cook on low for 6-8 hours or high for 3-4 hours. Remove chicken from the crockpot and shred with two forks. Mix with your favorite barbecue or hot sauce. Bake the biscuits according to directions, then immediately when they are done tear a biscuit in half and flatten it, place it into a muffin tin, top with chicken and shredded cheese, and bake at 350 degrees for 15-20 minutes.
PB&J APPLES2 apples, 1/4 cup peanut butter, 1/4 cup jelly.
Slice apples into ¼-inch rounds. Use a small cookie cutter to cut the core from the center of each slice. Spread peanut butter on jelly on half of the slices then cover with the remaining halves. This is one that you'll want to make in the morning so the apples don't brown overnight.
PB&J SUSHI4 slices white bread, 1/2 cup smooth peanut butter, 1/2 cup grape jelly.
Remove crusts from bread. Using a rolling pin, roll bread until very flat. Spread with peanut butter and jelly and roll tightly. Cut into 2-inch pieces and serve.
PICKLE ROLL UPS4 slices of your child's favorite lunch meat, mustard or mayo, cheese, pickle wedge.
Spread mustard or mayo on the slices of meat, layer some cheese then another layer of meat. Roll a pickle wedge up and pack tight. You can use any variety of meat, cheese or condiments in this dish.
TURKEY CLUB ROLL UPS4 slices deli turkey, 2 tsp mayo, 2 slices cheddar (halved or quartered), 1/2 cup shredded or chopped lettuce, 1/2 tomato (sliced), 1/4 red onion (thinly sliced), 1/2 avocado (sliced), 4 slices cooked bacon, kosher salt, freshly ground black pepper.
On a clean work surface, place two slices of deli turkey and spread a thin layer of mayo on top. Top with 1 slice cheddar, half of the lettuce, tomato, red onion and avocado, and 2 slices bacon. Season generously with salt and pepper. Roll up and secure with a toothpick, then repeat with remaining ingredients.
GRILLED CHEESE ROLL UPS8 thick slices of soft white bread, 1.5 cups finely grated cheddar, 2 tbsp melted butter.
One by one, slice the crusts off of each slice of bread, then use a rolling pin to flatten. Add a pinch of cheese to each slice, making sure you leave a small strip at the end to brush with butter. Tightly but carefully roll up each slice to the end, brush with butter, then roll shut and place seam-side-down. Brush all over with butter. Add roll ups to a dry pan seam-side-down over low-medium heat and fry until golden all over with the cheese starting to leak out. Use your tongs to frequently turn them. You may need to do this in two batches depending on the size of your pan.
NUTELLA BANANA SUSHIThis recipe is by the single serving, so repeat as many times as you need.
Nutella, 1 banana, 1 whole wheat wrap.
Lay your wrap on a breadboard and slather with Nutella, Place the banana on top of your chocolate coating, Roll the wrap as you would sushi or a burrito and carefully slice into rolls.
HAM, MAC N CHEESE MUFFINS2 cups of your favorite macaroni and cheese, 2 large eggs (beaten), 1 cup diced ham, 1/4 cup breadcrumbs + 2 tbsps. Combine macaroni and cheese with eggs, ham and 1/4 cup breadcrumbs.
Stir until well combined. Spray eight openings in a muffin tin with non-stick spray. Use an ice cream scoop to add 1/2 cup of mixture to each cup. Gently press mixture down with your fingers to flatten it into each cup. Sprinkle with additional bread crumbs. Bake in a 350-degree oven for 20-25 minutes depending on how soft or firm you prefer your muffins. Immediately remove from cups to cool on a wire rack. Refrigerate after 30 minutes of cooling.
RICE KRISPIE PEANUT BUTTER BANANAS2 bananas, peanut butter, 1 cup of crispy rice cereal, foil or parchment paper so you don't have to wipe peanut butter smears off your counter.
First peel the bananas and cut them into thirds. Then dump some cereal onto your wax paper, smear the bananas in peanut butter and roll the peanut butter bananas in the cereal.
PEPPERONI PIZZA STICKS1 Pillsbury pizza crust, 40 pepperoni slices, 10 mozzarella cheese sticks, 2 tbsp butter, 1/2 tsp garlic powder, 1/2 tsp dried parsley, your favorite marinara sauce for dipping.
Preheat the oven to 450 degrees. Spread pizza dough out on a lightly greased baking sheet. Cut the dough into 10 equal size rectangles. Arrange 4 pepperoni slices on each rectangle and top with a mozzarella cheese stick. Roll up the pizza dough, enclosing the cheese stick, pinching the seams closed. Melt the butter and add the garlic powder and dried parsley. Brush the pizza sticks with the butter. Bake for 10 to 12 minutes or until golden brown.

author: ANDREA GRABENSTEIN agrabenstein@chespub.com
content:
County agrees to audit of school system financial records

 September 11, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: ANDREA GRABENSTEIN agrabenstein@chespub.com | Section: News 
 
 494
 Words 

 Read News Document

 CENTREVILLE — The Queen Anne's County Commissioners unanimously approved hiring an independent auditing firm to conduct a performance audit of the Queen Anne's County Public School's Board of Education's financial records and budgetary development procedures Sept. 10."The county does not suspect any fraudulent activity, but believes it is prudent for transparency to our citizens that we engage a third party firm to conduct a performance audit in order to assess the operational decisions of the school system, evaluate whether the finance office is properly structured and designed to deliver a complete, accurate, reliable financial information and ensure that no fraud is occurring," said Commissioner President Jim Moran, presenting a statement from the County Commissioners.
The Board of Education is funded by both the county and the state of Maryland and has faced several challenges over the past few years, "Which has now led to potential staff and service reductions to our local school system," he said.
According to Moran, financial challenges faced by the Board of Education include:
Significant turnover and instability in its accounting function over the past several years, particularly in the Chief Financial Officer position and finance office.
Request for operational funding for the FY 24-25 fiscal year that far exceeded its maintenance of effort requirements and previously agreed upon increases
Budgetary requests that have increased materially over the time despite flat student enrollment numbers.
"Despite these concerns, the commissioners provided an additional $6.2 million in funding over last year's FY 24, which is $7 million above the required MOE (Maintenance of Effort), Moran said. This equates to a total county allocation of $75.1 million plus an additional $42.1 million in state funding, for a total operating budget of $118,400,000 for FY 25, according to Moran.
"However, the board is currently operating with a projected budgetary deficit just six weeks into FY 25 and there are concerns that this trend will continue to get worse in the coming years," he said.
The commissioners reiterated the audit was "not a witch hunt" but a means in which to support the Board of Education including assistance in identifying resources, guidelines, and best practices with the County's Finance Department and the Spending Affordability Committee.
Commissioner Chris Corchiarino noted when things go wrong some people have a tendency to get caught up in the blame game and not put forth viable solutions.
"We want to fix things," he said.
Commissioner Jack Wilson noted the audit would be a good first step and "huge push toward transparency across the board" and with the current fiscal state of Maryland, time was of the essence.
Commissioner Phil Dumenil noted Superintendent Patrica Saelens, the Board of Education, and leadership have been "more than cooperative" regarding the endeavor and a review of the financial books.
With the Board of Education's next fiscal year budget process beginning soon, work is underway narrowing down potential firms to expedite the auditing process as quickly as possible, and no final schedule has been set, County Administrator Todd Mohn said.
The audit is capped not to exceed $100,000.

title: Caroline County pilots cell phone pouches in schools, other districts to follow
author: KONNER METZ kmetz@chespub.com
content:
Caroline County pilots cell phone pouches in schools, other districts to follow

 September 12, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: KONNER METZ kmetz@chespub.com | Section: Local News 
 
 610
 Words 

 Read News Document

 DENTON — Some students in Caroline County are without access to their phones to begin the school year due to new cell phone restrictions.Caroline County Public Schools began a policy where students at Colonel Richardson Middle School and Lockerman Middle School put their phones in locked pouches during the day to prevent usage during class.
The students carry the pouches, designed by the company Yondr, during the entire school day, with their phones inside but not accessible. At the conclusion of school, a magnetic, unlocking device lets the students unlock the pouches and retrieve their phones.
Caroline County Public Schools Superintendent Derek Simmons said middle school was the right level to implement the test of the technology.
"Middle school students are wrestling with a lot of things, a lot of changes," Simmons said. "There's a lot going on for kids at that time, a lot of research is talking about the impact of devices on kids at that age in particular."
As Caroline County pilots the Yondr pouches, Talbot and Dorchester counties are preparing for implementation later this fall. Across the board, there is a common goal of improving in areas such as student achievement, attendance and discipline.
Simmons said his district attempted to take a strict stance on cell phone usage after the pandemic. However, teachers and administrators found it hard to enforce the policies in large classrooms and settings.
"The devil was in the details of implementation," Simmons said. "Saying it and getting folks to be able to monitor was really hard. … Being able to keep an eye on every kid who's (looking at a phone) … it's impossible."
The pouches cost about $30 each. Simmons said Yondr believes the pouches will last three to four years.
Dorchester County Public Schools will be implementing a similar pilot later this school year. Valerie Goff, DCPS communication and community outreach specialist, said the district is hoping to begin its pilot before the end of October for middle school students only.
Talbot County Public Schools may follow suit soon thereafter. At an Aug. 26 Moms for Liberty meeting with school administration, TCPS Superintendent Sharon Pepukayi said the district hopes to roll out the same Yondr pouches after Thanksgiving.
Pepukayi and Easton Middle School math teacher Robert Jurrius responded to questions about access to cell phones in the event of a school emergency.
"I need you to pay attention when something bad is happening," Jurrius said on Aug 26. "And there is no circumstance where a child looking at their phone at that moment is going to be safer. Parents might feel better that they can reach their child, but they're actually endangering their child."
"What I've heard from the emergency response and the crisis management people," Pepukayi said, "is they want students to be able to listen to the directions of where they need to go and what they need to do versus being distracted in looking at their phone."
Simmons said the same regarding the situation of a school emergency while kids' phones are locked in pouches. "If there's an absolute emergency, we need the kids to focus in on their teacher," he said.
In Caroline County Public Schools, Simmons said the district will track if there's a decrease in student discipline or increases in student focus and achievement. If results are positive, the policy could extend to other schools in the district.
While the superintendent did say the high school level "presents an interesting dilemma" and a need for balance as students are being prepared for adulthood, it's the next step if Caroline County's pilot yields improvements.
"If we do see positive impacts in the middle, it absolutely warrants that we look at it at our high schools in some settings," Simmons said.

title: Birding and boating the Harriet Tubman Byway
author: Tom McCall
content:
Birding and boating the Harriet Tubman Byway

 September 14, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Tom McCall | Section: Local News 
 
 711
 Words 

 Read News Document

 DENTON — On Thursday afternoon, a tour group traversed the Harriet Tubman Underground Railroad Scenic Byway while also spotting 25 species of birds.The event, "Birding & Boating the Harriet Tubman Byway," was hosted by Alex Green and Jim Rapp. It aimed at highlighting Tubman's accomplishments while also celebrating the nature of the Eastern Shore.
Jeanea Blair came all the way from Baltimore for the excursion.
"I love that we can combine history and nature, which I think traditionally people don't combine those things. It shows you can't really separate one from the other. The land informs our history and the history informs our land. It is cool to see that intersection and learn more about all of our history," Blair said.
The tour featured several sites that are central to the life and work Harriet Tubman, an abolitionist and social activist who escaped from slavery in Dorchester County and became well-known for her work on the Underground Railroad.
Green, owner of Harriet Tubman Tours, gave context to each site.
Rapp, owner of Delmarva Birding Weekends, was the second guide. He had a pair of binoculars around his neck and was listening for chirps, watching attentively for birds.
"Alex is interpreting the reason why Linchester Mill, The Webb Cabin and the Caroline County Courthouse has so much importance to the Underground Railroad. Then on the boat we are still interpreting both things, but I step up and do the birding portion. We sort of tag team. This tour is about Harriet Tubman's work on the Underground Railroad," Rapp said.
Many sites were visited by the caravan of cars who followed the guides. Several participants said they had driven by the Underground Railroad signs on the road, but had never stopped.
The Harriet Tubman Underground Railroad Scenic Byway is a self-guided driving tour through Caroline and Dorchester Counties, with significant sites marked with signage. It continues north to Philadelphia.
One stop was the Leverton House, which was owned by Quakers Jacob and Hannah Leverton, supporters of the Underground Railroad. It was a dairy farm at the time. Although the Levertons were wealthy, hiding and clothing those escaping slavery was a risky undertaking. Now the private home has a long dusty road with corn fields all around, turkey vultures flying overhead.
Rapp said most birds can't smell a thing.
"Vultures have a huge nasal opening and a lot of senses in there. They are sniffing for stinky, rotten stuff," Rapp said.
There was sturdy but small cabin in Preston, which was owned by James Webb. The tour went inside and got to see the "potato hole," a trap door beneath the house, under which Webb would hide people escaping on the Underground Railroad.
"This is where James Webb worked his farm and lived and worked the Underground Railroad. He was a farmer and an Underground Railroad agent," Green said.
Standing in front of the Caroline County Courthouse, where slaves were sold, Green said the land affected the slave trade. The current courthouse replaced one that burned down.
"The menacing building of the time with slave auctions would be somewhat of a fanfare. It is just like going to a car auction. This is where they sold African Americans. A lot of commerce comes up and down the river. From here you can go anywhere you need to go in the world by the Choptank River all the way to the Atlantic," Green said.
There was a former school teacher of history on the tour. She wrote her senior thesis on abolitionists.
"It is great. I am learning things that I didn't know before and supplanting things I already knew," Betty McAdams said.
When Rapp saw a handful of hummingbirds, they filled the air with a buzzing sound.
He said, "Our predominant hummingbird on the East Coast is the ruby throat. Males have a bright, shiny metallic-looking throat."
The history buffs turned into avid naturalists as the tiny birds flitted around orange jewel weed blossoms. Later in the tour the saw a red tailed hawk.
At the end, the group boarded a 33-foot tritoon named Ellen B. The captain, Allan Thomason, had his daughter Ali Thomason as first mate.
Though birding and Underground Railroad history are a unique pairing, Green and Rapp bring life to both subjects.
In the winter they come together to do a different tour in Dorchester County that focuses on Tubman's early life.

title: Easton High teacher named finalist for Maryland Teacher of the Year
author: KONNER METZ kmetz@chespub.com
content:
Easton High teacher named finalist for Maryland Teacher of the Year

 September 14, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: KONNER METZ kmetz@chespub.com | Section: Local News 
 
 671
 Words 

 Read News Document

 EASTON — Every day in the classroom, Jeremy Hillyard keeps a simple, two-word phrase in mind: "Yes, and."He learned the phrase from his involvement in Improv Easton, a local comedy group. It's meant to encourage improvisers to listen to their partners and appreciate their ideas.
"I hear what you're saying, I'm going to honor it, and I'm going to grow from it," Hillyard says.
As a Spanish and English as a second language math teacher at Easton High School, Hillyard embraces the "Yes, and" philosophy with his students. It's a core message he has delivered to teachers across Talbot County and the state since he was named Talbot County Public Schools' 2024-25 Teacher of the Year in April.
"That philosophy has really carried over with me into the classroom," Hillyard said. "Having my students know that I have a genuine interest in them as human beings and that I will do what I need to do to support them."
On Wednesday, Hillyard was named one of seven finalists for Maryland Teacher of the Year by the state's Board of Education. A selection panel nailed down finalists from 24 district teachers of the year through a rigorous application and evaluation process.
Hillyard was shocked when he heard the news of his selection as a finalist from colleagues who texted him congratulations.
"I'm like, 'What are they talking about?'" he recalled. "I checked my email and it said I was a state finalist, and I was like, 'Holy cow, I'm a state finalist?'"
Hillyard and the other finalists will attend a reception in Baltimore on Oct. 4 where the Maryland Teacher of the Year will be announced.
"It's very, very humbling, and I'm very grateful to know that my efforts to go above and beyond are being recognized," Hillyard said.
STEPPING UPHillyard has taught at Easton High School since 2010. His original background is in the foreign language department. Last year, the school was in need of a teacher for its English for speakers of other languages, or ESOL, math course.
Having a certification to teach math, he stepped in and took on the workload without any hesitation.
"To me, the best teacher is when they see an educational need that they can help with, they do it," Hillyard said. "They jump in there and do it."
By using his skill sets in math and Spanish, he's been able to embrace the challenge of teaching children at a wide variety of progress levels in their English abilities. Depending on their backgrounds, some may come in on track in math, but unable to complete operations in English.
Hillyard lays the groundwork by starting with basic math in English and then moving to more advanced arithmetic as the full-year course continues.
"They each come with a set of their own challenges and strengths and weaknesses," Hillyard said. "That kind of challenge pushes me to want to figure out a way to overcome those or address those."
LOOKING AHEADHillyard and the other 23 district teachers recognized this cycle will have opportunities to explore the state and collaborate throughout the upcoming months. Hillyard's excited for that journey, which includes stops at Deep Creek Lake in Garrett County and the statehouse in Annapolis.
With the school year beginning, he said he's also excited to advance initiatives with colleagues at Easton High.
Recently, the morning announcements have been presented in both English and Spanish, with the help of Hillyard's Advanced Placement Spanish class. He's hoping small improvements will make the growing number of Spanish-speaking students feel more welcomed at Easton High.
"I'm very excited in my school to be working with some colleagues at making our entire school a more equitable environment for our Spanish-speaking community or multilingual community," Hillyard said.
No matter the background of a student, the district teacher of the year aims to play a supporting role in the student's academic journey.
"The students, at the end of the day, they're the authors," Hillyard says.
"That positive relationship and them knowing that my classroom is a safe, supportive place and they can learn and be themselves without being judged or criticized, is truly the secret ingredient."

 Lucas Thorpe, co-founder and executive director of All4Love, spoke to members of the Rotary Club of Cambridge about the organization and the work it is doing with the youth of Dorchester County.He said 10 years ago he and Khail Johnson formed a brotherly love based on their combined interest in youth. Thorpe was born and raised in Dorchester County, graduating form North Dorchester High School. After graduating, he attended Chesapeake College and the University of Maryland Eastern Shore.

title: For Dorchester superintendent, it's all about teaching and learning
author: MAGGIE TROVATO mtrovato@chespub.com
content:
For Dorchester superintendent, it's all about teaching and learning

 September 19, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: MAGGIE TROVATO mtrovato@chespub.com | Section: Local News 
 
 746
 Words 

 Read News Document

 CAMBRIDGE — When Dorchester County Public Schools Superintendent Jymil Thompson stepped into a third grade classroom at Sandy Hill Elementary during one of the first weeks of the school year, he saw sheer energy."They might have been doing a social emotional learning lesson," Thompson recalled. "And the kids were so involved. They were standing up in their chairs. And the teacher was so energetic."
Everyone was engaged. And for the student that didn't want to get involved, the teacher had him help her with the lesson on the computer so that he was still participating.
Neither the third grade teacher nor the school's principal knew Thompson would be stopping by Sandy Hill Elementary that day.
"And so you know it wasn't a dog and pony show," he said.
For Thompson, who visits the school system's buildings and classrooms every week, the reason for these visits isn't to catch principals and teachers doing the wrong thing. It's to create a comfortable atmosphere of teaching and learning and to offer guidance when needed.
"I used to be a principal, I used to be assistant principal and teacher," Thompson said. "So I want to make sure that they are comfortable with me and know I'm here to help better them and get them supports to be better."
Since becoming superintendent in June, Thompson has made known his hope of bringing the district's ranking up from 23rd to 15th in the state. In an effort to do this in four years, the district has identified different steps to making that happen.
This year, the district is focusing on instructional leadership, taking a top-down approach in an effort to improve student success. Thompson considers instructional leadership — or leadership that focuses on teaching and learning — as his top priority this school year.
"Outside of the teacher, administration has the most impact on student achievement, without a doubt," he said, adding that because principals oversee the entire school, and not just one classroom, they have the most impact on student achievement.
Jodi Colman, assistant superintendent of academics and student services, said that Dorchester County is usually toward the bottom when it comes to rankings among the other school districts in the state.
"And at this point in time, the only way we're going to change that rating and our students are going to start performing at higher academic levels is (if we) focus on instructional leadership within the school system," she said.
In March, the Dorchester County Board of Education approved a purchasing agreement to bring coaching and professional development support for district administrators.
Thompson, the then-interim superintendent, said at the March 25 board meeting that the district executive team expects all its principals to become "great instructional leaders," but not enough professional development has been provided to those leaders.
On Sept. 16, Thompson said this professional development support includes leadership meetings twice per month that focus on how administrators should give feedback to teachers on how to improve in the classroom.
"Making sure that (administrators are) continually developing (teachers') skills to deliver the best instruction to the kids," he said.
In order to jump from 23rd in the state to 15th in four years, Thompson said the district will need to be consistent with developing instructional leadership and follow through on it.
"Making sure that I'm having meetings with the principals, having conversations on how they're progressing on their goals," he said. "And if they're not progressing, how can we shift and go in a little different direction to ensure that they're meeting their goals?"
Thompson thinks one of the biggest challenges the district faces this year will be getting people comfortable with change and holding them accountable to those changes. He said that often, people automatically think accountability is negative, but when you don't hold people accountable, you end up doing them a disservice.
"We don't want to fire anybody," he said. "We want people to do what they were hired to do. And we want to be able to provide the supports when people are struggling at their craft, and then help them improve their craft. When we talk about accountability, that's what we mean."
Colman said that change can be uncomfortable. She said she hopes that by the end of the year, people in the district will find a comfort in being uncomfortable.
"We're only going to make this move if we all know that we've got the same target and (know) that we're all going to have to push ourselves to probably go and do things that we're not normally used to doing," she said.

title: Talbot school board sees test scores, improvement initiatives
author: KONNER METZ kmetz@chespub.com
content:
Talbot school board sees test scores, improvement initiatives

 September 19, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: KONNER METZ kmetz@chespub.com | Section: Local News 
 
 836
 Words 

 Read News Document

 EASTON — State test scores released last month show a slight increase in math and English proficiency levels at both the district and state levels.Talbot County's Board of Education discussed that trend and others during a work session on Monday, taking a first deep dive into the test results from 2023-2024's Maryland Comprehensive Assessment Program.
In English, 47.3% of Talbot County Public Schools students tested proficient, a jump of 2.8% from 44.5% in 2022-2023. In math, 18.3% of students were proficient, up 1.1% from 17.2% the year prior. The district slots in 14th and 18th, respectively, in those categories among the state's 24 districts.
ENGLISH TRENDS"One of the things that the board is always interested in is how does Talbot County Public Schools compare to other districts in the state," said Helga Einhorn, assistant superintendent of school leadership, while presenting the English results. "And I wish that I could give you better news and say that we have flip-flopped the map, but if you compare this year's results to last year across the state, you will see very little change. There is not a single district in the state who is leapfrogging in improvements on this map."
Einhorn and Superintendent Sharon Pepukayi emphasized that the district internally tracks student learning levels. This is done at benchmarks throughout the year.
"I can assure this board that more than 47% of our students are mastering grade level standards," Einhorn said of the English proficiency rate. "It's just that they are not showing it across the state on this particular assessment."
Some positives for the English rates included third grade proficiency and the growth for certain cohorts and subgroups. Third grade English proficiency saw a significant jump from the 2022-2023 school year.
Einhorn pointed out that in 2023, sixth grade students were 40.1% proficient. That same group of students came in at 43.8% proficient on the seventh grade test. "For that cohort of students, it's growth," Einhorn said.
Einhorn said all student groups saw growth in English rates, though Black students had the smallest increase.
"We are reaching every student in some sense, in some capacity," Board President Emily Jackson said of the subgroups. "Maybe not as well as we could, but we're getting there, we are making growth, and that's what I want to see."
MATH TRENDSIn math, the district has many initiatives to increase proficiency. Einhorn said the number of elementary math coaches has increased from three to six, along with an addition of one middle school math coach.
The district is implementing an adaptive testing program called Measures of Academic Progress for kindergarten through eighth grade to track student growth.
In 2023-2024's state test scores, TCPS students showed increases across the board.
"We see slight increases for each one of our student groups," Einhorn said. "We have less of an increase for our Hispanic and Latino students. And we still continue to have fewer than 5% of our Black students and our multilingual learners proficient in mathematics."
For proficiency levels below 5%, the state does not indicate exact percentages. Of the 24 districts, the Talbot district is one of three below the 5% mark in math proficiency among Black students, and one of nine districts below the 5% mark in math proficiency among multilingual students.
Einhorn and Jackson each thanked the Talbot County Council for its commitment in funding education, particularly the math coaches in elementary schools.
"When you see movement like we did in third grade," Jackson said, "I think that we are making really intentional, really important, really good funding decisions that have a big impact on learning."
EXPERT REVIEWSAs required by the state's education initiative, Blueprint for Maryland's Future, experts vetted by the Maryland Department of Education will be reviewing school districts across the state. Einhorn said state reviewers will be visiting three elementary schools in Talbot County this year.
Those schools will be Chapel District Elementary, St. Michaels Elementary and White Marsh Elementary. They were chosen for separate reasons. Einhorn stated: Chapel for reviewers to look at literacy instruction, St. Michaels to review practices for multilingual learners and White Marsh due to success in state testing.
"They had significant growth in their math achievement across all grades in this last MCAP assessment," Einhorn said of White Marsh Elementary. "So they want to know what White Marsh is doing well."
Jackson asked how the district can take lessons learned from these three schools to its largest elementary school, Easton Elementary.
"Can you speak to how we plan to address that?" Jackson asked. "How do you take what you've learned at a very small, very specific population and duplicate it or replicate it at a school like Easton Elementary?"
"One of the things that we do even though it's a larger school, we have committed the same types of resources but just on a larger scale," Einhorn said. "So while our smaller elementaries might have one math coach, we see multiple math coaches to be able to service the number of classrooms that we have at Easton Elementary."
Einhorn said other schools in the district will have state reviews in the next year or two.
