title: Community school leaders in Talbot County aim to make a difference
author: Konner Metz
content:
Community school leaders in Talbot County aim to make a difference

 March 19, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Konner Metz | Section: Local News 
 
 794
 Words 

 Read News Document

 EASTON — In her third year as community school manager at Easton Elementary, Katie Fox's job is all about removing barriers for students in need and becoming a community resource."The premise of a community school is for you to be the community hub," Fox said of her role. "So you serve as a resource for everyone."
It's a relatively new position in Talbot County Public Schools and across the state. In 2019, community schools were introduced as part of The Blueprint for Maryland's Future, the state's initiative to fund and improve education.
More than 600 Maryland schools are community schools. Two are in Talbot County: Easton Elementary and Easton Middle. Those schools receive extra funds to create services for students and families in poverty.
As future funding remains up in the air this legislative session, Talbot County's two community schools are moving forward at two different stages of the process.
Last school year, Easton Elementary came up with an implementation plan and goals. Those goals are to increase availability of healthy foods, provide mental health resources, raise enrichment by 15%, and add 100 students to the school's Choptank Community Health partnership, Fox said.
Fox, a longtime teacher before taking on her current role, said those needs become apparent.
"You could probably spot test any single classroom teacher. All of those things spike up," Fox said. "Food insecurity, needing materials, clothing. All of that is prevalent in all of the spaces, especially post-pandemic."
Easton Elementary is in its third year as a community school. Starting off, the school received state funding to hire Fox's position and a health care practitioner. In Year 3, it received "per-pupil" funding to begin providing specific services and resources.
Fox said the per-pupil funding has supported before- and after-school programs and Teddy Bear Fresh Produce boxes for family events, among other programs.
Easton Middle, meanwhile, is in its first year. Community school facilitator Shelby Parks is spearheading a needs assessment that includes staff, family, student and community surveys.
At the middle school, Parks says mental health, food insecurity and transportation are focus areas.
"We can't offer too many after-school programs because we just don't have the transportation, and students are struggling," Parks said.
Fox noted that transportation to grocery stores for neighborhoods around Easton Elementary and Easton Middle is a challenge.
"We don't have a current grocery store that's within walking distance, so that's just something to consider," Fox said. "If the family doesn't have their own personal transportation, it makes it more difficult to access any kind of healthy food outside of a few restaurants that are there."
FUNDING UNCERTAINTY
Attempting to close a nearly $3 billion state deficit, Gov. Wes Moore proposed a budget in January with significant cuts and freezes to education funding, including for community schools. Many education advocates pushed back.
His budget proposed freezing community school funding at next year's levels, potentially impacting the money provided to schools such as Easton Elementary in future years.
But last week, the House of Delegates amended some of Moore's education cuts by passing a refined Blueprint education bill. The House struck through his proposed pause to community school funding and sent the bill to the Senate chamber.
Kristen Tilghman, Blueprint implementation coordinator for Talbot County Public Schools, said the district is watching closely to see if community school funding is paused or affected in any way.
The district is "going to move forward because our community clearly has a need," Tilghman added. Easton High, White Marsh Elementary and Tilghman Elementary are the district's schools next in line to become community schools. Job postings for community school program leaders are active for those three schools.
Tilghman said the state funding "sets the stage" for schools to create partnerships and assist families all over Talbot County.
"(It's) vital to the whole community, not just that particular school's community," she said.
'HELPING ALL'
Talbot school leaders emphasized that theme of not just helping the designated community schools but bettering the entire district.
For instance, Fox is involved in monthly food distributions for families across the district, not just Easton Elementary.
"Because we're a small county, I can do this heavy lift at Easton Elementary, but Easton Middle and High and Chapel (District Elementary) and Tilghman (Elementary) can benefit from some of the things that are happening," she said.
As Parks prepares to move EMS into the implementation phase next year, she's watching how Fox makes an impact at the elementary school.
"I'm excited that if Easton High comes on board, we can see trends between Easton Elementary, Easton Middle and Easton High, how it all flows, how we all work together," Parks said.
The concept of working together applies not just for every school in Talbot County, but for every student in each school. Fox said all students benefit from the community school resources and programs.
"You create something for one, it always ends up helping all," Fox said.

title: Dorchester County Council, Board of Education discuss budget concerns
author: Maggie Trovato
content:
Dorchester County Council, Board of Education discuss budget concerns

 March 19, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Maggie Trovato | Section: Local News 
 
 566
 Words 

 Read News Document

 CAMBRIDGE — Members of the Dorchester County Council and Dorchester County Board of Education highlighted the dangers of making sweeping cuts to education expenses during a County Council meeting March 18."You can't do big sweeping things that a business would do," County Council Vice President Mike Detmer said about education during the meeting.
Both the county and Dorchester County Public Schools face budget deficits for fiscal year 2026. Since January, the school district has reduced its estimated budget deficit, which is separate from the county's budget, from $10.19 million to $5.59 million. It is still looking for ways to further reduce the deficit.
Both the district and county — which gives a portion of its revenues to the district every year — have said state mandates regarding the Blueprint for Maryland's Future are affecting their budgets.
During the council meeting, DCPS Superintendent Jymil Thompson and Board of Education member and Finance Chair Chris Wheedleton presented on the district's draft budget for fiscal year 2026, reiterating what was shared during a Board of Education budget work session in late February. Thompson said the district will be presenting more changes to the budget at another Board of Education budget work session on March 20.
After the presentation, Detmer said $5 million of the district's deficit equates to a 15% increase in property tax rates.
"My question is how much do athletic programs cost?" he asked. "How much do school plays cost? How much does operating two high schools instead of one high school in the county, how much does that cost?"
Board of Education Vice President Talibah Chikwendu, who was sitting in the audience at the meeting, stood up to answer Detmer's question. She said sending all the county's high schoolers to one high school would increase transportation costs, increase class sizes and hurt student achievement.
Chikwendu said the Blueprint, which is a state plan that aims to improve student outcomes and the quality of education, does not just increase starting teacher salaries, but it changes what makes a student eligible to graduate.
She said getting rid of extracurriculars like athletics, which are outlets for students, will increase the district's dropout rate.
"If we do not have graduates, we do not have good employees, we do not have homeowners, we do not have property taxes to spend," she said. "Everything is connected largely to how well we educate our students."
Chikwendu said removing extracurriculars would affect school culture and climate.
"That's also part of what the state evaluates," she said. "And if those things slide, so do then our ratings and so do then what the state provides to us."
Detmer said he resents having to ask those questions.
"I resent the fact that a one-size-fits-not-us solution has been passed down," he said about the Blueprint. "I would much rather be waiting for recommendations developed here for how to best serve our students."
Detmer said he would like to have the county look into asking for a special dispensation so the district can follow a plan that is tailored to it.
"We've just heard that the big, nuclear solutions, for many reasons, aren't tenable," he said. "We can't just close multiple schools."
Detmer said the county needs to follow a plan for education improvement that is slower and more purposeful.
"We don't have the property tax base," he said.
Council President Lenny Pfeffer said the council will be directing county staff to look at options to solve the deficit, including looking into getting a dispensation.

title: What it was like ... to be a teacher
author: HANNAH COMBS hcombs@chespub.com
content:
What it was like ... to be a teacher

 March 21, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: HANNAH COMBS hcombs@chespub.com | Section: Local News 
 
 526
 Words 

 Read News Document

 COVID-19 shook the entire educational system, changing how, when and where teachers taught. Five years ago, Tamara Forte was in her 15th year of teaching first grade. On Friday, March 13, teachers were told to pack up their classrooms as if for summer vacation, covering items with bulletin board paper. They thought it would be for only two weeks."The fear of the unknown was big," Forte said. "We were closing the school buildings but had no idea what the future would hold and how long it would be for."
Conditions were constantly changing, with teachers having little control or input. After closing for two weeks, teachers learned they would have to send learning packets home. Some parents printed the packets through email, while others picked them up at school. Staff members delivered packets to students' homes when necessary.
Forte admits having to ask colleagues for help recalling some details of what they went through five years ago.
"It was a blur, and I blocked many details out. It was a hard, worrisome time," she said. Her day care closed after she had paid weeks to hold her spot. "My day care had closed; my work had closed. It felt like the world was closing down."
At home, Forte watched videos on properly cleaning and disinfecting groceries, even cereal boxes, as she moved them between counters. She balanced keeping her family safe while maintaining her teaching responsibilities.
Teachers continued being flexible and adapting to unprecedented circumstances. Forte's sister traveled from New Jersey to help create a classroom in her basement. With a laptop and projector, teachers did their best to make virtual learning engaging.
They learned to conduct Zoom calls and waited patiently while students searched for misplaced pencils. Teachers virtually entered all their students' homes, observing family members engaged in various online activities that sometimes created distractions. Some students struggled without tech-savvy family members to assist them, while others, including Forte's own school-aged sons, had to learn to log in and out at specific times for whole group and small group instruction.
Teachers spent considerable time troubleshooting frozen screens and internet glitches. Some created paper cutouts of themselves and mailed them to students with inspiring messages. They organized a school parade, decorating their cars with "we miss you" messages and driving through neighborhoods to wave and honk at their students. Teachers created grade-level photo collages with encouraging messages.
When fall arrived, teachers returned to schools without students. They prepared pizza boxes full of materials for at-home use and distributed computers and hot spots to families in need. Before students could return, teachers learned to space desks 6 feet apart, marking the distance with tape.
Students gradually returned to school on rotating A/B schedules. Teachers simultaneously instructed in-person and at-home students. They observed children biting wet masks or dropping them on the floor before putting them back on. Physical expressions of encouragement like hugs and high-fives were no longer possible.
"Reflecting on teaching and life in the pandemic really makes you appreciate every smile, hug, high-five, and all the learning together," Forte said. "It makes you cherish the many things that we take for granted every day. I never want to go back to this time."

title: Schools struggle to bridge learning gaps, adapt to a new normal
author: ANDREA GRABENSTEIN agrabenstein@chespub.com
content:
Schools struggle to bridge learning gaps, adapt to a new normal

 March 21, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: ANDREA GRABENSTEIN agrabenstein@chespub.com | Section: Local News 
 
 726
 Words 

 Read News Document

 Five years after COVID-19 upended classrooms, Mid-Shore school districts are still working to close learning gaps, combat chronic absenteeism and adapt to lasting changes in education. While academic performance is improving across Maryland, with more schools earning top ratings, districts continue to wrestle with pandemic-era challenges — particularly in student engagement, virtual learning access and social-emotional development."We continue to see some gaps in students' learning," said Queen Anne's County Public Schools Superintendent Patricia Saelens, emphasizing the district's focus on tutoring, academic intervention and social-emotional strategies. Yet chronic absenteeism remains high, with some counties reporting rates above 25%, and virtual learning remains a logistical hurdle due to disparities in technology access.
Despite the challenges, local educators say students have proven resilient, with many now excelling in academics and careers. The post-pandemic education system may look different, but its impact on today's students will be felt for years to come.
LEARNING GAPSMaryland's most recent education report indicated steady improvements in school performance, with 91 schools achieving five-star ratings in the 2023-24 school year, up from 85 the previous year. About 41% of schools statewide received a four- or five-star rating, marking a gradual increase. However, despite these gains, schools statewide still fell short of meeting annual targets in every category.
To address learning gaps, Queen Anne's County Public Schools have expanded tutoring services where funding is available. Additional intervention programs in reading and math aim to support struggling students. Saelens stressed the need for continued focus on social-emotional learning, ensuring that students feel connected and ready to learn.
CHRONIC ABSENTEEISMOne of the most persistent challenges post-COVID is chronic absenteeism, according to state Department of Education data. While attendance rates have improved since the height of the pandemic, absenteeism remains above 25% across the Mid-Shore:
Queen Anne's County: 22.9%Kent County: 26%Caroline County: 28%Talbot County: 28.5%Dorchester County: 38.3%
Matt Evans, supervisor of Student Services in Queen Anne's County said their district was already experiencing a slight increase in chronic absenteeism prior to the pandemic; however, that rate significantly increased during COVID-19 school closures and peaked during the 2021-2022 school year. Since then, the chronic absenteeism rate is on a steady decline but not back to the pre-pandemic rates, Evans said.
Home instruction numbers also were increasing prior to the pandemic, with the sharpest increase and peak during the 2020-2021 school year. After 2020-2021, the home instruction numbers significantly decreased and ultimately plateaued, although they are not back to the pre-pandemic numbers, he noted.
Statewide, officials are working to reengage students but lingering effects of pandemic-related disruptions continue to impact attendance.
VIRTUAL LEARNINGVirtual learning, once an emergency measure, remains a complex issue. While some districts have successfully integrated online instruction for inclement weather closures, Queen Anne's County faces challenges in fully adopting virtual learning due to technology and connectivity limitations.
"In the state of Maryland, virtual learning days must adhere to all the guidelines of MSDE," Saelens said. "Not all QACPS students have a one-to-one device, and unfortunately, we still have pockets throughout the district where internet connectivity is challenging."
Additionally, some teachers struggle with reliable internet access, making a full-scale virtual learning model unfeasible.
ADOPTION AND INNOVATIONDespite the setbacks, educators see lasting benefits from the changes forced by the pandemic. Kent County Public Schools Superintendent Mary Boswell-McComas noted that five years is a significant portion of a student's educational journey.
"A fifth grader in 2020 is now well into their high school years. Elementary school students today don't remember the pandemic and wearing masks," she said.
While routines have returned to pre-COVID norms, teachers and students have become more proficient with technology. Virtual instruction, once foreign, is now a tool used strategically during weather-related closures.
Federal funding post-pandemic helped schools innovate, including the implementation of student support coaches in Kent County classrooms. These coaches allow teachers to work with students in smaller groups, providing targeted academic support and aiding in social-emotional development.
A NEW CHAPTERAs districts continue to navigate post-COVID realities, educators emphasize resilience and adaptation. Students who graduated during the pandemic are now succeeding at competitive universities and in the workforce, proving that the disruptions, while significant, did not define their futures.
"The pandemic was a challenging and troubling time for all of us: in schools, in our communities and around the world," Kent County's Boswell-McComas said. "As with so many challenges, we have come out of it stronger. We learned more about ourselves and have incorporated innovative techniques that are still in use today."

title: Easton Middle administrators: New cell phone restrictions are working
author: Konner Metz
content:
Easton Middle administrators: New cell phone restrictions are working

 March 21, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Konner Metz | Section: Local News 
 
 325
 Words 

 Read News Document

 EASTON — Easton Middle School administrators are saying the school's new cell phone use restrictions are effective.Easton Middle began piloting new cell phone pouch requirements last December, following suit of other districts in Maryland.
Students place their phones in locked pouches at the start of the day, carry those pouches with them and unlock the pouches when leaving. Talbot County acquired the pouches and unlocking devices from the company Yondr.
"We would love to continue to have it at Easton Middle," principal Kelly Murdoch told the Talbot County Board of Education Wednesday.
"There's a positive impact on safety and wellness. We've seen a positive change in student engagement within the classrooms and during instruction," Murdoch added. "Ultimately, we hope to see improvement with academic performance as well."
Assistant principals Ashley Quicke and Todd Stoker echoed that sentiment Wednesday.
"(Students) do use the screens as their avenue to speak to someone," Quicke said. "With them not being there, we are forcing this generation to have face-to-face conversations."
Stoker noted the school has a four-step disciplinary process for students who don't comply with the new rules. Beginning at the second offense, parents are called and must pick up the student's phone from the school office.
Board Vice President Amy Dodson asked if there's been a decrease in bullying since December.
"Absolutely. Definitely a decrease in any kind of cyberbullying," Murdoch said.
"Thank you for being our guinea pigs," President Emily Jackson said to the Easton Middle administrators. "We really appreciate it. We know this was a big lift for everybody involved."
Jackson asked if they think the policy should be expanded to other schools in the district. Murdoch said she could only speak for EMS but that it's "something to consider."
Stoker said it's important to look at research, which he said shows cell phone use negatively impacts the mental health of students starting at "upper elementary through high school."
"We've certainly seen a positive impact, at least on our end, with students of that age," Stoker said.

title: DCPS looks to staff reductions to balance budget
author: Maggie Trovato
content:
DCPS looks to staff reductions to balance budget

 March 22, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Maggie Trovato | Section: Local News 
 
 365
 Words 

 Read News Document

 CAMBRIDGE — Facing a $5.59 million deficit for fiscal year 2026, Dorchester County Public Schools is considering staff reductions."We're not just making decisions based on how we feel," DCPS Superintendent Jymil Thompson said during a Dorchester County Board of Education budget work session Thursday. "We're looking at every ounce of data. We're having budget meetings on a weekly basis. We're talking to our team consistently with the board. We're trying to make the best decision possible for Dorchester County Public Schools, and it's not easy."
While giving a budget update at the meeting, Thompson said the district will be looking into reducing its staff by 12 to 24 positions. He said those layoffs could save the district between $900,000 and $1.8 million.
"There are no definitive positions that we have identified as of yet," he said. "But we will be moving forward to doing that at our next meeting."
Thompson said the district has been in conversation with district principals, Dorchester Educators, Dorchester Educators Education Support Professionals and the Dorchester Administrators and Supervisors Association to discuss where those staff reductions could be made.
Thompson said the district wants to retain as many staff as possible and minimize the impact on teaching and learning.
"If we want to get from 23 to 15, we can't afford to lose teachers," he said about the district's state rating. "We have to make sure that we keep our class sizes small and keep teachers at all costs. And we're trying to do what's best for everyone."
Thompson said the district is reviewing attrition rate trends. He said he believes the number of teachers who leave the district for retirement and other reasons at the end of the school year will help.
"And we may not have to reduce as many staff," he said. "But we will have to reduce some staff."
Along with looking into staff reductions, Thompson said the district will be opening up negotiations with its staff representatives, which include Dorchester Educators, Dorchester Educators Education Support Professionals and the Dorchester Administrators and Supervisors Association.
"And the reason is because we cannot currently honor the step increases and the (cost of living adjustment)," he said.
Thompson said the district could potentially save $3.5 million through these negotiations.

title: Teacher for a Day brings community into the classroom
author: Lilly Howard lhoward@chespub.com
content:
Teacher for a Day brings community into the classroom

 March 25, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Lilly Howard lhoward@chespub.com | Section: State News 
 
 808
 Words 

 Read News Document

 Community members were behind teachers' desks this week thanks to the "Teacher for a Day" event organized by the Education Foundation of Cecil County Public Schools at schools across the county."Our goal here at Rising Sun was for our teacher of the day to see several different classrooms and different teaching styles," Rising Sun Elementary School Principal Sherri Isaac said.
Various business leaders and community members visited elementary schools, middle schools and high schools throughout the county from March 3 to 13.
Josh Hayhurst of Superdojo Martial Arts had participated in the former "Principal for a Day" at Rising Sun Elementary but found this experience to be more fruitful as he got to attend both Rising Sun and North East elementary schools — the largest elementary schools in the county — and sit in on classes, and facilitate a gym class for a more immersive day.
Isaac enjoyed this initiative more than any other.
"I feel like our teacher for the day got to experience more of what educators do than when he was following me around for a day," Isaac said.
Hayhurst spent time with each elementary grade in both schools to see the full scope. He pointed out that — contrary to the popular narrative of low test scores reflecting badly on CCPS — "these kids were ridiculously good readers and the teachers are rockstars."
Hayhurst said that he sees a lot of the same kids at his Superdojo, so he enjoyed being able to connect with them both in a space outside of martial arts. At Superdojo, he focuses on taking abstract ideas like how to create a positive environment and making them relevant in his teaching of martial arts, which he brought into facilitating the gym class with a fun twist on a jump rope activity.
Hayhurst also brought dry erase markers to replace the dried up ones for a teacher, and created "reading buddies" — pom poms with googly eyes — to make reading activities more fun for the kids. His efforts to bring in new elements made a positive impact on the students and the faculty.
"Go into the classroom and believe that you're a leader and you can make a difference with the kids just by being a positive role model," Hayhurst said.
He was impressed with the students' math abilities. He joined in on a multiplication table competition doing as many problems as quickly as possible, thinking he would win. But to his surprise, "I look up and there's a girl that had been finished for like 10 seconds just looking at me like, 'What took you so long,'" Hayhurst said.
Hayhurst valued the opportunity to connect with students and teachers and encouraged others to do the same.
"That connection is really important, and we've lost it in our community. We don't even know who our neighbors are, but we can find our neighbors in our local schools, and everybody, I think, should be a part of the schools," Hayhurst said.
Darius Humphries with Chesapeake Care Resources said he enjoyed his time at Elkton Middle School where he sat in on a math class where the teacher pushed the students to think critically and strategize. He plans to volunteer more with public schools in the future because of his experience with "Teacher for a Day."
School officials said that situations such as these were the goal of the entire experience.
"We really just wanted our community to see what goes on, the amazing things that go on in our school every day and see what the kids are learning," Isaac said.
Nick LaBrant with Utilitrain had the opportunity to teach a Cherry Hill Middle School social studies class about the history of power lines. With an informative presentation and power line props, LaBrant immersed himself as a teacher.
"It was actually an incredible class," LaBrant said. "I was able to give the students a little bit of an industry insight on something that really matters in the class."
The students had just learned about the history of railroads, so LaBrant's presentation fit right into the curriculum. LaBrant also educated students about soft skills necessary for the work force.
"I know that they're still in middle school, but I got to talk to them about teamwork and accountability and integrity from someone who's been out in the industry," LaBrant said.
LaBrant added that he was impressed with the students' engagement with his lesson.
"For every student to be paying attention, have questions, remaining engaged, I think it says a lot of good things about our public school system here in Cecil County," LaBrant said.
As a parent himself, this initiative reminded LaBrant to get more involved in Cecil County schools, while seeing how much patience and gratitude the teachers have toward their students to be successful.
"We would welcome an opportunity to have another 'Teacher for a Day' next year and hope that people continue to take advantage of it," Isaac said.

title: Plan to require school uniforms doesn't gain traction with Talbot Board of Ed
author: Konner Metz
content:
Plan to require school uniforms doesn't gain traction with Talbot Board of Ed

 March 26, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Konner Metz | Section: Local News 
 
 453
 Words 

 Read News Document

 EASTON — A proposal to institute school uniforms in Talbot County failed to advance at last week's Board of Education meeting.Board member Ann O'Connor, who first raised the uniform topic at a meeting last month, made a motion to institute school uniforms. However, that motion did not carry, as none of the other six board members seconded.
Before the failed motion, Talbot County Public Schools Superintendent Sharon Pepukayi shared results of a community survey with the board. Nearly 1,900 responses were recorded — 74% of those coming from parents, 15% from staff and 8% from students.
Overall, around 49% opposed school uniforms, with 45% in favor and the remaining voting no opinion. Responses varied based on the grade level:
Elementary school: 49% in favor, 41% opposed.Middle school: 49% in favor, 42% opposed.High school: 44% in favor, 48% opposed.
O'Connor said after one year of implementation, there could be a school shop with "hand-me-down" uniforms. She said purchasing uniforms wouldn't be "an exorbitant expense."
Vice President Amy Dodson disagreed.
"If you have a family that is only making minimum wage, it's a significant expense," Dodson said. "And you have a significant portion of our student population that is on free and reduced meals."
Board member Dyshekia Strawberry said she doesn't see the need to introduce uniforms since the survey didn't show "an overwhelming response either way." President Emily Jackson concurred.
"I don't see an overwhelming need to make a major change in policy and procedure," Jackson said. "Combined with the fact that, again, we are in a challenging budget year, and this would be an expensive undertaking should we go forward with it.
"Those two factors combined leave me not compelled to do anything in this regard."
O'Connor said she was surprised by the high response rate. She told The Star Democrat she'd like the district to gather information on the impacts of uniforms at other schools and potentially revisit the topic next school year.
In an interview Friday, Pepukayi said she was surprised by both the high survey response rate and "the closeness of the percentages that came out with elementary and middle" school questions.
The superintendent said her team discussed the cost factors around having parents pay for uniforms, though they did not get into what specifics costs may be if the district assumed uniform payments.
Pepukayi said potentially helping families pay for school uniforms would bring up questions of which families the district helps and how that's determined.
"That's another discussion because then where do you draw the line?" she said.
Pepukayi said she doesn't expect the topic of uniforms to come up again anytime soon.
"It didn't get the second (to) the motion, so it kind of died right there on the spot. But that's not to say it couldn't come up again," she said.

title: Amid budget woes, Dorchester cancels summer school, appeals to students to 'get the work done'
author: Maggie Trovato
content:

 Author/Byline: Maggie Trovato | Section: Local News 
 
 534

 CAMBRIDGE — Dorchester County Public Schools will not offer summer school this year, citing budget restraints. But county education officials say there is still time to improve grades for students who are at risk of having to repeat a grade."There is still time to pull it out," Dorchester County Board of Education President Sheri Hubbard said during a board meeting March 27. "... Buckle down and work as hard as you can to get the grades to where they need to be so that you don't have to worry about there not being summer school."
On March 20, the district announced it would not be able to offer elementary and middle school summer sessions nor the high school credit recovery summer program in 2025 due to the district's need to adjust its programming.
The move does not affect the Extended School Year program for students receiving special education services nor the Summer Career Enrichment Program being offered in Talbot County.
"As we work to balance our budget for the upcoming fiscal year, we are having to realign our resources and adjust various programs," the announcement addressed to families said.
Currently, the district is facing a multi-million dollar deficit for fiscal year 2026.
Since January, the district has reduced this deficit from $10.19 million to $5.59 million. During a Board of Education budget work session March 20, Superintendent Jymil Thompson said the district would next be looking into reducing its staff by 12 to 24 positions to save money. According the district, it currently has 859 total positions.
WHAT THIS MEANS FOR STUDENTSThe lack of summer school will mean if a student fails a course this school year, that student will not be able to make up the course this summer. The district wants parents to plan accordingly.
"If your student is failing a course, please reach out to the school to determine what can be done to help your child pass the course prior to the end of the school year so he/she does not risk being retained in the same grade level next year," the announcement said.
During the Board of Education meeting March 27, Thompson said his suggestion to students is to take advantage of the time remaining in the school year "to get the work done."
Hubbard said the board wishes the district could offer summer school this year.
"Of course we like to be able to offer summer school," she said. "But in today's budget climate, it is not something that is foreseeable at this moment, so I do apologize."
Hubbard, who used to be a teacher, said teachers are generally willing to work with students who ask them if there is something they can do to bring up their grade.
"Whenever there was a student who came to me with sincerity and said, 'Is there something I can do? Can I please make up some work?' or whatever, we always came to some sort of way that that student was able to bring up their grades if they really wanted to," she said. "It is possible."
Hubbard said the district doesn't want to have to hold students back.
"And we certainly don't want to keep anybody from graduating," she said. "So just please, all of you work together and get it done."

title: Education workers empty their offices after recent layoffs
author: JADE TRAN and JESS DANINHIRSCH Capital News Service
content:
Education workers empty their offices after recent layoffs

 April 1, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: JADE TRAN and JESS DANINHIRSCH Capital News Service | Section: State News 
 
 1041
 Words 

 Read News Document

 WASHINGTON — Suitcases and large cardboard boxes rolled across the pavement outside the Department of Education's offices last week as recently fired federal workers packed up their desks.Waiting outside, workers were greeted with claps, cheers and whistles as they emerged from the buildings, some raising their fists in defiance. Colleagues embraced, sharing quiet words or simply holding on. Signs with various messages floated above the crowd, most thanking the workers for their public service.
What began as a smaller "clap out" outside the Office of the State Superintendent of Education, home to Free Application for Federal Student Aid offices, on Wednesday grew into a larger demonstration by Friday. Fired employees gathered at the Department of Education's headquarters, joined by advocates rallying in solidarity.
About two weeks ago, workers in the department, which originally had 4,200 employees, began to hear rumblings of a large round of layoffs aimed at reducing the workforce by 50%. Some employees opted for early buyouts, while others took early retirements. The remaining 1,300 employees were subject to "reduction in force" notices, according to former employees Nikki Churchwell, of Calvert County, Maryland, from the Office of Performance and Improvement, and Kaitlyn Vitez, of Alexandria, Virginia, from the Office of Communications and Outreach.
The U.S. Office of Personnel Management lays out specific procedures for downsizing, which include ranking employees based on seniority and performance. However, Churchwell said the administration altered the way competitive areas were identified to bypass this process.
Veronica Greene, 56, a nearly retired worker, made her way down the path outside the state superintendent's office, her belongings packed into two cardboard boxes stacked on a dolly. A security guard and another man, also carrying boxes, helped guide the load.
A car pulled up to the corner of the building, its windows down. A man and a woman inside waved and clapped in support. With teary eyes, Greene said, "These are my colleagues."
"We party hard. We love each other. It's hard to see these people leave because I don't know if I'll ever see them again, " she said. "Some I might, but a lot I might not."
Describing her experience, Greene said that she planned to retire, but this departure was not on her own terms. In just 15 to 20 minutes, the place she had considered home for decades was reduced to two boxes, after dedicating her life to student aid and loan services since 1991.
Her days were spent answering phones and sorting through mail, but it was in her office in meetings, where she said she witnessed the dedication of her colleagues.
Kelisa Wing, of Virginia, a former employee with the Office of the Deputy Secretary at the Department of Education, was escorted to her workstation around 9 a.m. on Friday with just 30 minutes to pack up her belongings.
As she moved through the office, she noticed Homeland Security personnel monitoring the building. By 11 a.m., the walls of her workspace, once decorated with family photos, potted plants and an image of Martin Luther King Jr. from the night before his assassination, were bare.
Everything had been carefully placed into a sleek black suitcase with a box stacked on top.
"All I ever wanted to be was an English teacher and look what God did, because of education," she said. "Education saved my opportunities, so that's what they want to take away."
Though for Wing, the moment was bittersweet. The abrupt departure offered a sense of closure, giving her the chance to say a proper goodbye to colleagues she had worked alongside for years.
"This is an assault on public education, because people know that education is the great equalizer," she said. "It is the way that a student, a person like me, who came from nothing from Toledo, Ohio, from nothing, can end up working in a place like this."
Supporters gathered with former employees, holding signs of solidarity. One sign, adorned with Sesame Street's Cookie Monster, read: Thank you! Gracias! Merci! Salamat!
Tony Sarmiento, a retired worker from Silver Spring, Maryland, who has attended 21 demonstrations in support of federal employees since the new administration took office, stood beside Greene, snapping photos and helping her with her belongings.
He said firings like these often lead to deep emotional struggles, with laid-off workers battling depression and self-blame.
"So, even with the completely irrational, cruel way these closings are happening," he said, "there's a phenomenon where workers are so depressed, they aren't going to blame the right person."
Bill Bimber, a retired science and technology high school teacher with 34 years of experience in northern Virginia schools, spent many years without computers to teach his students computer repair. If it weren't for funding programs created by the Department of Education, he may never have received computers to teach his class.
Bimber expressed his concerns that if the department is experiencing massive layoffs, programs like this that provide equipment and materials to students may no longer get off the ground.
"I know how programs from this agency, this department, have affected schools over the years, and it's largely invisible, but it's huge," Bimber said. "It really is enormous what they do."
Dressed in a Department of Education graphic T-shirt, Jackie Murray approached her firing with grace — after 40 years in communications and outreach — with a positive outlook on her future. After being placed on administrative leave over two months ago, the popular Murray bounced around the outside of the building with a smile and laughter.
She responded to a question about her next steps, saying, "My mouth moves a lot, so it needs to get paid because it has to eat, you know."
For her, a support system of girlfriends, music, and scripture was key during moments like this that felt shared by many federal workers across the Washington region.
"Find you a support group that has accepted this, because there are still individuals, um, that I know who have not fully accepted this," she added, offering advice to those in her situation.
In the coming days, there will be debates about what form the department should take and how programs should be implemented, Vitez said.
"At the end of the day, we need to do what's best for schools … and for students and provide them the most resources and support to get the job done," she said. "And people need more support, not less."

title: Committee made for potential new Lockerman Middle School
author: AHMAD GARNETT agarnett@chespub.com
content:
Committee made for potential new Lockerman Middle School

 April 1, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: AHMAD GARNETT agarnett@chespub.com | Section: News 
 
 513
 Words 

 Read News Document

 EASTON — A committee called the Education Specifications Committee has come together to begin the discussion of renovating or replacing Lockerman Middle School."So this is the first step of the project process we go through for renovation," Caroline County Public Schools Superintendent Dr. Derek Simmons said. "This committee... is an opportunity for our community, this group of stakeholders and working with our outside consultant to talk about what they may feel is needed in a modern 2025, 2026 middle school."
In the summer of 2024, the Caroline County Board of Education approved Lockerman Middle School as the next large construction project for the county. Consultant David Lever with Educational Facilities Planning LLC was contracted with to begin the process.
According to Simmons, the committee will help give the consultant a picture of what a middle school facility should look like to educate kids in the modern era and moving forward.
The architect will use the Education Specification Committee's documents to help design the school, whether renovating the current structure or building a new school altogether.
County Administrator and Committee Member Katheleen Freeman says the committee will go through multiple different scenarios and specifications to make sure the middle school is correctly designed.
"We're going to look at the square footage that's needed for the facilities that would be needed in the school," Freeman said. "Also the traffic flow. Can can students walk to the school? If they have to drive, what's the traffic impact going to be? Is it going to be easy for parents to drop off and pick up, and the buses and all of that kind of thing?"
The committee consists of multiple school officials from schools in Caroline County and officials from the state, as well as community members.
"We have teachers from Lockerman, we have members of the Lockerman Association," Simmons said. "We have central office folks who are involved with curriculum as well as building and facilities. We have parents at our elementary schools, as well as administration from Lockerman. We have some state representation that's been invited because the state will be a major funder."
At the Nov. 26, 2024, Caroline County Commissioners meeting, Bill Mengel, director of operations at Caroline County Public Schools, said the state is projected to be receive $76 million in requested funding from the state.
Mengel said the $76 million is around 89% of the total $86 million estimated for years one and two of the project. The county would be responsible for the remaining 11% of the funding.
Simmons said the forming of the committee is a first step in what will be a long process to bring the middle school together.
"It is a marathon in terms of pulling this together," Simmons said. "As we work through the process, we want to really keep an eye on respecting the past and preparing for the future for the needs for Lockerman.
"We want to make sure that it's done right, something the community can be proud of. It is also a responsible use of the funding that will be used to build it. We are really looking forward to the process."

title: Talbot County wrestles with schools funding request, long-term Blueprint concerns
author: Konner Metz
content:
Talbot County wrestles with schools funding request, long-term Blueprint concerns

 April 2, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Konner Metz | Section: Local News 
 
 660
 Words 

 Read News Document

 EASTON — The Talbot County Council opted Tuesday not to include an additional $5.7 million in funding for Talbot County Public Schools in the county's draft fiscal year 2026 budget.TCPS requested the additional funds last month to help with teacher salary mandates from the state, new positions and health insurance hikes, among other factors.
The county's budget will already include around $55 million in required education funding as mandated by The Blueprint for Maryland's Future, the state's overarching education improvement framework.
Council member Keasha Haythe argued Tuesday to keep the $5.7 million out of the budget for the time being. Any additional funding for education included would potentially lead to a property tax increase for residents by way of an education supplement.
"Putting an additional property tax supplement on them this year specifically is a challenge," Haythe said. " ... I just believe we have to be very conservative and think about the vulnerable population."
Vice President Pete Lesher was the council's lone member in favor of including additional educational funding in the county's initial budget proposal. Lesher said it's "not prudent" to push off the education funding to next year.
"It would make next year a lot more painful," Lesher said. " … I'd rather do steady, incremental increases than take a year off and be hit with a much larger percentage increase a year down the road."
Lesher warned that holding off on fulfilling some of the district's requests could endanger recent county investments for new positions such as math coaches and social workers, since the district is under state pressure to meet $60,000 teacher salary minimums.
TCPS Superintendent Sharon Pepukayi said Tuesday the district won't be able to continue funding all its priorities if the county only provides the minimum required funding.
"We will have to prioritize and we will have to make some tough decisions," Pepukayi said.
Council members and county officials said Tuesday the option to fulfill some or all of the $5.7 million ask remains available in the coming weeks as the budget is amended. A budget proposal will officially be introduced April 15.
LONG-TERM UNCERTAINTY
While the county held off on promising additional education funding Tuesday, council members and school leaders found common ground during a joint meeting Monday, fielding concerns over the long-term sustainability of the state's Blueprint initiative.
Talbot County Public Schools Chief Financial Officer Sarah Jones touched on projections from the Department of Legislative Services released in February, which forecast significant increases for how much money counties are expected to provide school districts.
The report shows Talbot County is expected to contribute $90 million to schools in fiscal year 2034, up $35 million from what the council is planning to obligate for FY2026.
"That's a really sobering increase, but it's baked into the law," Jones said. "I don't know what the council's view is on how you're going to be able to meet this contribution."
Jones said the DLS calculations, in part, are derived from The Blueprint's goals to improve teacher compensation and provide needed student support.
Haythe said it's going to take time for the county to assess whether meeting those requirements is possible.
"We would have to come together as a council and really think through, get the details, work with (Finance Director Martha Sparks) to determine how we can get there, and if we can get there," she said.
Board President Emily Jackson said the state doesn't always offer financial solutions when it asks counties to fork over funding for The Blueprint. She said the state advising districts to ask counties to fill funding gaps isn't effective.
"That's not good government, that's not good planning, that's not good oversight," Jackson said. "But I think that the people in this room can do all those things, good planning, good government, good foresight, good working together."
As for the looming $90 million mark, officials agreed it's going to take joint strategic planning and a lot of time to flesh out the path forward.
"'Can we get there?' is important to determine first before we figure out how," Jackson said.

title: University of Delaware asks state for $43.5 million to build Biden Hall, renovate labs
author: Josh Shannon jshannon@chespub.com
content:
University of Delaware asks state for $43.5 million to build Biden Hall, renovate labs

 April 4, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Josh Shannon jshannon@chespub.com | Section: News 
 
 654
 Words 

 Read News Document

 The University of Delaware is asking the state legislature for $43.5 million for capital projects, including building Biden Hall and renovating aging laboratories."These requests all support our overarching goal of meeting the educational goals of Delawareans who are coming to UD with greater financial need," UD President Dennis Assanis said Thursday during his annual capital budget request to the state legislature's Joint Capital Improvement Committee.
The committee, commonly referred to as the bond bill committee, hears capital budget requests from various state agencies and later will finalize the budget and send it to the full legislature for a vote in late June.
UD is asking for $20 million to help build Biden Hall, an interdisciplinary social sciences building named after UD's most famous alumnus. The money is already in Gov. Matt Meyer's budget recommendation.
UD first publicly disclosed plans for Biden Hall in January, but details remain scarce. Assanis revealed in his presentation to the bond bill committee that the building has been in the planning stages since 2018.
"We're still very much in the fundraising and planning stage of this project, so we have not set a timeline for construction yet," Assanis said. "However, this demonstration of state support for the project will greatly help us in our efforts to continue to raise the necessary funds through philanthropy."
Officials have not disclosed where the building will be located or any details about it, other than it will be on the main Newark campus and will house the Joseph R. Biden, Jr. School of Public Policy & Administration and the Biden Institute.
The Biden Institute was created after Biden left the vice presidency in 2017, and it is currently located in the old Blue and Gold Club on Kent Way. Chaired by the former president's sister, Valerie Biden Owens, the Biden Institute hosts events, brings prominent speakers to campus and focuses on developing domestic public policy.
UD's highly ranked School of Public Policy & Administration, which was renamed for Biden in 2018, offers undergraduate and graduate programs in leadership, public administration, public policy, public health, disaster management and related fields. It is currently headquartered in Graham Hall on Academy Street.
Biden Hall "will harness the latest technology to cultivate academic growth, interdisciplinary research collaborations, dialogue, and civil discourse, all of which are crucial to a flourishing democracy in the 21st century," a UD spokesman said earlier this year.
UD is also asking the state for $20 million to address deferred maintenance of its laboratories and other buildings. Former Gov. John Carney recommended that amount in the budget he submitted days before leaving office, but Meyer reduced it to $14 million in his recommended budget.
Assanis asked the bond bill committee to provide the full $20 million.
"We're hoping that you will consider providing that level of funding to help us maintain academic spaces, especially the laboratories that provide our students with hands-on learning in biology, chemistry, physics, engineering and other disciplines," he said. "Maintaining modern facilities is a critical component in preserving our stature as a top-tier research institution, which is one of the most significant ways that UD serves the needs of our state."
UD has struggled in recent years to keep up with maintenance, accumulating a backlog of $1.2 billion in needed repairs and upgrades.
The university is trying to reduce that backlog by consolidating space across campus, closing underused buildings and considering situations where it makes sense to construct a new building rather than continue to repair an old one. Still, Assanis said, state funding needs to be part of the equation.
"It is extremely difficult to find philanthropists who want to support replacement of HVAC systems or torn seats in a lecture hall," he said. "State capital assistance is one element of our plan, and we're grateful for every dollar that you provide."
The remainder of UD's capital request is $3.5 million to renovate lab and classroom space in Georgetown and Lewes, which would boost the university's Associates in Arts Program in southern Delaware.

title: Maryland wrestles with blow to the state schools budget
author: SASHA ALLEN Capital News Service
content:
Maryland wrestles with blow to the state schools budget

 April 4, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: SASHA ALLEN Capital News Service | Section: Local News 
 
 733
 Words 

 Read News Document

 ANNAPOLIS — Maryland lawmakers are scrambling to figure out their education budget this spring after learning that $418 million they'd been expecting for public schools from the federal government may not come through.Senate President Bill Ferguson says the state had already spent approximately $300 million of the money and allocated the rest to school districts around the state when they learned that President Donald Trump's education department may not reimburse them as previously planned. The money was supposed to come from a special pandemic-era fund.
The funds are being spent by school districts to cover reading materials, after-school programming, and repairs for heating and air conditioning units, among other things.
Mid-Shore school districts were still unsure of the exact impacts to their budgets when asked for comment Thursday.
"At this time, we are waiting for details from MSDE (Maryland State Department of Education) regarding the final calculations and impact on funding for all Maryland school districts," Talbot County Public Schools said in a statement to the press. District officials said they expected to have more information by Monday, the final day of this year's state legislative session.
Senate Democrats had already proposed cuts to the state's education plan, known as the Blueprint for Maryland's Future. Now Republicans say it's even more important to make significant trims.
"We don't have an extra $300 million to spare, and it is foolish to double down on Blueprint spending when there are obvious accountability issues coupled with the concerns of our local school districts who are struggling to meet both the financial and the policy mandates," said Sen. Mary Beth Carozza (R-Somerset, Wicomico, Worcester).
Word of the $418 million gap came late last week in a letter from U.S. Secretary of Education Linda McMahon, informing states that the fund's liquidation period would be coming to an end that day. Extensions of the pandemic-era fund, she said in the letter, were "well past the period of performance" and were "not justified."
The letter specified that there may be exceptions on an individual basis, and Office of the Attorney General Spokesperson Jennifer Donelan said in a statement they are "reviewing the matter and weighing our options."
"Protecting the state's schools and Maryland students is a top priority," read the statement.
But on Monday, Carozza introduced an amendment to the Excellence in Maryland Public Schools Act, a bill aiming to reduce Blueprint funding, to pause implementation of the plan for the next two years.
"It's never been more clear that we need a pause in the Blueprint when it comes to affordability and implementation," Carozza said.
To balance the state's budget and bridge the structural deficit, the Excellence in Maryland Public Schools Act would make numerous cuts to the state's plan for hiking the investment in public education. While many Democrats still believe the Blueprint is necessary for the future of Maryland public schools, Republicans like Carozza are pushing for further cuts.
"There's no question that we've increased spending dramatically in education for the last 25 years, and our SAT scores are worse, our reading scores are worse, math is worse," said Sen. Justin Ready (R- Carroll, Frederick) on the Senate floor Tuesday. "While we're not suggesting you want to cut education from where you are now, we are saying we should slow down how fast we're going and not raise taxes on working Marylanders for a little while longer."
Ready and numerous other Senate Republicans fought against tax increases in the budget bill, and many advocated instead to cut education even more.
But cuts have already been proposed. Senate amendments to the Excellence in Maryland Public Schools Act include pausing for four years the requirement for "collaborative time," or the allocated period each day when teachers get for planning. The act would also maintain some reduction in funding for the Consortium on Coordinated Community Supports, a program providing mental health support in schools under the Blueprint.
Some Senate Democrats, however, are in staunch disagreement with Republicans regarding the bill. Sen. Jim Rosapepe (D-Prince George's, Anne Arundel) was the first to speak about the budget on the Senate floor Tuesday morning.
"We're not rolling over for the attacks on Maryland," Rosapepe said. "We're protecting health care, we're protecting education, we're protecting public safety, we're protecting transportation … We're making the tax system more fair."
Like Rosapepe, many senators mentioned the necessity of education funding. State Democrats pushed to protect funding for low-income students and English Language learners.
The Star Democrat Reporter Konner Metz contributed to this article.

title: Chapel District Elementary renovations nearing 30% completion mark
author: Konner Metz

Chapel District Elementary renovations nearing 30% completion mark

 CORDOVA — As students approach spring break and the final stretch of the school year, construction teams at Chapel District Elementary School are making progress.Kevin Shafer, director of operations for Talbot County Public Schools, told district and county officials this week that the first phase of work should be complete at the Cordova school this June.
About $11.28 million, or around 30% of the total cost, has been spent to date, Shafer said. Construction progress isn't quite at that mark, however.
"We'll be about 30% done at the end of the first phase in June," Shafer said during a meeting Monday. "And the reason for that is a lot of front loading."
The renovation is a multimillion-dollar effort that includes around $27 million in county funding as well as state funds from Maryland's Interagency Commission on School Construction. Construction is being led by the Whiting-Turner Contracting Company.
The project is set to fully renovate the existing building and add around 16,000 square feet. There will be additional learning space for the school, as well as a Critchlow Adkins Children's Centers site located in the building.
The school's media center is moving to the center of the building, and the playground is also under renovation.
Construction, which began in summer 2024, is expected to take a couple years. The school was built in 1952 and last renovated in 1994.
Shafer noted the construction project started about 34 days late due to unforeseen septic system issues and permitting delays.
He credited Bill Stagg, the project manager appointed by the Talbot County Council, for preventing what could've been a significant delay.
"He was instrumental in making sure that this project even got started on time," Shafer said. "If that would've hit about 40 days, it would've been pushed back a year."
School operations have continued in the existing building this year during the first phase of work. Phase two of renovations will begin this summer once school ends, Shafer said.
"That is why you will see a front loading of expenses, making sure the supplies and equipment are here in place ready to hit the ground running," he said.
"That is a make-or-break time for this project. We have to be ready by the time kids come back in August."

title: Freedom of speech under assault on campuses
author: ROBERT C. KOEHLER
content:
Freedom of speech under assault on campuses

 April 5, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: ROBERT C. KOEHLER | Section: Columns 
 
 1043
 Words 

 Read News Document

 Freedom of speech is kind of like eggs nowadays — too expensive. For Columbia University, the cost imposed on it by the Trump administration was suddenly $400 million in rescinded federal funding, at least if the speech was pro-Palestinian and critical of Israel.What choice did the school have, except, as Jennifer Scarlott writes, "to appease the Trump administration by expelling, suspending and revoking the degrees of a growing number of students accused of peaceful protest and exercising their constitutional rights to free speech and assembly ...?"
"The shameless capitulation of Columbia to government pressure," she goes on, "is reflective of the corporate, neoliberal selling-out of academia. Academia, exemplified by Columbia University, has surrendered its proclaimed mission of intellectual independence and endeavor and the academic pursuit of knowledge and social advancement."
Can you believe it? An academic clampdown on peace protests. Reading about this, I couldn't help but feel my own college days come back hard and strong, and I started reading the current news in a larger context.
Education isn't just a matter of absorbing a bunch of dead facts and certainties. As we gain — as we claim — our education, we bring our expanding awareness into the world we're entering. An essential part of the world during my own college years, back in the late '60s, was of course the Vietnam War. This war wasn't simply an abstraction; it was anxious to claim us as obedient participants.
Many of us chose not to be obedient. We saw the hell and pointless horror of the war and decided that the only way we could participate in it was by standing against it, by ending it ... and, ultimately, by working to be create a world where war was no longer the unquestioned norm: a world, you might say, not defined by the lurking, soulless enemy (who must be killed), but by our connection to everyone and everything.
Yeah, this work is still in progress. War remains humanity's cancer — with no funding rescinded for its endless waging, at least not by the U.S. government. But five-plus decades ago, free speech did eventually bring the Vietnam War to an end and, indeed, precipitated an era of "Vietnam syndrome," where the public basically opposed war in general. No small problem for the nation's warmongers.
It took almost two decades, but the U.S. eventually found itself an enemy equal in evil to the commies: the terrorists. Specifically, Muslim terrorists.
In 1991, President George H.W. Bush launched Operation Desert Storm, aka, Gulf War I, a quick, brutal assault on Iraq after its invasion of Kuwait. The Bush administration employed some highly effective public relations to push the war, including the false assertion that the evil Iraqis had ripped Kuwaiti babies from their hospital incubators and left them to die on the floor. The war lasted a little over a month, ending in the bombing and slaughter of retreating Iraqi troops, as well as civilians, along what became known as the Highway of Death.
Afterward, Bush extolled the real victory his assault on Iraq had achieved, declaring: "It's a proud day for America. And, by God, we've kicked the Vietnam syndrome once and for all."
The public was OK with war again. God bless America.
And it's been at war, in various ways, ever since. This is also part of the context in which I ponder today's news about the Gaza genocide protests. Federal control over public relations is crucial, and if the protest movement is allowed to continue — and spread — sheerly because of the mass slaughter of Palestinian civilians, the funding of which is our declared national policy, this could be ... uh, problematic.
In the '60s, college campuses were at the hub of the nation's antiwar protests, with faculty members seriously involved as well, and the various college administrations across the country mostly remained aligned with and committed to the principle of free speech. That meant the military-industrial complex had a serious domestic enemy: those loud-mouth college critics and their ability to punch holes in the official government PR about its military initiatives.
So what's it going to do? Go total fascist and simply shut those students up by banning free speech? As appellate attorney Joseph Pace writes:
"There's a malign genius to the administration's approach. Trump and his enablers know they can't directly muzzle students or faculty without facing First Amendment lawsuits. To be clear, that doesn't mean the administration won't try. ICE has already begun arresting foreign student activists, and DOJ has signaled plans to charge protestors under federal counterterrorism laws. But the administration surely understands that most of those actions will be thwarted in the courts."
So start squeezing the college cash flow. That way, as Pace notes, it can force private college administrations to do the dirty work — banning protests, expelling protesters — legally. Pace quotes Trump strategist and former Heritage Foundation board member Christopher Rufo, who explained in a New York Times interview that the plan was to put the schools in a state of "existential terror" unless they went after the protesters.
I would call this flipping the reality, a crucial aspect of war-related public relations. Here, for instance, is a small sliver of a United Nations report from Tom Fletcher, Under-Secretary-General for Humanitarian Affairs and Emergency Relief Coordinator, noting that Israel's latest ceasefire violation on March 17 resulted in hundreds of deaths. Furthermore:
"Since 2 March, Israeli authorities have halted the entry of all lifesaving supplies, including food, medicine, fuel and cooking gas, for 2.1 million people. Repeated requests to collect aid sitting at the Karem Shalom border crossing have also been systematically rejected, no further hostages have been released and Israel has cut power to southern Gaza's desalination plant, limiting access to clean water for 600,000 people."
But criticizing this is what the smugly powerful call antisemitic. The irony here, as Pace noted, is in the nature of the Trump administration itself, which he described as a "den of antisemites." This is no doubt most flagrantly represented by Elon Musk, who infamously gave two Nazi salutes at a recent rally and, among much else, spoke at a right-wing convention in Germany where he lamented that "Germany's real problem was 'too much focus on past guilt.'"
We're on a dark and dangerous road to nowhere. The protests are keeping human sanity alive.

title: Four months in, Easton Middle staff, parents weigh in on cell phone pouches
author: Konner Metz
content:
Four months in, Easton Middle staff, parents weigh in on cell phone pouches

 April 5, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Konner Metz | Section: Local News 
 
 686
 Words 

 Read News Document

 EASTON — Since December, Easton Middle School students have been placing their cell phones in locked pouches, a policy that's largely succeeding according to staff, though it hasn't quelled all parents' concerns.School principal Kelly Murdoch says students are no longer multi-tasking during teacher instruction by trying to talk to their friends on social media or texting apps. Overall, it has improved student engagement and restorative conflict management, she says.
"We've been intentional in trying to build those skills of having face-to-face interactions, because it's a skill that has been missing," Murdoch said.
Talbot County followed suit of Caroline and Dorchester school districts, both of which began cell phone pouch pilot programs closer to the beginning of the school year. The districts acquired the pouches from the company Yondr.
Students place their phones in locked pouches at the start of the day, carry those pouches with them and unlock the pouches on a Yondr magnetic device when leaving.
"Initially, I was a little hesitant because of the safety issue that if something happened at school, I wanted to be able to get a hold of my child," said Carla Beavers, an EMS parent.
But Beavers said she was "alleviated" upon hearing from the district that emergency services professionals recommend students not use their phones during most emergencies. EMS also has "portable" unlocking devices, which Murdoch says allow students to unlock their phones if administrators deem it necessary during an emergency.
PARENTS CHIME IN
Beavers' son, a seventh grader, has left his phone at home since the new pouches were instituted. She says he's more focused on school instruction, and she hopes the pouch policy stays in place.
Her son using the school phone to call her was "seamless."
"He went to the office, he was allowed to make a phone call," Beavers said. "I feel like the administrative team has it down."
Nicole Crosby, parent of an EMS eighth grader, has her son leave his phone at home too. He immediately brought his grades up, she said. But the decision to leave the phone at home stemmed from the pouches being "ineffective," Crosby says.
"Having the knowledge that I do on what goes on in the eighth grade (and) what goes on in the middle school," Crosby said, "I do not anticipate (the pouches) being very successful for the main reason of — we all had bets on how long it was going to take for the kids to break them and unlock them."
Murdoch says Yondr has noted there are magnets out there that can be used to unlock their pouches, but the company warns it comes with the risk of damaging or breaking the phone. Murdoch said she hasn't seen students bring their own magnets yet.
Crosby contends the policy would have better results with community investment. She says teachers are doing everything they can, but the ultimate responsibility falls on parents.
"They can't parent our children for us all the time," Crosby said. "And if they don't have that support from us, then everything's going to be ineffective, unfortunately."
MORE POUCHES TO COME?
TCPS is leaving the door open to expanding the policy to other schools in the district, though not until next school year at the earliest. Superintendent Sharon Pepukayi said opinions from members of her student advisory board are "mixed."
"I have some students that feel like in high school, let's relinquish some of that independence and they should be able to have their phones," Pepukayi said.
Gabriella Streaker, a senior at Easton High and Board of Education student representative, believes the pouches could be useful at the high school level, particularly for ninth and tenth graders — though it wouldn't be a popular rule.
"Students can't really go anywhere without them. The phone is always with them," she said. "And I often think the phone could be causing more issues than not."
While others schools may or may not see the phone policy in coming years, the pouches have brought consistency and simplicity to Easton Middle's phone policy.
Teachers, as well as administrators, are spending less time out of their days policing cell phones.
"It frees them up to do what they're supposed to do, which is be instructional leaders," Murdoch said.
