title: Schools face shortage of social workers
author: ELA JALIL Capital News Service
content:
Schools face shortage of social workers

 April 7, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: ELA JALIL Capital News Service | Section: State News 
 
 863
 Words 

 Read News Document

 WASHINGTON — Jaden Smith, a second-year master's student in social work at Howard University, is doing something not enough people do. He's working in a public high school, offering what he calls "big brother love" to his students.Smith, who started work at Bard High School Early College DC in Southeast Washington last fall while completing his degree, said he's now doing the same "noble" work that his mother did: serving as a school social worker.
And thanks to a Howard program that aims to place social work students in schools in hopes that they'll work there full-time when they graduate, others are doing similar work. In the program's first two years, 22 second-year master's students have been placed in schools in the nation's capital to increase and diversify the school social work labor force, especially where they are needed the most.
It's called Project PRESS, which stands for Preparing Responsive and Effective School Social Workers. And the pilot program addresses a pressing need: a shortage of social workers in schools both in D.C. and nationwide.
When Project PRESS started in 2023, there were 95 school social worker vacancies in D.C. public schools, said Sandra Jeter, an assistant professor of social work at Howard, at a panel about the project in December. And according to the School Social Work Association of America, no state in the union meets the recommended benchmark of one social worker for every 250 students.
Jeter, who launched Project PRESS with a five-year, $2.6 million federal grant, said social work programs at other universities could establish similar efforts to address the nationwide shortage of school social workers.
"I think PRESS can definitely be a model or just be an organization that offers this training to different universities that are developing social workers, whether they have a school social work focus or not," Jeter said. "I think any university can adopt this model or work with me on expanding the model."
Intensive training
Project PRESS aims to motivate social work students to do something many of their predecessors have decided not to do: work in schools.
"The Project PRESS program is a really exciting thing to see to get students excited about the school social work profession," said Allie Perez, a representative of the School Social Work Association of D.C.
This yearlong program puts Howard social work students through two weeks of intensive training before they are placed at one of 11 participating schools. Students in the program receive a $10,000 stipend to ease some of the financial stresses of placement in a city school.
Social workers have different responsibilities than counselors and school psychologists. School social workers tend to work with specific students for long periods of time and create treatment or action plans.
"We do the mental health support, but we also take a more systemic view and we really focus on connecting people to resources and helping them remove barriers to those resources," Perez said.
School counselors are more likely to focus on academic and career development compared to school social workers that are helping students with socio-emotional challenges.
A school psychologist has the ability to diagnose students and perform psychosocial assessments, Jeter said.
The services that a school social worker provides, especially to underserved students, have a trickle-down effect on how a student performs, said Gloria Cain, an assistant professor at Howard's School of Social Work and a faculty member with Project PRESS.
"Social work is a discipline that really focuses on individuals within the context of their environment," Cain said.
The need
Project PRESS focuses on sending students to D.C.'s Wards 7 and 8, historically Black and low-income areas located south of the Anacostia River.
Jeter said she believes these areas not only lack investment from the city but lack support rooted in the Black perspective that focuses on issues and trauma people often experience in majority Black and low-income communities.
The program focuses on culturally responsive training, which prepares program participants to engage with different student populations. It also teaches trauma-informed training, which promotes awareness of the systemic and individual trauma students carry with them so the student is not retraumatized.
Racist incidents, poverty, food insecurity and homelessness are just some of the traumas students can carry with them that impact their performance in school. A main goal of the program is to interrupt these factors and use education as a gateway to success, Cain said.
Kyaus Washington, a 2024 graduate of Howard's master's of social work program, said it's important for social workers to know when students have experienced such traumas.
"Traumatic events happen to people and whenever you kind of understand that and try to understand from the person's perspective, then you're able to kind of tailor your modality to be effective based on the traumatic experience," Washington said.
Washington works as a school-based expansion clinician at Lorraine H. Whitlock Elementary School in Ward 7. He noted negative experiences with therapists and the nation's long history of medical racism can lead to a sense of relief when a young Black student sees a Black social worker.
"People automatically have this shared sense of community with each other," Washington said. "If they see, you know, me, a Black man walking into the school, my Black male students could automatically connect with me from that one shared identity."

title: Speakers ask to keep St. Mary's elementary music and arts intact
author: Michael Reid mreid@somdnews.com
content:
Speakers ask to keep St. Mary's elementary music and arts intact

 April 8, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Michael Reid mreid@somdnews.com | Section: State News 
 
 705
 Words 

 Read News Document

 It was somewhat ironic that during Music and Art in our Schools Month that the heated and at times emotional topic of discussion during the March 26 St. Mary's school board meeting included discussion on scaling back such programs.On March 7, special area teachers were told about a three-year plan to transition from the current 10-day rotation cycle (A-Week, B-Week) to a four-day cohort model for elementary music and art.
The presentation noted that the inclusion of band, chorus and orchestra in the schedule offers third-, fourth- and fifth-graders a "unique opportunity to be exposed to options provided in music education while minimizing disruptions to their academic learning." Currently, students participating in these ensembles are required to be pulled from core instruction two to four times per week.
The proposed change aims to "enhance the quality of instruction, which is frequently interrupted by students moving in and out of the classroom for band, orchestra and chorus practices," according to the proposal.
The new model would allow students to engage in just one ensemble during their designated special area music time, replacing general music classes with participation in band, orchestra or chorus.
"Even if the budget was fully funded we would want to be talking about how we're delivering this in schools because we have inequity," Superintendent Scott Smith said. "We need to have a different model than just kind of a random pullout for things. We need more structure."
Thirty minutes before the meeting started, the room was about 75% full and 36 speakers — ranging from educators, retired teachers, parents and students — voiced their concerns during the nearly 3½ hour meeting.
"A significant concern of this proposed schedule is the lack of access it would cause for some of our our most vulnerable learners," Mechanicsville Elementary School media specialist Michelle Smith said.
"So what does a cohort student look like coming into the secondary realm?" asked Megan Czechanski-Giannuzzi, who has been the band director at Leonardtown Middle School for the past 18 years. "They're unprepared, they can't handle middle school, they can't understand the content that we instruct and they're struggling with transition and they just have meltdowns. I suggest we not become Montgomery County, firing one out of every three secondary art and music educators. We don't need to be like Calvert County. We don't need to be like Charles County. We need to be St. Mary's County and do our best every day."
One Town Creek Elementary School student, who plays the saxophone, said that with the new schedule, "I would struggle to be focused on the amount of content [teachers] want me to learn in one sitting," and added that she hoped the board would "listen to the teachers and sit with them to find a solution."
"My plea to the board is that we consider ways of providing our current music education offerings and opportunities with the same frequency because it allows students to expand their brains in fun and engaging ways," paraeducator Deborah Hines of Evergreen Elementary said. "Music education not only creates a well-rounded curriculum, but also encourages students to participate and attend school regularly."
George Winslow, who taught in the county for 44 years, said, "How can you possibly not keep it going? I have no idea, and I'm glad I'm not in your seats right now because the arts are important."
The presentation was first delivered to specials teachers last month and Smith said it was being presented publicly because, "We figured it was only fair to present the presentation that was made and where we are in the process as we move forward."
The presenting panel said they have been meeting weekly and collecting feedback about the proposed change. The plan calls for all schools to adopt the model over the next three school years.
Green Holly Elementary has been using the cohort model the last 10 years and Park Hall is piloting the cohort model this year.
Staff noted that data from Park Hall stated, "The number of pullouts and transitions dropped in 25 band classes per week, 13 strings classes per week, and two chorus classes per week to zero pullouts," and added, "reducing the number of transitions for students has helped reduce referrals, suspensions and ISI, helping to keep students in the learning environment."

title: Caroline County Board of Ed declares last day of school, discuss virtual instruction
author: AHMAD GARNETT agarnett@chespub.com
content:
Caroline County Board of Ed declares last day of school, discuss virtual instruction

 April 8, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: AHMAD GARNETT agarnett@chespub.com | Section: News 
 
 719
 Words 

 Read News Document

 EASTON — The Caroline County Board of Education declared Tuesday, June 17, as the last day of the extended school year after inclement weather closures exceeded the four days allotted.The last day will be a half day for students and a full day for teachers.
Next year, county schools will have three allotted inclement weather days. At the April 1 Board of Education meeting, district officials explored options for implementing virtual instruction should weather cause unexpected closures.
Because of the challenges presented by district officials, the board concluded it thinks the district will not be able to conduct virtual instruction on inclement weather days.
"The structure we tried to take with the presentation was a condensed version of some the requirements that the school system would have to meet if the county were to entertain virtual weather days," Caroline County Public Schools Superintendent Derek Simmons said. "We walked through some real tough spots for us to get to those points."
Internet Connection and Google Meets
There are multiple factors Caroline County board of education most consider to conduct virtual inclement weather days. Including ensuring every student has a hotspot or wifi to participate in virtual learning.
Robert Wielgosz, supervisor of technology, led the discussion on cellular service, offering points on the Kajeet program.
Kajeet was a hotspot used during the pandemic for students to connect to the internet in areas where wifi access was limited and not available.
According to Wielgosz, when given the opportunity to use Kajeet, some students would use the hotspot for personal uses like video games and movies. This overloaded the hotspots and caused delays.
The estimate cost for Caroline County to provide the 700 needed Kajeet devices over five years would be about $736,000 for students and $35,000 for teachers.
Wielgosz also mentioned the need for Google Meet Breakout Rooms, which teachers use to conduct learning activities with groups in virtual classrooms. While this feature was available at no cost, it is no longer available in Caroline County's free Google plan.
"To get the feature back, it's going to cost Caroline County somewhere between $30,000 to $50,000 a year to get the premium Google aspect," Wielgosz said.
Multilingual Learners, Special Education and Homelessness
State law mandates districts "ensure that all staff and students, including students with disabilities, homeless students, and English language learners, have the necessary devices at home for virtual education days, including access to Wifi."
Providing equitable access to these services can be challenging during virtual instruction, district officials said.
Caroline County has 576 multilingual learners, 569 individualized education program students and 116 students who experience homelessness. For these students, hands-on teacher engagement and preparation is required for proper learning.
"It's very hard to keep students engaged, especially for four hours of synchronous instruction," Erica McDonald, supervisor of special education, said. "Without that in-person tangible motivating things that can keep them engaged during instruction, it can lead to increased frustration."
Providing necessary technologies and translation services are also complicated by virtual instruction, the officials said.
Teacher, staff negotiations
Some district employees work on inclement weather days, and some staff members do not work and still get paid, district officials said.
Requirements of the state say, "during virtual inclement weather days the local school system shall offer public school employees who are not assigned to work during the virtual education day an opportunity to make up the lost work through other duties before the beginning of the next school year."
The district would be responsible for determining how this work would be made up.
Virtual learning days require additional planning from teachers, which requires a negotiation with the teachers' union for proper pay.
"Our teachers work really hard. We all know are teachers work outside of hours. We have all come to accept that it comes with the job," Dr. Robert Willoughby, director of administrative services said. "However, the law does say that we may negotiate with our teachers' union. They have a right to come to negotiate if there is extra work here we would like extra compensation for that."
After going through the presentation, Simmons concluded it would be to hard for the county to pull off virtual inclement weather days.
"I don't see how as a county, with the resources we have right now, that this puts us in a great position to be able to hit all the marks to be able to pull this off effectively to meet all requirements," Simmons said.

title: Rescinded federal reimbursements cause $1.4 million impact on TCPS health center
author: Konner Metz
content:
Rescinded federal reimbursements cause $1.4 million impact on TCPS health center

 April 10, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Konner Metz | Section: Local News 
 
 525
 Words 

 Read News Document

 EASTON — Construction work on a health center for Talbot County Public Schools staff members has been delayed due to rescinded reimbursements from the U.S. Department of Education.School board and district leaders have touted the Marathon Health center — located on Idlewild Avenue and expected to open later this year — as a significant benefit for staff and their families. But now the project is facing an uncertain future following a notice from the U.S. Department of Education.
In a March 28 letter, Secretary of Education Linda McMahon announced effective the same day that the department would not be honoring extension requests for projects that were granted pandemic-era funds, such as the American Rescue Plan's Elementary and Secondary School Emergency Relief, or ESSER, program.
The move left the state with millions of dollars in funding at risk after it was previously granted an extension by the Biden administration.
State Superintendent Carey Wright said in a press release that the rescinded reimbursements would put more than $400 million of Maryland schools' pandemic-era funding in jeopardy.
About $305 million had already been spent and was awaiting reimbursement from the federal government, state officials said in March. About $112 million had not yet been paid out by the state, requiring school districts to halt ongoing work.
At a Board of Education meeting Wednesday, TCPS Chief Financial Officer Sarah Jones said the district isn't finding itself in a huge hole with regards to the reimbursement window unexpectedly closing.
But as far as the staff health center goes, the district is "sort of dead in the water," she said.
TCPS has paid $127,000 to Marathon for its work to date, Jones said. Remaining costs total to around $1.4 million.
"Those are costs that have not yet been spent, but we don't have authority to spend them," Jones said.
Jones told board members the district contacted Marathon, and the company quit work on the project.
The board agreed to revisit the question of funding the health center at a future meeting. Jones said there are multiple funding options at the district's disposal, including tapping into fund balance.
"We should really figure out how to make this work, and we should fund this," Board President Emily Jackson said.
Both Caroline County Public Schools and Dorchester County Public Schools have been fully reimbursed for all of their ESSER-related spending, according to school officials.
"We expended our funding within the timeline that was originally stated," CCPS Superintendent Derek Simmons said. "We considered (extending), but we did not end up needing it."
Simmons and Dorchester County assistant superintendent Jodi Colman each said the March 28 letter did raise concerns for the status of federal funding in general.
In the letter, McMahon wrote the department "will consider an extension to your liquidation period on an individual project-specific basis."
Wednesday, TCPS Superintendent Sharon Pepukayi noted the state has submitted an extension request to the U.S. Department of Education.
Jones said she imagines there will have to be "some allowances for costs that have actually been incurred" made by the federal government.
"There are literally schools that are in the middle of some sort of construction, capital improvement, and you can't leave a gym half built," Jones said. "You can't leave an HVAC system half-installed."

title: Maryland will slow – not stop – its investment in schools
author: SASHA ALLEN Capital News Service
content:
Maryland will slow – not stop – its investment in schools

 April 10, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: SASHA ALLEN Capital News Service | Section: News 
 
 377
 Words 

 Read News Document

 ANNAPOLIS — Maryland lawmakers passed a bill this week revising the state's expensive education reform plan, making marginal cuts instead of the more dramatic rollbacks proposed earlier this year.The bill, initially introduced by Gov. Wes Moore in January, reforms the Blueprint for Maryland's Future. Freezes to annual funding increases supporting students in poverty, special education students and English language learners were among the most controversial of Moore's proposals.
But as the bill made its way through the General Assembly, members of the House and Senate pushed to fully implement and fund programs they deemed most necessary under the Blueprint.
And when it passed Monday, it had been watered down to include only a few program changes and less sweeping budgetary cuts.
"At a time when the federal government is trying to eliminate the Department of Education and gut funding for schools from Mount Maryland to the Eastern Shore," Moore said Tuesday, "we've delivered the largest single investment in K-12 education in the history of our state."
Federal cuts left the legislature searching for ways to cut funding — especially after news from the federal government that up to $418 million in state education spending would not be reimbursed as previously expected.
But lawmakers decided that funding increases under the Blueprint for special education students, English language learners and schools experiencing high rates of poverty were too crucial to pause.
The most major cuts targeted the Blueprint's collaborative time initiative, requiring that teachers spend a portion of their workday planning. For the next three years, schools will not be required by the state to meet the priorly established teacher planning thresholds. Funding increases will also be paused for fiscal years 2027 and 2028.
"I think the bill that passed is fine, I mean, I think it makes some relatively modest changes," said Sen. Jim Rosapepe, a Democrat representing Prince George's and Anne Arundel Counties. "I don't think it's a big deal. I think it's a little deal."
But the bill received "no" votes from Republican lawmakers. While much of the discourse on the bill focused on the decision to raise taxes rather than pausing more Blueprint initiatives, Sen. Jack Bailey, a Republican representing Calvert and St. Mary's Counties, said he voted against the bill because of the financial burden that it might place on counties.

title: Buffenmyer, Marshall named Caroline Teacher, Support Staff of the Year
author: AHMAD GARNETT agarnett@chespub.com
content:
Buffenmyer, Marshall named Caroline Teacher, Support Staff of the Year

 April 11, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: AHMAD GARNETT agarnett@chespub.com | Section: News 
 
 484

 RIDGLEY — On Thursday at Cow Barn Events in Ridgely, Caroline County Public Schools held its yearly award ceremony to honor the Teacher and Support Staff of the Year.Andrew Buffenmyer was honored as Teacher of the Year and Nick Marshall was honored as Support Staff of the Year.
"It's incredible, it's one of the best nights of the year," Caroline County Public Schools Superintendent Derek Simmons said. "We can't do the work without great people and great employees, and I'm glad we have a way to recognize them, not just our teachers, but especially our support staff."
Buffenmyer, Teacher of the Year
Buffenmyer is a social studies teacher at North Caroline High School. He has been a teacher in Caroline County since 2009.
"It's an absolutely amazing feeling," Buffenmyer said of winning. "It's an amazing county and the greatest group of students in the entire world. I'm just absolutely thrilled and so happy for everything that's happened this year and everything that's going to be happening going forward."
While Buffenmyer is excited about the award, his main focus is his students, and he hopes to continues to see them walk across the stage.
"(The award) is vindication for the hours, the tears, the long nights, the everything that we've put in behind the scenes," Buffenmyer said. "But, it doesn't change anything, like, students are still number one. They always will be number one. The best thing is seeing those kids walk across that stage, seeing them in the community, seeing them be successful in their life, like that's the real reward."
Buffenmyer will go on to represent Caroline County in the state's Teacher of the Year contest, where Simmons thinks he will be an excellent representative of the district.
"It's going to happen, We have incredible teachers," Simmons said of winning the state Teacher of the Year. "We are one of 24 school districts. They're awesome ones everywhere else as well. At some point Caroline's time will be there."
Marshall, Support Staff of the Year
Marshall is the head custodian at Greensboro Elementary School. He has only been with Caroline County Public Schools for three years.
"I was surprised, a little shocked. I wasn't expecting it being a fairly new employee of the county," Marshall said about winning the award.
"I couldn't ask for a better group of people to work with. They make it enjoyable to come to work. I've came from other job, jobs that just wear you down, and it's a good experience to be here. The kids, seeing them every day and how they enjoy it, it's just a pleasure."
While Marshall appreciates the award, he said regardless of winning, he plans to put his all in for the students at Greensboro Elementary.
"I appreciate it," Marshall said. "I've told my supervisors that no matter what, this doesn't change who I am. We don't do this for awards. It's it's for the school. It's our job. It's what we're supposed to be doing."

title: Cell phone pouches coming to St. Michaels Middle next year
author: Konner Metz
content:
Cell phone pouches coming to St. Michaels Middle next year

 April 11, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Konner Metz | Section: Local News 
 
 472
 Words 

 Read News Document

 EASTON — The Talbot County Board of Education unanimously voted Wednesday to institute cell phone pouches at St. Michaels Middle School for the 2025-2026 school year, though it chose to hold off on bringing the pouch restrictions into high schools.Since December, the district has piloted a cell phone restriction program at Easton Middle School. Students place their phones in locked pouches at the start of the day, carry those pouches with them and unlock the pouches with a magnetic device when leaving.
Administrators have sung the praises of the new phone rules, citing an improvement in student engagement and a decrease in bullying.
"I can't imagine discontinuing it," Board Vice President Amy Dodson said Wednesday.
Superintendent Sharon Pepukayi estimated it will cost the district around $9,000 to purchase pouches for St. Michaels Middle and replacements for some worn pouches at Easton Middle.
HIGH SCHOOL DEBATE
Board members voiced differing opinions on whether to introduce pouches at the high school level.
President Emily Jackson said she wants to see more data on the effectiveness of the pouches, suggesting the district monitor this year's sixth graders through the next two years for behavioral and academic trends.
Board member Ann O'Connor argued pouches should be instituted in the high schools.
"We all know the effects of the cell phone and how it adversely affects our students, so why wouldn't we?" O'Connor said.
"This is a trial program," Jackson said. "I just want to see more before I feel comfortable saying yes definitely."
Board member Karla Wieland-Cherry pushed back on putting the pouches in the high school next year, stating schools need to work on managing students' behaviors.
"By the time this sixth grade class reaches the high school, it will already be an expected behavior," Wieland-Cherry said.
Chief Financial Officer Sarah Jones said purchasing pouches for high school students could cost around $38,000.
O'Connor said she doesn't think the money to bring the program to the high schools is an issue. She emphasized the impacts that phone use and constant notifications have on the younger generation.
"Isn't our job to educate and take away all these distractions?" O'Connor said. "It is a distraction, we know this. There are studies, there is data."
Wieland-Cherry responded, saying it's hard to stop an addiction like cell phone usage cold turkey. "They do need time to adjust," she said.
Jackson said she's open to considering an expansion into high school in the future, but not for next year. She said there's added nuance to the situations high schoolers face, such as those who are parents, care for younger siblings or work jobs.
"I look at high schoolers and think there's a major difference between a freshman and a senior," Jackson said.
During discussion, O'Connor motioned for the pouch program to be extended to high schools in the district. Board member Deborah Bridges joined her in voting yes, but the remaining five members voted the measure down.

title: 'We can turn lightbulbs on'
author: Staff Writer
content:
'We can turn lightbulbs on'

 April 12, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Staff Writer | Section: Editors Inbox 
 
 318
 Words 

 Read News Document

 Thank you for Maggie Trovato's uplifting article, "We Can Turn Lightbulbs On." It offered a rare but welcome dose of hope.The piece spotlighted the work of three retired health care professionals — led by Dr. Judy Gieske — along with a team of volunteers launching Introduction to Careers in Healthcare (ITCH), a program designed to spark and sustain student interest in health care careers from middle through high school. It will serve Caroline, Dorchester, Kent, Queen Anne's and Talbot counties.
The timing couldn't be better. Construction has finally begun next to the Talbot Community Center on a long-promised, modern inpatient medical facility — expected to open in 2028. Yet even the most advanced hospital is useless without skilled, dedicated staff.
Our current Memorial Hospital depends heavily on traveling doctors and nurses. While competent and committed, they aren't rooted in our community. Many of us remember a time when our health care providers lived next door, when nurses were trained locally at the McQueen-Gibbs School, and when the hospital was the region's largest employer. The quality of care felt stronger because the staff had a personal stake in our well-being.
Memorial Hospital once helped drive local economic growth. Quality health care made Talbot County attractive to retirees, professionals, and families alike — people drawn to both the lifestyle and the peace of mind that came with reliable, community-centered care.
The ITCH program aims to reignite that connection by:
Introducing health care careers early.Supporting local students through their journey.Building a skilled, homegrown workforce.Reconnecting the hospital and the community.
These are long-term goals, but the potential return on investment is huge — economically and socially.
I urge my neighbors to support ITCH in any way they can. Whether through mentorship, donations or spreading the word, every effort matters. Let's bring the hospital back to the community — and the community back to the hospital.
Thanks to the Star-Democrat for shining a light on this promising initiative.
HUGH M. SMITH
Easton

title: Maryland State of Reading Report: 'time for a comeback after a decade of decline'
author: ANDREA GRABENSTEIN agrabenstein@chespub.com
content:
Maryland State of Reading Report: 'time for a comeback after a decade of decline'

 April 16, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: ANDREA GRABENSTEIN agrabenstein@chespub.com | Section: Local News 
 
 469
 Words 

 Read News Document

 BALTIMORE — Maryland's schools are showing signs of progress in reading achievement, but a new report underscores that a deep and lasting crisis remains.The Maryland READS "State of Reading in Maryland 2025: It's Time for a Comeback After a Decade of Decline" report reveals that although incremental gains have been made among fourth-grade students, 67% still cannot read at a proficient level — a figure that mirrors the stagnation seen in eighth grade.
"We are still facing a reading crisis," said Trish Brennan-Gac, executive director of Maryland READS. "Our state is dealing with a budget crisis, including unexpected federal education cuts. Equally concerning, our report shows far too many students are not able to read proficiently."
Brennan-Gac's remarks come as state and local leaders attempt to reverse a long-term decline in literacy.
Maryland READS is a nonprofit working to improve reading instruction in the state. The organization partners with government officials and community leaders to create better policies based on research it conducts.
The report, released amid a backdrop of rising education spending — up 37% to nearly $18,900 per pupil since 2013 — provides a snapshot of Maryland's progress compared with national trends. While the state has nudged ahead of some peers in its national ranking for fourth grade reading scores, nearly two thirds of children continue to struggle.
"Reading is an investment," Brennan-Gac said. "Results will not come to fruition unless everyone works together."
The executive director stressed strong reading skills are critical not only for academic success, but for long-term outcomes like career readiness and reducing chronic absenteeism. "If a child can't read, they feel stupid and don't want to come to school," Brennan-Gac said.
Based on data provided by Maryland READS using the Maryland Comprehensive Assessment Program reading scores to assess the health of reading instruction in individual districts, Mid-Shore learners fall below 50% proficiency in English Language Arts with the exception of students in Queen Anne's County.
The 2024 ELA Proficiency rates are:
Caroline: 45.5%.
Dorchester: 33.7%.
Kent: 41.2%.
Queen Anne's: 58.5%
Talbot: 47.3%.
State leaders have taken steps toward a solution by prioritizing teacher training and the development of literacy coaching programs. However, Brennan-Gac criticized recent legislation for "missing the mark" by not providing adequate funding for literacy coaches — a move she argues is essential for translating research-based practices into everyday classroom instruction.
In addition to bolstering teacher support, the report calls for a comprehensive, community-driven approach to literacy. It highlights a need for creating reading ecosystems that extend beyond the classroom and address factors such as excessive screen time — a growing barrier to the "deep reading" it says underpins comprehension and critical thinking.
"Over the last year, state leaders have led by taking action, but we need a comprehensive, community-driven effort," Brennan-Gac said. "My hope is the legislator will look at his data and start to ask why and, next year, have a different mindset."

title: High school graduation rate reaches seven-year high
author: Erin Sjostedt Capital News Service
content:
High school graduation rate reaches seven-year high

 April 18, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Erin Sjostedt Capital News Service | Section: State News 
 
 510
 Words 

 Read News Document

 Maryland's high school graduation rate climbed to 88% in 2024, reaching its highest point since 2017, according to the Maryland State Department of Education. The increase of nearly 2 percentage points over the previous year marks a significant recovery following pandemic-era declines.The 2024 data from MSDE shows significant gains among student groups that have historically faced barriers to graduation. Hispanic students saw their graduation rate rise over seven percentage points, while multilingual learners experienced a dramatic increase of over 10%.
"Last year was the largest year-over-year gain of any student group, and I think that's a testimony to targeted, sustained supports that are making the difference," said Theresa Timmons Parrott, an MSDE official focused on multilingual education. "It's a step in the right direction, but it's not the finish line."
Talbot County boasted a graduation rate of 95%, seven points above the state average.
Caroline and Dorchester counties both fell below the state average with rates of 87.5 and 84.4, respectively.
Statewide, female students continued to graduate at higher rates than male students, and white and Asian students graduated at higher rates than their Black and Hispanic peers. Students with disabilities graduated at a rate of 69%, still well below the statewide average. Economically disadvantaged students' graduation rate increased slightly from 2023, graduating at a rate of 82%.
The graduation rate report comes as Maryland begins to implement the Blueprint for Maryland's Future, a landmark education reform law that aims to expand early childhood education, increase college and career readiness and close equity gaps.
Several of the strategies outlined in the Blueprint — including community school models and increased funding for English language learners — align with areas of progress highlighted in the 2024 data.
"If you dig down into the Blueprint, it really lays the foundation for the strategies we're seeing pay off," Parrott said. She attributes a large portion of the progress made to broaden access to early childhood education, target funding for multilingual learners, and mandate college and career readiness pathways by tenth grade.
While the Blueprint for Maryland's Future has driven recent graduation gains, lawmakers enacted adjustments this year due to a projected $3 billion budget shortfall. The Excellence in Maryland Public Schools Act, passed in April 2025, includes a three-year delay in implementing teacher collaborative time and provisions to freeze increases in funding if state revenues significantly decline.
Still, regional disparities persist. While some districts reported graduation rates above 90%, others, particularly in rural counties on the Eastern Shore and in Western Maryland, sit at 80% and below. Education advocates say these gaps underscore the need for continued investment and monitoring.
"This is great news for Maryland," State Superintendent of Schools Carey Wright said in a press release from MSDE. "When we set high standards, deliver strong instruction, and invest in proven supports, our students show that they will exceed expectations."
As the 2025 graduating class enters its final year, educators and policymakers are cautiously optimistic. The latest data suggests that Maryland's post-pandemic recovery is underway, however state education officials say it will require long-term commitment to equity, funding and student support services to maintain.

title: College built as an economic engine for Shore
author: CLIFFORD P. COPPERSMITH
content:
College built as an economic engine for Shore

 April 19, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: CLIFFORD P. COPPERSMITH | Section: Columns 
 
 823
 Words 

 Read News Document

 Nearly 60 years after its inception, Chesapeake College remains at the center of regional progress and innovation. The college's role and mission were highlighted earlier this month when Maryland's top leaders gathered in our Health Professions and Athletics Center.Gov. Wes Moore held his cabinet meeting on our Wye Mills campus, part of an initiative to travel to every corner of the state. After that meeting, Lt. Gov. Aruna Miller and Secretary of the Maryland Higher Education Commission Sanjay Rai toured Chesapeake's skilled trades labs and new mobile welding trailer, to learn about the college's response to local economic and workforce needs and to meet some of our students.
In bringing his cabinet to our campus, Gov. Moore reinforced the college's role as a regional hub, fueling progress for the Shore. We discussed our shared priorities, like connecting Marylanders to jobs, ensuring student success and creating an equitable and robust economy.
Open-access institutions and workforce champions like Chesapeake are helping to give Marylanders a hand up to better lives — and that has always been what we're about. Conceived during the Truman Commission, the concept of the community college is part of the American Dream. As individuals set their own goals and choose their own paths to success, community colleges provide the guidance and knowledge for achieving success.
During a time of rapid change in the 1960s, Eastern Shore leaders joined together to found the college, creating a lasting resource available to all residents of our region. With foresight and a commitment to working together, the founders of Chesapeake created an institution designed to respond to the full spectrum of human interest and ability and to offer something to everyone, from transfer-bound college students to industry professional seeking new certifications to retirees enriching their lives.
Though milestones such as the Wye Mills groundbreaking and opening of the first buildings on campus in 1967 and the first commencement in 1969 would follow, the charter date of December 1965 marks the official beginning of Chesapeake College.
Remarkably, Chesapeake is still the only community college in Maryland with five support counties — a geographical area comprising nearly one fifth of the state's landmass. We're grateful for the support we enjoy from our diverse and beautiful counties, our many and varied business partners and the whole of our service community. That support has enabled this institution to endure for 60 years, in turn supporting Eastern Shore residents in finding meaningful education and employment in a wide variety of political, economic and social changes.
Even now that community-building and economy-building role continues at Chesapeake, through partnerships with county leaders, local school systems, generous donors, friends and more. In the past five years, I am proud to say that our faculty and staff have supported students to higher graduation and transfer rates; we recently ranked second in the state among community colleges, based on a study conducted by the Federal Reserve Bank of Richmond, Virginia.
Looking forward, we have ambitious plans to develop cutting-edge workforce training facilities, to demonstrate that trades jobs are the "new tech" jobs and help keep Eastern Shore talent right here at home on this beautiful peninsula — not just the "land of pleasant living" but a landscape where we see abundant personal and professional opportunities.
Everyone here at Chesapeake is proud to serve our students and region, believing we are one of the most important resources to residents of the Mid-Shore and watching generations of our graduates serving their communities and giving back every day.
Acquiring skills and achieving academic success are key components of a college experience, but personal growth can contribute just as much to a student's life.
Our students develop critical thinking skills and learn how to make intellectual and interpersonal connections. Students get to know and collaborate with classmates of different ages, backgrounds and experiences. They consider the biggest challenges facing society today, and they learn to find common ground and work toward a greater good.
These experiences can't be assessed with test scores, grades or certifications. They are, however, critical for people who are able to adapt and thrive in a rapidly changing world.
I can't predict what the next 60 years will bring for higher education. The world will change in ways that we can only imagine now. Chesapeake College, as always, will adapt to those changes and continue to prepare our students for what's next in their lives as we contribute to the vitality of our community.
I hope you will help us celebrate the 60th birthday of Chesapeake College. We're planning a variety of events on campus to mark this special occasion, and you can learn more about our plans at chesapeake.edu. First up is the dedication of our new mobile welding lab on April 24 at 1:30 pm on our Wye Mills campus. If you can't visit us then, look for our mobile lab in the service area as we take our skilled trades training into the community, striving as always to meet our students wherever they are.

title: Tilghman Island celebrates opening of Judy Center
author: Konner Metz
content:
Tilghman Island celebrates opening of Judy Center

 April 24, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Konner Metz | Section: Local News 
 
 389
 Words 

 Read News Document

 TILGHMAN ISLAND — The Tilghman Elementary School Judy Center, which opened in January, is already serving 40 families.Lori Julian, the center's coordinator, says the early learning hub is important to ensure young children and families become comfortable in a school environment.
"It's really a great transition tool to get children ready and families ready for school," Julian said.
Julian joined community members, school and center staff and state partners Wednesday to cut the ribbon on the Tilghman Island Judy Center. It's Talbot County's third center, following locations in Easton and St. Michaels.
Judy Centers are funded by the state and are a focus of The Blueprint, Maryland's expansive initiative to fund education. Last October, the state awarded a grant to Tilghman Elementary School to create one.
The centers provide workshops, family support services, enrichment and learning activities, and more for children up to five years old, according to the Maryland Department of Education. They provide most services for free for families in the school district where a center is located.
"Learning begins long before a child enters the classroom," Talbot County Public Schools Judy Center Supervisor Amy Walstrum said Wednesday. "It starts at birth."
"The earliest years are the most critical years, and the most influential people during those years are the child's first and most important teachers, who are their families," Walstrum added.
Julian has 25 years of experience as a Judy Center coordinator in Maryland, including in Queen Anne's County and recently at the St. Michaels site. The new Tilghman Island Judy Center is paramount to providing local families with resources, Julian said.
"We had (Tilghman Island) families that were coming to our St. Michaels (site), and then due to funding, we had to tell them they couldn't come anymore," Julian said. "So we lost half our families. So when we put in for this grant, we were blessed to get it here."
Julian says in a way, the Tilghman Island community has been left behind and put at a disadvantage. The elementary school only has about 100 students, community resources are limited and families have to make 20-minute drives to get to a grocery store, she said.
But the Judy Center is a significant step toward closing that gap for local families.
"Because we're such a small school, we really were surprised when we did get the grant," Julian said. "And the families were just thrilled."

title: ‘Catastrophic’: Could Trump 'defund" Head Start preschools program?
author: MIKE SUNNUCKS APG Media
content:
‘Catastrophic’: Could Trump 'defund" Head Start preschools program?

 April 28, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: MIKE SUNNUCKS APG Media | Section: National 
 
 889
 Words 

 Read News Document

 Jennie Mauer is concerned about a looming "chaotic disaster."Mauer is executive director of the Wisconsin Head Start Association.
Head Start is a federal program offering free preschools to close to 800,000 lower-income kids nationwide and dates to the 1960s.
Mauer and other early education advocates are worried about current Head Start funding and the program's future with President Donald Trump's austerity efforts and a draft White House budget showing no funding for the $12.1 billion preschool effort.
In some rural and poorer communities, Head Start can be one of the only childcare options for lower income and working class families.
"There are many places where Head Start fills a critical void," said Mauer, whose group represents preschools across Wisconsin that receive funding under Head Start.
Earlier this month, U.S. Sen. Patty Murray, D-Washington, said the Trump administration has slowed $943 million in existing Head Start funding that goes directly from the federal government to local providers across the country.
Murray said in a statement the "slow-walk' of money prompted one Head Start provider serving 400 kids in eastern Washington state to temporarily close earlier this month.
"Before our very eyes, Donald Trump is defunding Head Start," said U.S. Sen. Tammy Baldwin, D-Wisconsin.
She said the Trump administration has delayed as much as $35 million in approved Head Start disbursements in Wisconsin so far this year.
Mauer said 40 Head Start providers in Wisconsin are budgeted $258 million annually to serve approximately 15,000 kids.
She said current DOGE efforts — including a short-lived spending freeze right after Trump took office in January and downsizing at the U.S. Department of Health & Human Services — have providers jumping through more hoops to get payrolls approved and the families they serve are concerned about current and future funding.
"It's chaotic," she said.
Mauer and other Head Start backers say the program is the only thing keeping some areas of the country from becoming "child care deserts" with few (or sometimes no) affordable daycare options.
Karen Filipovich, executive director of the Montana Head Start Association, said there is uncertainty about the War on Poverty-era program.
"I think right now there is a lot of wait and see," Filipovich said.
Head Start funding in Montana totals $62 million annually. Filipovich said there are 22 programs, including on Native American reservations, serving more than 3,900 kids.
She said many areas of Montana, which has a population of just over 1.1 million people, are already childcare deserts with few affordable options.
The average cost of child care is $1,000 per month in Montana, Tennessee, Florida and other states and can run even more in other states, including Ohio ($1,400 per month), Maryland ($1,600 per month) and California ($1,800), according to the Economic Policy Institute.
Filipovich doesn't think state governments have the financial bandwidth to take over funding.
"We are already struggling with the capacity to take care of kids," she said.
Head Start advocates said the cuts or an elimination would have its economic toll, making it harder for working class parents and grandparents to afford child care and get jobs.
Filipovich said those families are also concerned about other Trump cuts and potential changes for Medicaid, Social Security and other safety net programs.
Trump's Department of Government Efficiency (DOGE) austerity programs and congressional Republican efforts have frequently mirrored Project 2025.
The policy blueprint calls for Head Start to be eliminated, saying the program "is fraught with scandal and abuse" and citing a 2020 federal Inspector General's report that said as many as 'one in four' Head Start providers had problems with child supervision and others were not promptly reporting abuse or mistreatment allegations.
"Between October 2015 and May 2020, 12 % of recipients received an adverse finding for child abuse," the 2020 federal inquiry found.
In March, the Trump administration announced it was looking to cut 20,000 jobs at HHS to bring the agency headcount down to 62,000 employees.
The austerity efforts have resulted in the closure of six of HHS's 10 regional offices, including in Chicago, New York and Seattle.
The agency — which has said its restructurings will improve efficiencies and use of tax dollars — has not yet responded to a request for comment on Head Start funding.
Wanda Minick, executive director of the Florida Head Start Association, said the government-funded preschool program also offers hearing and vision screenings as well as meal and nutrition programs for low-income kids.
"At a time when we need solutions to workforce shortages, early education access, and economic disparities, cutting Head Start would be a step backward," Minick said.
Filipovich said Head Start staff are also worried about the future of the program and their jobs.
Head Start preschool programs, which serve infants and toddlers up to age 5, employ more than 250,000 staff across the country, according to the National Head Start Association (NHSA).
That includes 1,300 workers in Montana and close to 11,600 in Florida.
NHSA has called a federal defunding of Head Start "catastrophic" for working class and low-income families.
Last year, the Biden administration issued a new rule raising Head Start teacher pay — which ranged on average between $35,000 and $40,000 nationally — by approximately $10,000.
Republicans pushed back on the pay increases, with U.S. Rep. Virginia Foxx, R-North Carolina, saying "the effort smells like an attempt to form Head Start educators into a unionized political block."
The Trump administration — which has reversed a number of policies from the previous White House — has not yet taken any action on Biden's Head Start pay rule.

title: Maryland graduation rates hit 88% in '24 a seven-year high
author: ERIN SJOSTEDT Capital News Service
content:
Maryland graduation rates hit 88% in '24 a seven-year high

 April 29, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: ERIN SJOSTEDT Capital News Service | Section: State News 
 
 406
 Words 

 Read News Document

 Maryland's high school graduation rate climbed to 88% in 2024, reaching its highest point since 2017, according to the Maryland State Department of Education. The increase of nearly 2 percentage points over the previous year marks a significant recovery following pandemic-era declines.The 2024 data from the education department shows significant gains among student groups that have historically faced barriers to graduation. Hispanic students saw their graduation rate rise over seven percentage points from 2023-2024, while multilingual learners experienced a dramatic increase of over 10%.
"Last year was the largest year-over-year gain of any student group, and I think that's a testimony to targeted, sustained supports that are making the difference," said Theresa Timmons Parrott, a state education official focused on multilingual education. "It's a step in the right direction, but it's not the finish line."
Anne Arundel County Public Schools reported a graduation rate of 89%, two percentage points above the state average. North County High School in Glen Burnie, a Title I school, achieved a 7% increase in its graduation rate.
Bob Mosier, chief communications officer for Anne Arundel County Public Schools, said "every student group is different, and so it's providing students with what it is that they need on an individual basis to be successful."
"A nearly full-point jump in overall graduation rate is a very significant accomplishment," Mosier said. "We also had six schools that increased by two percentage points or more."
Statewide, female students continued to graduate at higher rates than male students, and white and Asian students graduated at higher rates than their Black and Hispanic peers. Students with disabilities graduated at a rate of 69%, still well below the statewide average. Economically disadvantaged students' graduation rate increased slightly from 2023, graduating at a rate of 82%.
The graduation rate report comes as Maryland begins to implement the Blueprint for Maryland's Future, a landmark education reform law that aims to expand early childhood education, increase college and career readiness and close equity gaps. Several of the strategies outlined in the Blueprint — including community school models and increased funding for English language learners — align with areas of progress highlighted in the 2024 data.
"If you dig down into the Blueprint, it really lays the foundation for the strategies we're seeing pay off," Parrott said. She attributes a large portion of the progress made to broaden access to early childhood education, target funding for multilingual learners, and mandate college and career readiness pathways by 10th grade.

title: PoliTalks transitions leadership as new era begins at Washington College
author: WILL BONTRAGER wbontrager@chespub.com
content:
PoliTalks transitions leadership as new era begins at Washington College

 May 1, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: WILL BONTRAGER wbontrager@chespub.com | Section: News 
 
 822
 Words 

 Read News Document

 CHESTERTOWN — The founders of PoliTalks, Washington College students Stephen Hook and Zach Affeldt, are stepping down from group leadership as they graduate next month.While both are preparing for promising careers, Hook assured the crowd at their spring lecture on April 24 at Hynson Lounge that the club's future is in good hands. The event, held on the second floor of Hodson Hall, featured renowned speaker Heather Mizeur, who delivered the lecture "Disagreement is Democratic."
The lecture, free to the public, included an introduction to the new PoliTalks leadership: co-presidents Charlotte Schurman and Grace Walsh. "We feel confident in our team to take the group forward," Schurman said during a catered meal and Q&A session following Mizeur's discussion.
Schurman and Walsh are continuing the tradition of PoliTalks: to provide a safe, respectful forum for political education and conversation.
Hook reflected on the club's success during a politically charged climate, noting that he was pleased to see people with differing views engage in peaceful discussions about polarizing issues during the Trump administration.
Mizeur, a former Maryland state delegate, candidate for Congress, and CEO and founder of WeAreOne Alliance, led these discussions. This was her second time giving the lecture. She discussed the guiding principles she learned while reaching across the aisle and campaigning.
Just as she did at the Toll Science Center on Oct. 17, 2024, Mizeur introduced her mnemonic device: **RESPECTFUL**, which stands for Reciprocity, Engagement, Sovereignty, Pause, Equanimity, Curiosity, Trust, Freedom, Unhook, and Listen.
In this session, she focused on the "S" — **Sovereignty**.
Mizeur defined sovereignty as "the ability to stand in your own agency." She explained that how we respond to political disagreements, while maintaining self-control and understanding, is key to sovereignty.
Mizeur stated that the nation's collective sovereignty is currently under assault. She criticized the Trump administration for trampling due process and weaponizing fear and control, leading to the dehumanization of people.
"The initial response to these policies," Mizeur said, "is to react with fear and frustration, instead of responding with sovereignty, which is a conscious choice rooted in integrity."
Sovereignty, Mizeur explained, is a calming force that leads us to a different path, one that cannot be legislated or controlled.
"It's not earned, but inherited," Mizeur said.
She offered lessons on how to reconnect with one's own inherited sovereignty.
Mizeur emphasized that sovereignty does not mean being a doormat. It requires setting boundaries, practicing a firm "yes" and "no," and avoiding separation from others, which leads to isolation and despair. She encouraged practices like journaling, speaking with a friend or partner, and engaging in joyful activities to help individuals maintain sovereignty.
Mizeur also emphasized the importance of listening to the body's warnings and stepping back from social media to detox and nourish oneself.
"Sovereignty is a practice, not a switch you turn on and off when needed," Mizeur added.
She said practicing these principles brings deeper joy, freedom, and can spark real change in hearts and lives.
The discussion continued over a catered dinner, where guests of all ages discussed how to apply these principles in their own lives. Some shared stories of losing friends or family members over political differences and blocking people on social media. Tensions over political debates had surfaced in families.
One attendee suggested that protests, such as the "Hands Off Rally," should include what participants are fighting for, in addition to what they oppose, emphasizing the positive.
A few attendees remarked that they no longer view people with opposing views as "enemies." A central lesson from Mizeur's talk was to lead with curiosity and learn from everyone, regardless of their political affiliation.
Others acknowledged that life experiences can lead to differing viewpoints, and sometimes, religion plays a role in those differences.
One woman pointed out issues on which everyone could agree, such as the need for more jobs and affordable housing.
Hook, who founded PoliTalks after witnessing the need for peaceful discussions on campus following a Washington College lecture by conservative speaker Robert George, expressed his satisfaction with the club's success. George had cut his speech short on Sept. 7, 2023, due to protests.
"This is the best possible way we could have ended with the club," Hook said.
He thanked everyone involved, especially Mizeur, for her nonprofit work in coalition building through community partnerships. "Heather brings a unique narrative to the conversation around political dialogue that we believe is important for our community to hear," Hook said.
For those who missed Mizeur's talks, they can sign up for her newsletter and receive information about her 2025 programming at [https://www.weareonealliance.org/](https://www.weareonealliance.org/).
What's next for PoliTalks under new leadership?Schurman noted that environmental justice is a strong focus across campus. She plans to invite Serena C. McIlwain, Maryland secretary of the environment, for a future lecture.
As they call for more student involvement, PoliTalks plans to hold monthly meetings.
Several members of the Chestertown government attended the event, including Mayor David Foster and Council Member Sheila Austrian of Ward 1. Austrian found the discussion eye-opening and thanked the college and PoliTalks for reaching out to the community in such a meaningful way.

title: Assanis to step down as University of Delaware president
author: Josh Shannon jshannon@chespub.com
content:
Assanis to step down as University of Delaware president

 May 5, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Josh Shannon jshannon@chespub.com | Section: News 
 
 1284
 Words 

 Read News Document

 University of Delaware President Dennis Assanis will step down at the end of the school year, he said in a surprise announcement Monday.The decision comes as Assanis has one year left on his contract but has faced increasing criticism from faculty over his handling of the university's finances.
"At this point, I believe I have made the meaningful contributions that I set out to accomplish with all of you in translating our shared vision into a reality and advancing our institutional mission and strategic goals," Assanis wrote in a letter to the campus community. "I therefore feel this is the appropriate moment to make a leadership transition, with the institution's best interests always in mind and a thoughtful approach for continued growth and excellence."
Assanis will work through June 30, and then an interim president will take over while the board of trustees searches for a new permanent leader, a process that often takes upward of a year.
Board President Terri Kelly said the interim president will be announced later.
"I want to thank Dennis Assanis for his inspiring leadership and service as the University of Delaware's 28th president," Kelly said in a statement. "His tireless commitment and bold vision have been transformative, advancing the university to new levels of accomplishment, promise and potential. As we look ahead to the next chapter in the university's leadership, President Assanis' legacy of purpose-driven, positive change will forever have an impact on UD's continued future of institutional excellence. We wish him and Eleni nothing but the best for their future."
Assanis' resignation follows a string of high-profile departures in recent months. John Long, executive vice president and chief operating officer, is retiring this week, and Mary Remmler, senior vice president and chief financial officer, resigned last week. Athletic Director Chrissi Rawak left earlier this year.
It also comes at a fraught time for higher education institutions nationwide, which have seen funding cuts and other threats from the Trump administration.
A record of campus growth
Assanis came to UD in 2016, replacing former president Patrick Harker. Before coming to Delaware, the native of Greece was provost at Stony Brook University and had spent most of his academic career as an engineering professor and administrator at the University of Michigan.
In 2021, the UD Board of Trustees announced that it had extended Assanis' contract through 2026. With a total compensation of more than $1.5 million, he was the third-highest paid public university president in 2023, according to rankings by the Chronicle of Higher Education.
Assanis' tenure at UD was marked by tremendous growth at the STAR Campus, including the construction of the STAR Tower, the Ammon Pinizzotto Biopharmaceutical Innovation Center, the Chemours Discovery Hub, the FinTech Innovation Hub and, coming soon, the Securing American Biomanufacturing Research and Education Center and a Buccini Pollin Group apartment complex. UD's role as headquarters for the National Institute for Innovation in Manufacturing Biopharmaceuticals has brought in hundreds of millions in federal funding.
When Assanis arrived in 2016, the STAR Campus was still in its infancy. Now, the site is home to 1.2 million square feet of new buildings and employs 3,000 people, more than it did when Chrysler was there.
On the main campus, UD opened the South Academy Residence Hall and, most recently, the new interdisciplinary science lab known as Building X. Earlier this year, the university announced its largest-ever donation, a $71.5 million commitment from alumni Rob and Kathy Siegfried to construct a new building for the Alfred Lerner College of Business and Economics.
Assanis also launched the First State Promise, a program that aims to cover all tuition and fees for Delawarean undergraduate students coming from families with incomes under $75,000. Approximately one-third of enrolled Delawareans are covered by the program.
On the athletics side, one of Assanis' first hires was Rawak as athletic director and together they aimed to increase the prominence of Blue Hen sports programs, which Assanis often said are the "front porch" of the university. He presided over the renovation of Delaware Stadium, the construction of the Whitney Athletic Center and most recently the decision to move to Conference USA and the Football Bowl Subdivision.
Financial strife
Assanis led the university through COVID-19, a crisis that required the university to quickly pivot to virtual learning and upended the university's finances. At the height of the pandemic, UD reported a $250 million deficit and instituted employee layoffs and furloughs.
As the pandemic waned, the university's financial difficulties continued. In 2024, Assanis reported that UD had a budget deficit of up to $40 million, which he blamed on inflation and skyrocketing health insurance costs.
Assanis instituted a partial hiring freeze, delayed capital projects, restricted employee travel and implemented other austerity measures. The university is forecasting another large deficit this year.
It was Assanis' handling of that situation that prompted criticism from faculty members.
Last spring, a survey of more than 750 university professors found that virtually all believed the university was not transparent about its finances and that it did not prioritize academics when it came to budgeting, according to reporting by the Newark Post's newsroom partner, Spotlight Delaware. About a dozen professors submitted anonymous comments that said they wanted faculty to call for a vote of no confidence in Assanis.
In a study released earlier this year, the faculty union questioned Assanis' "poverty narrative" and argued that the university's continued building spree was to blame for the financial difficulties.
"That's a lot of operating resources to be directed into building," Persephone Braham, the president of the university's faculty union, told Spotlight Delaware. "That's tuition, that's fees, that's research [facilities and administrative] funding, that is a local contribution from the endowment draw down, and only an average of 9-10% is being funded by presidential fundraising."
Town-gown relations
Assanis leaves a complicated legacy in terms of the university's relationship with the city it calls home.
Under his tenure, UD has faced sustained criticism from many Newark leaders and residents for its decision to push more of the burden of housing students onto the private sector, putting pressure on the city to approve more and more off-campus student housing projects, often against the wishes of residents.
In 2019, UD abruptly closed the Christina Towers, thus taking 1,300 beds off the market. The university also took control of the once-private University Courtyard Apartments, which removed the sprawling complex from the city tax rolls.
UD has also faced criticism for not contributing enough to the city's finances. That came to a head last year when city council — against the strong opposition of the UD administrators and students — began lobbying the state legislature for the power to levy a per-student tax on UD. A bill allowing the city to do so passed the state House and is awaiting consideration in the Senate.
Former mayor Jerry Clifton credited Assanis with cultivating a better relationship with the city than previous UD administrations did.
"Dennis made sure that I had all his contact information and could readily reach out to him," Clifton said in an interview Monday. "I've enjoyed our relationship together with Dennis and Eleni, and I certainly will miss that."
He also praised Assanis for agreeing to sell the former Rodney dorm complex to the city at a steep discount, leading to the creation of Hillside Park and the stormwater pond.
"It was a huge win for the city," Clifton said. "There's no way that would be a park today if it wasn't for the university and Dennis cooperating at the level that they did."
That said, UD's public battle against the student tax hurt how the public views the university, Clifton said.
"I think there could have been, and had been some, negotiations, but what they saw as their value to the community was not necessarily the cash that we saw that we needed because of the loss in tax revenue," he said.

title: A dream come true: Italian exchange student spending a year in Maryland
author: MARTY MADDEN mmadden@somdnews.com
content:
A dream come true: Italian exchange student spending a year in Maryland

 May 6, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: MARTY MADDEN mmadden@somdnews.com | Section: News 
 
 669
 Words 

 Read News Document

 Unlike Mantua, Italy, there is no opera house in Huntingtown. However, to Emma Agazzani, a resident of Italy's "Capital of Culture," living in the U.S.A. in general and Calvert County in particular has hit a high note.According to her, it's been a dream come true.
"It was something I wanted to do since I was very young," the teen told Southern Maryland News, adding that "the language, the culture, the travel" had her determined to pursue the opportunity to experience the life of a foreign exchange student.
"I applied in February 2022 with A.S.S.E.," Agazzani, 17, said.
The American Scandinavian Student Exchange has expanded since it was established in 1976. The exchange has its origins in Europe in the late-1930s. After World War II the exchange gained momentum and today over 30 countries on six continents participate.
On its website, the exchange states its mission is an effort "to foster international understanding through educational and cross cultural programs."
"My parents were hosts," Danielle Higginbotham of Huntingtown told Southern Maryland News in recalling how she and her family opened their home to Agazzani. "I knew it was something we wanted to do. We were researching students and Emma's profile stuck out with us."
Agazzani is a senior at Huntingtown High this year and will walk in the June graduation ceremony before returning to Italy later that month when her exchange program ends. She said since Italian high school is a five-year program she still has another year of secondary schooling to go in her home country before she will be off to a university.
At Huntingtown, Agazzani has been able to experience something that wouldn't be possible in Europe.
Of cheerleading, Agazzani said, "It was another of my dreams. When I think about the U.S. and high school, I think about cheerleading, because cheerleading is not a thing in Italy or Europe in general. It was my only option."
In addition to cheerleading, Agazzani has played lacrosse, a sport that hasn't caught on at all in Europe.
"I just finished lacrosse season and I really like it," she said, crediting her coaches for teaching her how to play the sport and excel in it.
Life for Emma Agazzani of Mantua at Huntingtown High hasn't been all cheers and sports, though. As a student, she is taking classes in Advanced Placement English — she has been taught English since first grade — A.P. Government, pre-calculus, biology, photography and theater.
As for what she will study in college, Agazzani said, "It's going to be something about science. I would like to be a neurologist."
When not in school, the Higginbothams have given Agazzani a chance to see America. She has traveled to several locations in Florida, including Disney World, where she donned a cheerleader's outfit for the annual Christmas parade.
While in Florida, Agazzani also got a chance to swim with dolphins.
"We tried to do a whole bunch of 'must-sees,'" Higginbotham said.
The hosts and exchange student have also traveled to New York City, Atlanta and Philadelphia.
Agazzani recalled one obligatory culinary experience in Philadelphia.
"I had the cheesesteak," she said. "That was amazing."
She also has been to Washington, D.C., and visited the White House during the annual Easter Egg Roll, meeting President Donald Trump and First Lady Melania Trump.
Comparing the urbanized character of her hometown, with its art galleries and opera houses, to the bucolic, wide open expanse of Huntingtown, Agazzani said, "it's very different. In Italy everything is tiny and compressed. Here, everything is spread out and very big."
Of her hometown she said, "We are walkable. We have a lot of history and arts."
Agazzani summed up her Hurricane high school experience, saying, "I really like the school and this town. I'm a senior here. I think it's more interesting."
Higginbotham conceded that the experience of having a teenage cheerleader in her home has been so incredible that, while she will offer aid and advice to other families who want to participate in hosting an exchange student, for now she feels fulfillment from her experiences with Agazzani.
"She's my daughter now," Higginbotham said. "We've created a friendship, a bond."
