title: Talbot council mulling $1.1 million request from school district
author: Konner Metz
content:
Talbot council mulling $1.1 million request from school district

 May 14, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Konner Metz | Section: Local News 
 
 706
 Words 

 Read News Document

 EASTON — With less than two weeks until the Talbot County Council adopts its budget ordinance for next fiscal year, education funding hangs in the balance.Talbot County Public Schools is seeking $1.1 million in additional funds for fiscal year 2026 — $600,000 to fill nine new positions and $500,000 for teacher and staff salary increases. The former would add to the district's multilingual and special education staff, while the latter aims to inch the district closer to state-mandated $60,000 teacher salary minimums by fiscal year 2027.
District leaders say it's a "scaled-back" request from its $5.7 million ask of the county earlier this budget cycle.
"We recognize the financial pressures you face," Board of Education President Emily Jackson said at a May 6 budget hearing. "This ask is lean, deliberate and rooted in what's most necessary to keep moving forward."
In the county's budget already is $55 million for TCPS as required by The Blueprint for Maryland's Future, the state's overarching education improvement framework.
Council members are left to mull the best option as they prepare to vote on final amendments to the county's draft $161 million budget. So far, there's no clear decision.
Council Vice President Pete Lesher supported fulfilling the district's full $5.7 million request last month and maintained that stance for the pared down ask at a budget deliberation Tuesday.
"We're going to have to do it sooner or later," Lesher said. "I think it makes sense to do it this year and reduce the pain next year."
President Chuck Callahan said he feels comfortable with honoring the $600,000 part of the request to cover the new positions.
Council members Keasha Haythe, Lynn Mielke and Dave Stepp have all indicated they need more time to consider options.
Any additional funding granted would result in an education supplement to the property tax rate, which is 79 cents per $100 of assessed value.
Talbot County is already mandated by the state to pay $440,000 for teachers' pensions, which will be collected through a supplement of less than half a cent per $100 of assessed value.
Three potential scenarios for tax supplements have been laid out by county staff:
Teachers' pensions only: 0.0045 per $100 of assessed value.
Teachers' pensions and $500,000 for salary increases: 0.0096 per $100 of assessed value.
Teachers' pensions and $600,000 for new positions: 0.0106 per $100 of assessed value.
Haythe said Tuesday she's trying to balance helping the school system with preventing tax increases for residents on fixed income, such as seniors.
"I am in no way, shape or form trying to discount the great work that the school system does and what the teachers do in the classroom," Haythe said.
At last week's hearing, teachers and parents advocated for the council to include the $1.1 million. Lisa Hayes, a parent of three TCPS graduates, said past education investments are paying off now as her children enter the workforce.
"You cannot not fund a budget for our children's education because there is nothing more important than that," Hayes said.
Andy Burke, president of the Talbot County Education Association, which functions as the teachers' union, made his case.
"We continue to see too many educators migrate away to the higher wages and salaries paid in neighboring public school systems," Burke said.
In an emailed statement, TCPS Chief Financial Officer Sarah Jones said the district made "very difficult choices" to reduce its request to the county.
Jones noted staff will present the Board of Education with a budget amendment package in June, which will adjust the $86 million unrestricted budget the board OK'd in February.
"We will eliminate most of the new positions we had requested," Jones wrote. "We will scale back our requests and defer programs that will have the least direct impact on our goals for our students."
A final decision by the county on the $1.1 million in question, as well as the entire FY26 budget, is expected at the council's May 27 meeting.
While no clear choice was made during Tuesday's deliberations, county and district leaders did agree that state mandates and formulas are creating the tricky fiscal situation.
"It's just become screamingly clear that there's a disconnect at the state level between the requirements that they're putting on local schools across the state, and the funding formulas that are articulated to county governments to pay for their education," said County Manager Clay Stamp.

 Read News Document

 DENTON — The Lockerman Middle School Committee held its first community meeting on the potential new Lockerman Middle School location and specifications Thursday.The meeting featured two potential locations for a new school and a third option of staying at the current location.
The first location would be behind North Caroline High School, and the second would be on Double Hills Road in Denton.
While locations are being looked at, the committee made it clear that the current Lockerman Middle School location would still be there, though it may not remain a school.
The community meeting gave committee members and architects the opportunity to hear the publics thoughts on what historic value should be implemented into the new Lockerman school and on the locations selected.
"We're going to be gathering it, reviewing it," said Robyn Toth, owner of TCA Architects and architect for the potential new Lockerman Middle School. "Then as we go through the site design, we'll be trying to incorporate as many of their concerns and try to accentuate any of the possibilities that they were saying."
The North Caroline High location puts the new site directly to the west of the high school. The potential middle school would sit on a 23-acre parcel.
On that parcel, there is a solar field area that architects would have to contend with. There is also a pasture connected to the Career Center that could impact school placement and design.
Community members brought forward suggestions for what the county could do with the Lockerman location if it moved next to North Caroline High. They recommended students could share bus routes with high schoolers and made safety suggestions for both schools.
The Double Hills road site is located near the Caroline County Sheriffs Office and Caroline County Emergency Services buildings on 76 acres. The county owns the land, and the Lockerman Committee is looking for a 21-acre portion.
Kevin Shearon, engineer for the Lockerman project, brought attention to the size and distance of the road and made considerations for what they would do to the road to make it accessible for the school.
"Double Hills is a 20-21 foot road with no shoulders on either side," Shearon said. "So, we would consider adding shoulders, at least on the school side or the site side for ACLD cell and just a wider feel for the right."
According to Lockerman Committee members, the public water and sewer could be extended from the Denton's systems for the potential school.
After explaining both new locations, Lockerman Committee members and Superintendent Derek Simmons answered questions from residents and heard their concerns and suggestions.
"It was great to see the turnout," Simmons said. "It was great to see the engagement, folks are really passionate about their faults, which is great. Our architects and our consultants need that information now as we're working in the very early stages of design. I'm glad they came out.
"There will be another opportunity on June 2, and I hope the turnout is equally as good as not better. Because the board's got a big decision to make in July, and we want to provide them with the best information we can on the sites that we're considering."
The next public meeting on potential school locations will be held on June 2 at Lockerman Middle School at 6 p.m. Following that, the committee will have a presentation to the Board of Education on July 1 about their decision.

title: 100 years and counting: Talbot County Free Library endures as community linchpin
author: Konner Metz
content:
100 years and counting: Talbot County Free Library endures as community linchpin

 May 14, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Konner Metz | Section: Local News

 Words 

 Read News Document

 EASTON — Over the last 100 years, the Talbot County Free Library has adapted to societal changes such as the creation of the Internet, economic downturns like the Great Depression and, most recently, a global pandemic.As the world changes around it, the organization's staff and volunteers are ensuring sure the library keeps up. Executive Director Dana Newman believes the library is well-positioned to serve the community's needs for years to come.
"I do think the library will continue to move with the future, and it will continue to be here," Newman said.
Serving residents across the entire county, the Talbot County Free Library has oriented itself as a hub for the county. Between a physical collection of over 130,000 books and other items, computer and technology access, and hundreds of free programs, Newman says the library has more resources available than most people would think.
This October, the library will host a centennial gala, an opportunity for many to celebrate the library's history and its impact on residents in the 100 years since its inception.
Emma Poole, TCFL's communications manager, was born in Easton and still has her original library card from when she was 3.
"This has always been such a safe space for me," Poole said. "My parents brought me here all the time. I begged my mom to bring me to the library. I'd drag her out of the house."
During college, Poole used the library's expansive Maryland Room collection in writing her historical thesis. And now as a staff member, Poole recognizes the institution's purpose in Talbot County extends far past books and research.
"It's so much more than books," she said.
ADAPTING OVER TIME
On Oct. 15, 1925, Talbot County Free Library opened in two rooms in the Tred Avon Building on South Washington Street. Caroline Burnite Walker founded the library, which began with an 800-book collection.
She was a longtime children's librarian, and the early days of Talbot's library focused on serving the youth. Scotti Oliver, current assistant director, says the organization's "emphasis has always been on children's services."
The library offers many early literacy programs, partners with local schools and will host the 10th annual Chesapeake Children's Book Festival this June.
TCFL moved inside the courthouse in the 1940s and soon became one of Maryland's first county-wide public library systems. Around three decades later, it moved to West Dover Street, where it sits today.
Ever since its founding, the nonprofit has constantly adapted, library leaders say.
"I think we demonstrated over time that when people think, 'Well maybe the library's a thing of the past,' it's not," Newman said. "Because there's a new need, and there's a need for instruction. We are a learning institution."
Among the many offerings are book clubs, community meeting rooms, a free collection of seeds, tax assistance aid and social services programs.
Following the pandemic, Newman says the organization reinvented itself in a way, focusing much more on digital literacy classes, availability of computers and devices, and internet access.
Newman noted the library has demonstrated an ability to pivot when needed, a skill that'll help tackle future challenges — one being the rise of AI.
COMMUNITY LINCHPIN
While the library's main branch is in well-populated Easton, TCFL is undergoing renovations to its branch site in St. Michaels. The building will expand and add children's spaces.
One of Newman's hopes is that the Bookmobile service can return. Ending in the 1990s due to a lack of funding, the Bookmobile made trips to remote parts of the county such as Tilghman Island, Cordova and Trappe. Newman said the library understands the importance of reaching these communities, and is looking to secure funding for the venture in the near future.
Around 20,000 county residents hold a library card, over 7,000 of them children. Like Poole, many of those cardholders consider the library a safe place. Newman emphasized that unhoused individuals often rely on that "safe space."
"Libraries exist because people have a need, and we're serving that need as much as we can," Newman says. "And that need continues and has continued for many, many years."

 DENTON — Last week was Teacher Appreciation Week around the nation. For Caroline County Public Schools, honoring the event meant taking time to celebrate teachers and support staff.The weeklong celebration featured free coffee and visits from Caroline County district employees for every school.

title: Removal of Safe Space stickers draws criticism
author: MARTY MADDEN mmadden@somdnews.com
content:
Removal of Safe Space stickers draws criticism

 May 15, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: MARTY MADDEN mmadden@somdnews.com | Section: News 
 
 396
 Words 

 Read News Document

 Calvert County School Board member Melissa Goshorn's comment at the panel's April meeting proved to be prophetic."I recognize it's going to make a lot of people unhappy," Goshorn said just prior to requesting that Superintendent of Schools Andraé Townsel to remove "Safe Space" stickers from school buildings.
Goshorn based her request on anecdotal information she received at a National School Boards Association conference during what she described as a "bone-chilling session" presented by the Beau Biden Foundation.
The story relayed to session attendees dealt with a principal who was arrested on child sex abuse charges and may have gained children's confidence by having a "Safe Space" sticker on the office door.
The sticker is widely used as a sign that LGBTQ students will not be discriminated in that space.
"I think we need to have them removed," Goshorn said.
School maintenance staff removed the stickers and the predicted unhappiness manifested itself during the board's May 8 meeting when 19 of the 20 speakers addressed the issue during the public comment segment. While a handful of the speakers indicated support for the sticker removal, many expressed opposition.
Sheri Tardio of Prince Frederick called the issue "manufactured outrage. Safe space stickers do not promote ideology. Diversity is a fact."
"You are not hiding your biases very well," said Stacy Tayman, president of the Calvert Association for Educational Support Staff.
"Removing stickers is not a violation of First Amendment rights," said school board President Jana Post in her closing comments, adding that the April discussion "was twisted" into an LGBTQ issue.
"Real safety comes from a culture of trust," Post said.
At the conclusion of public comments, board member Paul Harrison made a motion to discuss "a flag policy" at a future meeting. That policy would likely be aimed at setting parameters for displays of flags, posters and decals in school buildings. The motion passed unanimously.
Supervisor's post
The school board unanimously approved the appointment of Marc Watson as supervisor of health, physical education and athletics. The Indiana University of Pennsylvania graduate is a familiar face in Calvert County where he has previously served as a teacher, coach and principal.
Most recently, Watson served as principal of King George High School in Virginia.
Watson told the board he was looking forward to "continuing to create this wonderful environment of learning and athletics" in Calvert County.
In recommending Watson for the appointment, Townsel said the returning administrator will provide "training and mentorship for coaches."

 Galena Elementary School third grader, Helena Sanchez had no idea she came in first place for the speech she wrote in class.At the C. Henry Price II, American Legion Post 246, earlier this month when President of the Auxiliary Patti Bone announced it, Sanchez was so excited she put her hands to her mouth, glancing around the room in amazement. Her family kept it a secret on purpose to make the moment extra special.
Overcoming stage fright, without a hint of waver in her voice, Sanchez read her essay to 30 people in the room.
This was the first speech of the afternoon for the Legion Auxiliary's annual Americanism Essay Contest, created to teach students the value of patriotism.
Thousands of students from grades three to 12 around the nation participate, each year having a different theme.
This year's topic: "What does 'America the Beautiful' mean to me (regarding veterans and our military).
In her essay, Sanchez thanked our military who fight for our country to protect us from enemies.
"Many people have lost their life for us so we can have a better one," she recited.
She added these soldiers are role models and expressed her love for America to a hearty applause.
Like all six speakers that night, she received a cash prize, (first place $50, second $20, third $10) a certificate, congratulations from Betterton Mayor Donald Sutton and a goody bag of patriotic items like comic books, rulers, flags and candy to sweeten the deal.
Winners receive $50 and a $50 donation in the student's name is made to the Children of Warriors National Presidents' Scholarship fund.
Coming in second among third graders, was Chloe Cummings, who talked about the American flag being the symbol of freedom, pride and unity. In third place, Annistyn Clayton explained America brings unity to the world; America is a special place with beautiful landscapes she wants to visit and is home to great friends.
Coming in first for fifth graders was Liam Miller, detailing what makes our military so special, from the oldest branch, the Army, to the newest, the Space Force. He urged the audience to remember why America is a blessed nation.
"America is beautiful because of the things the soldiers did that would not be forgotten. We as Americans celebrate and remember our soldiers. God bless America," he read.
Amelia Rigby, in second, focused in on the lyrics of "America the Beautiful" calling veterans heroes. She was proud of one hero particularly, her mother, an Air Force veteran. Third place Samantha Carroll also talked about the lyrics of "America the Beautiful" providing an in-depth look at some poignant lines which inspire unity in the world.
Bone said the Betterton auxiliary has been having the essay contest for over 15 years and thanked all members of the Legion and the families for their attendance. She said they are always glad to see the community show up and support the students and socialize with refreshments and cookies.
With free family-focused entertainment in mind, she announced they will hold a Community Day on Flag Day, June 14. Bone encouraged the public to check them out and grab a free hotdog. There will be a bouncy house, petting zoo and some other activities planned for that day.
"We love doing these things for our families," Bone said.

Robbins YMCA opening reading hub to tackle childhood illiteracy

 Author/Byline: Lily Tierney | Section: News

 CAMBRIDGE — The Robbins YMCA is stepping up after Dorchester County Public Schools faced significant budget cuts this year.The school district started this budget season with a $10 million deficit. Addressing that deficit meant Dorchester County schools lost after-school and summer programming.
The cuts to education come at a time when the county ranks 21st out of 24 school districts (including Baltimore City) in third grade literacy and 22nd out of 24 in overall English Language Arts proficiency in the state.
The Y is partnering with the John and Janice Wyatt Foundation to create a space for the Dorchester County Campaign for Grade Level Reading, a campaign that aims to target childhood illiteracy.
{span}The campaign was inspired by the movie "Sentenced," which was produced and narrated by NBA champion Stephen Curry. The film explores the epidemic of childhood illiteracy and its lifelong impacts.{/span}
"Dorchester County has, for a long time, been ranked very low in the state of Maryland," said Matthew Peterson, executive director of the John and Janice Wyatt Foundation. "And so interestingly, now concurrent to all the work that the Y is doing, that we're all doing together, Dorchester County Public Schools is undergoing a strategic plan to go from 21st, to 15."
The Dorchester County Campaign for Grade Level Reading plans to approach this goal from multiple angles and with multiple partnerships.
Because third grade is a pivotal marker for childhood learning development, the campaign's target population are children from birth to age 5, so they are better prepared to enter kindergarten, and are less likely to fall behind.
"So we're trying to grab moms as prenatal because we're gonna do infant groups, we're gonna do, you know, toddler groups, mommy and me groups, so we want to bring awareness at early childhood," said Tynice DeShields, director of mental health at the YMCA of Chesapeake.
The campaign's partners include county schools Superintendent Jymil Thompson, the Dorchester County Public Library, United Way of the Lower Eastern Shore, Operation Pathways and volunteers from the community.
"There's a number of agencies we've been working with over the years. You know, as any organization, some were more engaged than others, and so bringing everybody on board, finding out where that alignment fits best, and then trying to leverage that, to do the best we can, is what we've always tried to have," Peterson said.
The reading hub will be a space that is open to the public and YMCA members alike.
"We're building this reading hub as a meeting place where we can have a resource center, we can have meetings with the community, we can have sessions with the parents to teach their kids how to read, how to look at letters and numbers, and not just throw a book in front of them," said Bryant Wittington, director of the Dorchester County Campaign for Grade Level Reading.
Peterson, DeShields and Wittington are excited to engage with the community and hope to build a strong foundation of volunteers at the reading hub.
"We want to build that unity in the community," Wittington said.

 Dogs throughout Leonardtown are wagging their tails in appreciation of a Girl Scout Bronze Award that has enabled them to chill with their owners.Girl Scout Troop 10069 junior members Sarah Mack, Kait Larson, Greta Isom and Stella Hageman worked on a project titled Pet Friendly Patios in Our Community that consisted of producing maps and decals indicating which Leonardtown eateries and cafes' patios were pet friendly.
The map, which lists 17 locations of pet-friendly patios as well as trail lengths for dog walking and locations of four pet waste stations, is available at the Town of Leonardtown, the Leonardtown Wharf and social media outlets.
Decals currently adorn the front doors of T&Js Cove, The Front Porch, Dairy Queen and Noli's.
"I came up with the idea by first thinking about the pet shelters and everything and how we could volunteer there," said Mack, 11, who lives in Leonardtown and said she is a big animal lover. "But we came up with [this idea] of having pet-friendly patios at restaurants."
She added the idea was born because "some restaurants don't allow pets so if you bring your dog in they could just say, 'You're not allowed in.'"
Isom, 11, who also lives in Leonardtown, said the foursome then "started planning out detail by detail what we were going to do" in terms of designing the decal and map.
Each of the four designed a decal and then had a meeting to iron out the final product.
"Our first idea was just to have a heart, more like a paw print than a heart, but then we came up with the idea of a hollow heart with the words pet-friendly patio inside and a paw print," Isom said, "so that was our train of thought leading up to the final product."
The Scouts also attended the Jan. 13 Leonardtown Town Council meeting to request permission for the project.
"They asked us what we were going to do to show they were pet friendly, and we told them we were going to put a decal in the window," Larson, 11, of Leonardtown said, "and they thought it was a good idea."
Troop coleaders Jaime Larson and Marie Isom said the project took around three months and cost about $125.
"We had to go to the different restaurants we had listed that were pet-friendly on the patios," Isom said, "and we would ask them if they would like a decal or a map to put up or we could put up to show they were a pet-friendly patio."
Hafgeman said it was "scary" approaching business owners because she was "not sure of the reaction, and I don't like talking in front of strangers a lot."
The Girl Scout Bronze Award consists of seven steps, including building a team, exploring the community, choosing a project, making a plan and setting it in motion and spreading the word.
The project required at least 20 hours from each Scout and be sustainable.

title: It's time to pause state's education blueprint
author: DAVID REEL
content:
It's time to pause state's education blueprint

 May 17, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: DAVID REEL | Section: Columns 
 
 762
 Words 

 Read News Document

 One of the issues in Maryland's state government and political arena that has generated recurring and intense debate, is funding for a 10-year educational improvement initiative known as the Blueprint for Maryland's Future, also referred to as the Blueprint or as Kirwan.The goals for Kirwan include expanding participation in pre-kindergarten programs, more funding for schools with high concentrations of poverty, increasing pay and opportunities for teachers, and creating career pathways for high school students.
With regard to pre-kindergarten, the Kirwan plan has two specific and measurable goals.
First, in 10 years, 80% of all 4-year-olds and all 3-year-olds are to be enrolled in pre-kindergarten programs, up from 40% in the 2023 school year.
Second, achieve the first goal by using a "mixed delivery system" using public school pre-kindergarten programs and private pre-kindergarten providers.
To date, achieving those goals has been elusive and may not occur on the current schedule.
A headline in one recent Maryland media outlet article was, "Even as spending rises, under half of Maryland 4-year-olds attend public pre-K."
The article references reports from the National Institute for Early Education Research at Rutgers University. They note that Maryland lags behind 17 other states enrolling kids in public pre-kindergarten programs, despite spending thousands more per child than it used to.
Last school year, 38% percent of 4-year-olds in Maryland were enrolled in state-funded pre-K programs, down one spot in the national rankings from the previous year.
Last year, 7% of 3-year-olds in Maryland were enrolled, also one spot below the previous year.
Rutgers reports those results occurred despite Maryland spending $358 million in state funds and an additional $3.8 million in federal pandemic recovery funds.
How much Maryland spent per pre-kindergartner, including federal recovery funds, is up $3,979 from the previous year.
With regard to the goal expecting greater involvement from private prekindergarten providers in an expanded pre-K program, current participation to date, is lower than expected.
In a survey of the state's private childcare providers, only 12.9% of respondents said they plan to or were already involved in the pre-K program created under the Blueprint.
More than a third of the 256 respondents said they were unsure whether they will participate in the pre-K expansion and nearly 40% said they would not. 12.9% of the survey responders had never even heard of it, the same as the percentage of those who are already involved in it.
All this news is in addition to sobering reports from the General Assembly's nonpartisan legislative budget analysts.
They are projecting that by next year, the state's structural budget deficit will grow to $1 billion. In fiscal 2027, the last year of Governor Moore's first term, it grows to $1.3 billion. A year later, it more than doubles to $3 billion.
That certainly helps explain Moody's downgrading the state's fiscal outlook from stable to "negative," citing looming structural deficits driven by state funding needed for Kirwan.
In its report, Moody's wrote, "The negative outlook incorporates difficulties Maryland will face to achieve balanced financial operations in coming years without sacrificing service delivery goals or adding to the weight of the state government's burden on individual and corporate taxpayers."
This news means the leadership of the General Assembly and Gov. Moore need to engage further in bi partisan dialogue and deliberations on tough decisions regarding revisions to Kirwan.
That is not unprecedented.
Gov. Moore and the General Assembly leadership did that prior to the end of the 2025 General Assembly session. There was bipartisan agreement on and support to delay a Kirwan mandate for local school districts to increase teacher collaborative time for curriculum planning, grading and professional development outside of the classroom.
About that outcome Moore said, "Two years before I was sworn in as governor, the General Assembly passed a historic piece of education reform. But, like any big law of ambition and bold aspiration, we knew that there would have to be responsible adjustments and enhancements that had to be made."
The revisions made on teacher collaborative time were a good step but is not nearly enough.
The governor must call for a special legislative session as soon as possible this year and well before the next regular 90-day session that convenes in January 2026.
He must also ensure the sole focus for that special session is next steps for Kirwan.
The best outcome of that special session should be twofold.
Bipartisan approval to a pause on all state funding for Kirwan until a date certain in the future.
Bipartisan approval of a pause on all new mandates for local school boards, until a date certain in the future. They know best about student needs and limits on funds to meet those needs.
Maryland citizens and Maryland taxpayers deserve nothing less.

title: TCPS cuts back on summer school; board displeased with how decision was made
author: Konner Metz
content:
TCPS cuts back on summer school; board displeased with how decision was made

 May 22, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Konner Metz | Section: Local News 
 
 535
 Words 

 Read News Document

 EASTON — Talbot Board of Education members expressed displeasure with cuts made to the district's summer school programs, arguing they should have been part of the decision-making process.Superintendent Sharon Pepukayi outlined Talbot County Public Schools' reduced summer programming during Wednesday's Board of Education meeting.
Summer school will not be offered to elementary or middle school students as it had been in recent years. According to the district, summer school traditionally spanned four weeks, Mondays through Thursdays.
"We decided to make the decision this summer not to have summer school as we've had it prior," Pepukayi said. "To take this time to really reset and to talk to our families and our students and our staff to find out what we could do to have a robust summer programming moving forward."
Previously, summer programs were funded through grants, Pepukayi said. But as pandemic-era grants have dried up, she said the district looked at cutting costs for this fiscal year. Summer school would have cost around $350,000.
The district will continue to have the following programs:
Middle school transition, or 6th Grade Academy.
Credit recovery for high school students.
Band camps.
Summer Career Enrichment Program, a multi-county program held at Easton High School.
Extended School Year for students receiving special education services.
On Wednesday, Board of Education members expressed disappointment that they weren't included in the decision to trim summer school.
"It ultimately affects a budgetary item, and the board was not asked to vote on it," Vice President Amy Dodson said.
Board President Emily Jackson said she's "dismayed" and "concerned" about how the decision was made without board input.
"Why weren't we told that we weren't planning for it, why weren't families told that we weren't planning for it?" Jackson asked. "Why did this decision come out last week to kind of surprise everybody?
"All of those families, all of those teachers, everybody who has counted on summer school for so long for whatever individual, personal reasons they have are now left scrambling to figure out how to pay their bills this summer, or what to do with their students."
In making the decision, Pepukayi said the district kept an eye on what nearby districts were doing.
In March, Dorchester County Public Schools canceled nearly all of its summer school programs as it grappled with closing a multi-million dollar deficit. DCPS Superintendent Jymil Thompson and board members shared the decision to families through a joint announcement.
TCPS first announced the summer school cancellation in a May 1 superintendent's update newsletter, though it wasn't discussed at any open board meetings prior. A district spokesperson said the final decision was made in late April.
Responding to board members' concerns, Pepukayi said she heard "loud and clear" that it should've been brought to their attention during budget season. She said the board will be included on such discussions in the future.
Along with voicing concerns about communication, board members touched on what students may miss out on with the cuts.
"I was disappointed about the summer programs being cut, because I thought that's what we had to do, especially for our (multilingual learners) to keep them going all summer," Ann O'Connor said.
"We do have students that are still experiencing a COVID gap," Cynthia Jurrius said. "So that's really my number one concern, is the students who are behind."

content:
Chesapeake College honors Class of 2025

 May 22, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: ANDREA GRABENSTEIN agrabenstein@chespub.com | Section: Local News 
 
 496
 Words 

 Read News Document

 WYE MILLS — Skipjacks sailed toward promising new horizons as the 2025 Chesapeake College commencement recognized 260 graduates, with 135 walking, on May 21.College President Clifford Coppersmith welcomed the Class of 2025, epitomizing the can-do Skipjack spirit. He encouraged graduates to never fear, embrace hard work and maintain connections.
"Everyone has to start somewhere, and sometimes the correct way is not the easiest," Coppersmith said. With its legacy of watermen and farmers, the Eastern Shore is known even today for its strong work ethic, he said.
Keynote speaker, former U.S. Sen. Ben Cardin, was presented the college's Community Service Award in recognition of his service as a senior statesman, his Chesapeake Bay protection efforts, his dedication to human and civil rights, and his staunch advocacy for higher education.
"Graduation marks a profound turning point in your life. It is not only the culmination of hard work and dedication, but also the beginning of a new chapter filled with opportunity. What you do with that opportunity is up to you," Cardin said.
"Embrace hope," Cardin said, noting the student body was stronger due to its diversity. "Never give up hope for a stronger, more inclusive, more equitable society," he said.
Cardin urged graduates to recognize history lessons as more than words in textbooks, but as guides on what not to do and on how ordinary individuals can be extraordinary.
"As graduates, you have the tools to think globally and act locally. You are the architects of a world where hope becomes reality," he said.
For her breakthroughs in pushing learning past the pages of textbooks, including unforgettable methods of blending academic rigor with applied learning and creative applications, the inaugural Adjunct Innovative Teaching Award was presented to Cherie Patchett, instructor of psychology.
Opening eyes to the world of psychology, Patchett's impact was also noted to extend beyond the classroom, supporting students by establishing a mental health club on campus.
Patchett encouraged graduates to embrace their individuality to innovate their lives.
The John T. Harrison Award was presented to 2025 graduate Cianni A. Phillips for her dedication and empathy. She exemplified true leadership qualities by developing student-focused campus communities.
Phillips is a member of the Phi Theta Kappa Honor Society and is on the Dean's List with a 3.8 GPA.
Phillips served on the Student Government Association, was president of the UHURU Black Student Union, and, in addition to numerous student clubs, served as a student worker in the Office of Diversity, Equity, and Inclusion. She will transfer to Coppin State University in Baltimore to pursue a bachelor's degree in social work.
Looking upon the graduating class, Phillips noted the students balanced all manner of life, including jobs and families, along with their schoolwork, to successfully earn a place at the commencement, which was more than a ceremony — it was a celebration and victory, she said.
Moving forward, Phillips encouraged her classmates to continually build support networks, pour back into the community, and be the representation so strongly needed.
"Young people need to see what their futures can be," she said.

 EASTON — Easton High School senior Kirn Khan and St. Michaels High School senior Alexandria Rockwell are this year's Talbot County Public Schools Senior Service Stars.Khan and Rockwell were recognized at the Board of Education meeting Wednesday for their exceptional community service.
"I'm especially excited with these young ladies, because so often students tell me they can't find time to do service learning because they're so busy," said Linda Brown, a culinary arts teacher at Easton High who's involved in the district's service learning initiatives.
"But wait until you see what these ladies have accomplished in addition to well over hundreds of hours," she added.
Rockwell amassed over 380 service learning hours. She volunteered at the St. Michaels Community Center, National Art Honor Society and Talbot County STEM Camp, among other organizations and programs.
Rockwell said in her second year volunteering at the STEM camp, she was responsible for raising funds for the program as the the finance and budget chair.
The soon-to-be St. Michaels High graduate will attend the U.S. Naval Academy in the fall. She's the first female from St. Michaels High to receive a Naval Academy appointment.
Khan was recognized Wednesday for her more than 450 service learning hours. She was involved in programs and clubs such as Interact Club, MY Tech Clinic, Teen Court and local STEAM camps.
She began community service in seventh grade volunteering at the YMCA. "It really kind of instilled that deep-rooted passion for my community and involvement," Khan said.
Khan plans to attend the University of Maryland in the fall on a full Banneker/Key Honors College Scholarship.

title: Community rallies around retired teacher after tornado
author: Lily Tierney
content:
Community rallies around retired teacher after tornado

 May 27, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Lily Tierney | Section: Dorchester 
 
 363
 Words 

 Read News Document

 GALESTOWN — After former North Dorchester High School baseball coach Dan Hortert's home was severely damaged by an EF-1 tornado, the community rallied around him to help pick up the pieces.Members of the baseball and softball teams, teachers, parents and former students responded to a Facebook post encouraging them to come out and help. The response was overwhelming.
People showed up with tractors, cranes, homemade cookies, pizza and determination to Hortert's Galestown, Delaware home Saturday morning.
"It's just unbelievable," the coach said through tears as he looked around at the support. "The Dorchester community as a whole is a whole lot closer than people can even describe," he said.
Hortert officially retired from North Dorchester High School last year. He was a beloved science teacher and baseball coach.
He has lived with his wife Kathy in their Galestown home for the past 50 years, and their daughter Angela lives in the home next door.
The damage to Hortert's home was mainly caused by two trees in the front yard. One of the trees snapped at the base, breaking through the house's roof, and the other was completely uprooted, destroying a shed in the backyard.
The family and one of their cats were in Hortert's home during the tornado, sheltering under the staircase. They got through the storm unharmed.
The cat had delivered a litter of kittens a few weeks prior, and the young cats were living in the garage. As soon as the tornado passed, Angela ran out to check on them, and they were also unscathed. "It all happened so fast," she said.
Hortert said the day after the tornado hit, community members began coming by asking how they could help.
"You know, Hortert's a great guy. He'll probably do anything for anyone. He's very willing to help, especially the youth," said North Dorchester High School senior TJ Leonard. This sentiment was echoed by several of the other volunteers gathered Saturday morning.
Hortert said that 50 years of teaching showed him how good the kids are at heart.
"The public schools are getting a bad rap, and North Dorchester in particular gets that from time to time, but its a wonderful school with wonderful kids that are a wonderful community," Hortert said.

title: Maryland school district delves into AI, conduct codes, cheating
author: MARTY MADDEN mmadden@somdnews.com
content:
Maryland school district delves into AI, conduct codes, cheating

 May 28, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: MARTY MADDEN mmadden@somdnews.com | Section: News 
 
 597
 Words 

 Read News Document

 It's a heavy issue and the document that the Calvert County public school system uses to enforce it is also ladened with weight. During the the county school board's May 22 work session, Cecelia Lewis, director of student services, presented summaries of the code of conduct and the significant changes that are proposed, including the use of AI.Lewis called the proposed references and policies related to artificial intelligence "a huge highlight this year. Technology continues to evolve."
The "added guidelines for use of artificial intelligence" cover "educational use, academic integrity, ethical use, supervision and monitoring and prohibited conduct."
The code's definition of "academic dishonesty/cheating" is proposed to now include "unauthorized use of digital or AI-generated materials, sharing of local, state or federal test information."
The drafters of the code of conduct's rewrite added "utilizing AI-generated content to harass, intimidate or bully any member of the school community" to the bullying, harassment and intimidation definition in the document's "levels of responses" section.
In a new section of the code entitled "responsible use of technology," there is a mandate listed on "avoiding plagiarism and AI misuse."
In addressing a question asked by Grace Minakowski, the outgoing student member of the board, on allowing for the citing of artificial intelligence and deciding what work might be plagiarism, Lewis said, "the teacher's determination" would be the big factor. She added that an artificial intelligence course for teachers "is being developed."
Board member Melissa Goshorn asked if artificial intelligence training for students is also being considered.
"That is on our radar," Lewis said. "It's something we are developing."
Lewis said the school system's instructional department's technology supervisors will be involved in developing the training for teachers and students.
Jackie Jacobs, chief academic officer, indicated classroom teachers will be giving students direction in the use of artificial intelligence and the extent of its use will be "dependent on what teachers are looking for."
In providing an overview on the code of conduct, Lewis told the board that many stakeholders contributed to the revisions, with a focus on assuring Calvert's public schools have a "safe, welcoming environment."
Much of the code is guided by state law, Lewis indicated during her presentation.
Other proposed changes include the addition of Safe Schools Maryland contact information. The free system is available to students, teachers, school staff members, parents and the general public "to report any school or student safety concerns, including mental health concerns."
Jana Post, school board president, called the work Lewis and the stakeholders did on revising the code "a humongous overhaul" and commended the group for its work.
The revised code will now be posted on the school system's website until late June for public review and comments.
High school theatre group lauded
A school organization used to receiving cheers and applause was showered with more accolades May 22 as the Patuxent High School Harlequins received a recognition from the school board.
The citation noted the group earned a superior rating at the 2025 Maryland Thespians Festival with their production of the one-act play "Everybody," by Brandon Jacobs-Jenkins. The Patuxent troupe earned the most superior scores at the recent festival.
"It's our tradition of unparalleled student leadership," Allen Price, Harlequins' production director, said after the citation was read and unanimously approved by the board. He added the program's long history of achievement was due to "student ownership" and "dedication to our program. The students care about the other students' successes."
Earlier this week, Price told Southern Maryland News that the Maryland State Department of Education is showcasing the Harlequins in a short documentary that focuses on the group's outstanding use of student leadership and student ownership to produce high quality shows.

title: Rocketeers explode onto the scene at nearby farm
author: WILL BONTRAGER wbontrager@chespub.com
content:
Rocketeers explode onto the scene at nearby farm

 May 28, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: WILL BONTRAGER wbontrager@chespub.com | Section: News 
 
 429
 Words 

 Read News Document

 CENTREVILLE — Over a mid-May weekend at Central Sod Farm, an H-130 rocket flew 1,000 feet through a cloudless sky, burning blue smoke before splitting apart.This was one of many rockets launched May 17 by hobbyists organized by The Maryland Delaware Rocketry Association Inc. following safety guidelines set by the FCC and the Tripoli Rocket Association.
While parachutes guided the nose and body of the H-130 downward, Yorktown Aerospace Club member Gavin La Rue watched his team's rocket's descent through a telescope.
The rest of the club members expressed excitement retrieving the rocket parts over the vast grassy landing zone.
"If you haven't noticed, there aren't many places in the city we can do this," club member Austin Humes said with a grin.
The launching activity at 920 John Brown Road, Centreville, is a learning opportunity for students in the Science Technology Engineering Mathematics field. Association Secretary David Kemp pointed out the rockets that day, large or small, use the same propellant as boosters on space shuttles.
Thanks to the organization's efforts, you do not need to be NASA trained to be a rocketeer.
For example, youth LaShawn Sudler watched his smaller rocket launch beside his step-grandfather, Mark Kraemer. It went 500-600 feet in the air, then released its chute at 200 feet.
A kid of few words, nonetheless Sudler showed pride in his rockets. Kraemer is passing his love of rocketry down to him and has fond memories of buying rocket kits when he was Sudler's age.
"These are just big boy toys," he said. "We love this stuff."
Over in another tent, friends Rich Custer and Erin Dawson from Northern Virginia showcased their rocket made from a fencepost and ceiling fan blades.
Under another tent, married couple Glenn and Adrienne Ramey shared how they even turned Christmas trees into rockets that when launched, spin the whole time.
On the grounds, there was just a handful of rocketeers in attendance, a smaller crowd since the American Rocketry Challenge was taking place in Virginia, said Fred Wallace, president of the association. Even though the conditions were a little windy, he had his high powered rocket with him just in case things calmed.
Although they were low in number that day, it offered a perfect opportunity to learn about the hobby.
That day, most landings were smooth although one rocket had a rough landing, the chute not deploying.
The association encourages all to come out to get their chance to be a rocketeer. People 18 and under fly for free. If you do not have a rocket, they have plenty to start you on your journey.
"Moms and dads, bring your kids," Wallace urged.

title: Mt. Aviat alumnae gather for first reunion in 40 years
author: Jane Bellmyer jbellmyer@cecilwlhig.com
content:
Mt. Aviat alumnae gather for first reunion in 40 years

 May 30, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Jane Bellmyer jbellmyer@cecilwlhig.com | Section: News 
 
 620
 Words 

 Read News Document

 It's been 40 years since these ladies gathered around to reminisce about their halcyon days at Mount Aviat Academy.They met at Schaefer's Canal House in Chesapeake City last month. Their last reunion was 40 years ago at The Swiss Inn in Elkton. (Now Mick's Crab House)
From 1960 until 1972 the school in the Childs area of Elkton was the only Catholic High School in Cecil County and it was a girls-only school for boarding and day students.
"I was in the first graduating class," said Barbara Ashton Johnson. "My last name started with an 'A' so I had to be first."
Having to be the first in line made the Philadelphia native nervous.
"I had to be the first to kneel before the bishop and kiss his ring," Johnson said of the long-ago experience.
Mount Aviat began with a group of Swiss nuns, in a program organized by local parents. The nuns came to the convent and organized the high school, which was led by Sister Francis Marguerite.
"She was idolized," said Eileen Stubbs Viars.
Sister Francis Marguerite was the stuff of legend, according to Alva Eldridge Dopp, who was a boarding student from Fredericktown, Md.
"When she was 19 she lived in Germany. She joined the Oblates and learned to be a nun in Italy," Dopp said of the revered nun. This was during the height of World War II. "The Germans invaded their convent and lined them all up and shot them. The bullets grazed her head and her knee. She fell and played dead."
Elizabeth "Betsy" Patterson Patterson referred to Sister Francis Marguerite as "the heart of the school."
Judy Schamme Hart meanwhile, remembered Father Naulty fondly.
"We give credit for our musical training to Father Naulty. He was our Glee Club director," Hart said, adding that now, 47 years later she continues to use those singing skills in the choir at Immaculate Conception Church in Elkton.
There was a lot of fun to be had, Alva Eldridge Dopp recalled, telling the story of a fellow classmate with a gift for elopement.
"Jewel DiDomenica planned an escape with sheets out the window," Dopp said. "Since I was the littlest they made me go down first. They figured they could hold the sheet."
Sister Mary Beth was waiting at the bottom.
"She said I was a girl once," Viars said. Although guilty as charged the sister meted out their payment less harshly.
For their punishment the young ladies had to clean all the floors at the school. In those days the uniform included clunky black shoes with heavy rubber soles that left a trail all over the floors.
"We were given little scraps of steel wool and we had to remove all the scuff marks off of the floor," Dopp said.
Those uniforms included long dark skirts below the knee, which flew in the face of the 1960s fashion trend of mini skirts. Judy Schamme Hart said she was not alone in fixing that when getting on the bus to go home each afternoon.
"As soon as we got off of school property the top of the skirt got rolled up," she said. In spite of the uniform and the rules, she said: "It was the best time of our lives."
By 1972, Mount Aviat was transitioning to a day school for children from kindergarten through 8th grade. Only nine classes graduated from Mount Aviat Academy's girls high school.
Whether the students lived on campus or went home each evening, all agreed they formed a camaraderie that lasts to this day.
"We came together for Catholic education," Patterson said. "But it wasn't just a Catholic education. It was an education in appreciating each other."
"But the camaraderie we had; relationships with girls not from your home town," Hart said. "We built this community. We had a lot of fun."

title: Easton, St. Michaels high schools celebrate graduates
author: Konner Metz
content:
Easton, St. Michaels high schools celebrate graduates

 May 30, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Konner Metz | Section: Local News 
 
 523

 Seniors at Easton High School and St. Michaels High School marked the end of a four-year chapter with graduation this week, celebrating accomplishments and looking forward to the future.On Wednesday, 291 graduated from Easton High. Talbot County Public Schools Superintendent Sharon Pepukayi said during her address to the class that the school's yearbook showed just how close students and faculty were during the last four years.
"What stood out the most were the connections I saw," Pepukayi said. "As I turned each page, I saw smiles, I saw groups of students clustered together. … I saw laughing, talking, joking taking place between the students, among students, in between staff and students."
Pepukayi emphasized to the graduates that creating those human connections is vital, especially in a world influenced by artificial intelligence.
"I read that Generation Z, who are the ages of 18 to 28, require a higher level of human connection, whether it's at home, at school, or in places of business," Pepukayi said. "Human connection. Now in the AI-driven world, this is of utmost importance. And that human connection is very evident in this class."
Easton High valedictorian Mia Mazzeo shared a similar theme in her speech.
"When all the information in the world is just a click away, take that extra step and dig deeper," Mazzeo said. "An eagerness to learn and an attentive teacher is all one really needs. It is only when you question how the world works that you can truly change it."
Mazzeo told her classmates that wisdom comes from interactions with one another.
"When I look back at my time in high school, I think I grew the most during late-night conversations with friends and after school chats with teachers," she said. "The experiences you share with others and the advice they have to offer is priceless."
ST. MICHAELS HIGH
On Thursday, 60 seniors at St. Michaels High School threw their caps in the air and joyously celebrated the achievement of being a newly-minted graduate.
Valedictorian Alexandria Rockwell said the Class of 2025 showed "incredible purpose" and encouraged her classmates to maintain that same drive as they go their separate ways.
Rockwell said the last four years tested and pushed the graduating class.
"As we entered high school, many challenges were thrown at us," she said. "Four years felt like forever. But now we're here. It's gone by in a flash, and it's bittersweet because we looked forward to this moment for so long, but now we know we're leaving behind something we'll never quite return to."
School principal Theresa Vener echoed that Thursday's graduation was bittersweet, bidding farewell to the graduating class she's been alongside since starting as St. Michaels Middle High School principal seven years ago.
Vener, retiring this year after 32 years working for the district, was presented with an honorary diploma at Thursday's ceremonies. Students, staff and district administrators thanked her for her dedication and leadership.
The outgoing principal said it was an "absolute privilege" to watch the Class of 2025 grow into caring and confident young adults.
"I have watched you fall, get back up and take those steps forward," Vener said. "One step at a time, but 'always forward,' just like your class motto says."

title: A day for children at the library
author: BILL PEAK Talbot County Free Library
content:
A day for children at the library

 May 30, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: BILL PEAK Talbot County Free Library | Section: Life 
 
 821
 Words 

 Read News Document

 When I was 3 years old, my parents told me there would soon be a new addition to our family, that my mother was going to have a baby.At that age, my two favorite things in the world were TV cowboys and Coca-Cola, which inspired me to come up with the perfect name for my new brother or sister. I began to declare confidently (and often) that we should name the child "Coco Bang-bang."
When my parents finally admitted they were thinking along different lines, maybe "Catherine" or "Robert," I began to have serious doubts about the whole enterprise.
For my entire life (which, at 3, stretched back toward infinity), I had been the center of Mom and Dad's world; the idea that I might now have to share their affections with some poorly named interloper rubbed me the wrong way.
I think my parents must have suspected my misgivings because about a month before the blessed event was to occur, they gave me a new picture book. I no longer remember the title of that tiny tome, but I do remember what it was about: a little boy, who looked a lot like me, was excited about the new baby his parents were about to bring home.
Actually, what I remember best about the book is a single illustration.
As I recall, it shows a scene that takes place immediately after the new addition to the family has arrived home from the hospital. The little boy sits on a couch. His parents have placed a pillow on his lap, and upon the pillow they have laid the child, its tiny hands lifted wonderingly toward the little boy's smiling face.
Immediately, the idea that I too might sit on our couch, a pillow on my lap, an infant lying upon it, took possession of my impressionable 3-year-old mind. And, as I recall, my parents wisely allowed me to realize that fantasy when my little sister Cathy finally did come home from the hospital.
I could be wrong, but it's my guess that picture book — whatever its title — probably saved my sister from a fair amount of brotherly pestering.
Which leads me, naturally enough, to the benefits accruing to children from books. On Saturday, June 7, from 10 a.m. to 2 p.m., come rain or shine, the Easton branch of the Talbot County Free Library will host the 10th annual Chesapeake Children's Book Festival.
This year's festival will feature 22 children's book authors and illustrators, all of whom underwent a rigorous vetting process before being selected to participate.
Children who sign up at the festival for the library's Summer Reading Program will receive a free cookie (while supplies last) imprinted with the festival's crab logo, courtesy of All in the Mix Bakeshop, and a voucher good for one free book (once again, while supplies last) from the attending author of their choice. It's always fun to see the pride children take in asking the author they've selected to sign the book they've received.
This year's festival will offer children some great books to choose from. Here's a small sampling of the many works that will be on display:
Danielle Joseph's young adult novel "Shrinking Violet" was adapted into the Disney Channel movie "Radio Rebel."
Colleen Kosinski's "A Home Again" is so popular, it's been translated into seven languages.
Trinka Hakes Noble's "The Day Jimmy's Boa Ate the Wash," (ALA Notable, PBS Reading Rainbow feature, American Book Award) has just celebrated its 45th year in print.
Jennifer O'Connell's beautifully illustrated picture books include "The Eye of the Whale," winner of the Green Earth Book Award, and The New York Times bestseller "Ten Timid Ghosts," which has sold more than a million copies.
And Timothy Young (who first conceived of the Chesapeake Children's Book Festival) has set his middle-grade chapter book "Mac and the Millstone of Time" at the Old Wye Mill in Wye Mills.
Traditionally, the festival resembles a small, library-sized carnival, designed to create a special day of fun for little ones. The Maryland State Opera Bears will be back for a return engagement this year, the Daughters of the American Revolution will offer crafts, the Judy Center will have their Make-A-Book table, the Master Gardeners will assure that Mother Nature provides an important part of the day's excitement, and Raising a Reader will set up a story walk.
Maryland Public Television, The Imagination Library, Radcliffe Creek School and Friends of the Library will also be on hand to keep the day entertaining.
The Friends of the Library are the primary sponsors of both the Festival and the Summer Reading Program. Other festival sponsors this year include Maryland Public Television, Easton Utilities, Talbot County Government, Talbot Arts and the Maryland State Arts Council.
All in all, the Talbot County Free Library's 10th annual Chesapeake Children's Book Festival should be a special day for children. And those parents out there thinking about bringing a new baby into the world can rejoice. The name "Coco Bang-bang" remains available for their consideration.

title: 'Green School' programs in Caroline County bring joy to students
author: AHMAD GARNETT agarnett@chesoub.com
content:
'Green School' programs in Caroline County bring joy to students

 May 31, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: AHMAD GARNETT agarnett@chesoub.com | Section: News 
 
 611
 Words 

 Read News Document

 DENTON — As of this year, Two Caroline County public schools have been certified as Green Schools by the Maryland Association for Environmental and Outdoor Education.Denton Elementary joined Greensboro Elementary in gaining the certification this year. Both schools went through a two-year application process through MAEOE to be come Green School certified.
Although directors for programs at the schools said the program was intense, they said the help they received from the community was surprising and made the process go much smoother.
"You have to work together, and we divided and conquered," said Julie Strange, pre-k teacher at and program coordinator for Green Schools at Denton Elementary. "You have to contact people at the board office. You have to contact contact your cafeteria. You have to contact people I didn't even know did jobs.
"It's an intense process, but again, eye-opening how helpful everybody was and that there are people for everything."
Within that application for the program there are different subcategories for which the schools must show evidence they met the objective.
The application also comes with a curriculum that must be completed by the students, and the school must provide one example of outdoor or environmental instruction per grade level.
"Through our curriculum and standards, we're able to teach these kids sustainability practices and how to take care of the Earth, just learning about the Earth through those environmental literacy standards. It's one of my passions. I really enjoy doing it," said Zellie Kneller Kidigarden, a teacher and program director for Green Schools at Greensboro Elementary.
Throughout the application process, the elementary schools have been able to produce multiple projects that help compost, save energy and grow fresh foods.
One project at Denton Elementary involves collecting breakfast bags in the morning after breakfast. According to Strange, the school lets third graders create boxes and put recycle signs on them to put in their classrooms to collect bags in the morning.
"Every day, we get breakfast in plastic bags per child, and our school is about 650 kids. So that's 650 bags that go in the trash every day," Strange said. "The kids were so excited about it, and they did it... the kids are responsible for putting their bag in there when they're done their breakfast instead of throwing it in the trash."
One of the projects Greensboro Elementary conducts is planting in multiple gardens.
"We do strawberries, herbs in our garden tower and then we have our pollinator garden. Our Environmental Club also planted native plants everywhere in our swales. Before the end of the school year, we're going to plant native plants in our courtyard," Kneller said.
Kneller credits community partners for being helpful in their pursuit to becoming a green school.
Some of the organizations Greensboro Elementary has partnered with are Pickering Creek Audubon Center, Chesapeake Bay Foundation, Tuckahoe State Park, Wetlands on Wheels and many more.
"I'm so grateful that we're a community school because being a community school allows us to work with... stakeholders in the community, and we get wonderful things from all the members in the community," Kneller said.
Greensboro Elementary has been a green school since 2021 and will go through a renewal next year. The school has been able to secure multiple grants that will lead to future projects, including tree planting and much more.
Both Kneller and Strange believe every school should be Green School certified.
"It's really, really, really important work and every school should be green school certified," Kneller said. "It is life-changing for a lot of students and adults and I would say everyone because this is the planet that we live on and everyone needs to learn how to take care of it because we don't have anywhere else to go."

title: Lockerman Middle School Committee heard and addressed concerns at second meeting
author: AHMAD GARNETT agarnett@chespub.com
content:
Lockerman Middle School Committee heard and addressed concerns at second meeting

 June 3, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: AHMAD GARNETT agarnett@chespub.com | Section: News 
 
 634
 Words 

 Read News Document

 DENTON — At the Lockerman Middle School Committee meeting Monday night, Robyn Toth, architect for the new Lockerman Middle School, confirmed that after the state's assessment, the current Lockerman Middle School building cannot be renovated, and the county will go with a new building."We've already reached out to the state and said the renovation of this existing facility as a school is not feasible," Toth said at the meeting. "It is my understanding that (the current school is) going to become a community center. So, this building is going to stay. It's going to keep its history."
Though it was never indicated as a preferred option, staying at the current site and renovating was left on the table at prior committee meetings and discussions on the new school.
The May meeting featured two potential locations for a new school, the first location would be behind North Caroline High School, and the second would be on Double Hills Road in Denton.
After a public hearing at that meeting, the committee came back with models and options for the school at two potential new locations.
"There was a lot of feedback last time about the safety issue for buses coming and going, as well as parent drop off," Superintendent Derek Simmons said. "So, I think the architect did the best they could with the two existing locations that the county has told us to look at to kind of make them as usable as possible."
The presentation given Monday premiered three building layout options for the North Caroline High location and two options for the Double Hills Road location.
The North Caroline High design options included two plans for a two-story style building with wings separated by grade level. Though these designs for the building itself are identical, the building is located in different places on the lot in each design.
One option proposes relocating the North Caroline High baseball and softball fields to a different location. The other keeps the middle school on the left and everything belonging to the high school on the right side of the property.
The third design option would also involve relocating the fields and would also relocate the solar array on the site. The existing barn and fenced pasture would also be rebuilt in a new location.
This third option is a three-story building design, with each floor being a different grade level.
"The different locations on North Carolina High School was interesting," Simmons said. "I think most of us in our heads ahead of time could envision it in one spot, but giving the flexibility of the options really opened up some some pathway."
The Double Hills Road location designs featured the two- and three-story options as at the North Caroline location.
While both options propose that the solar panels currently at the site may need to be located another portion of the county property and that new pump station will need to be constructed, entrance options, building locations and parking locations are different.
"Double Hills Road with the new county road going in in that property does preserve a 20 plus acre plot for to use," Simmons said. "It's good location but again it gives us that flexibility now to see what the buses would look like coming and going. What drop off would look like, what staff parking would look like because there's nowhere near enough staff parking here as well."
Now that the Lockerman Middle School Committee has presented all options, the public will have until before June 9 to respond to an online survey with their comments.

title: Trump wiped out 75 years of science leadership
author: LENA GILL
content:
Trump wiped out 75 years of science leadership

 June 7, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: LENA GILL | Section: Columns 
 
 770
 Words 

 Read News Document

 The U.S. higher educational system may in future years lose $38 billion a year. This is the estimated annual contribution by foreign students to the operation of that system. In the school year 2023-2024 it was estimated that 1.1 million foreign students were studying at universities across the U.S., and they generally pay full fare or do work/study. They also supported about 378,000 academic jobs. In the past the U.S. was a magnet for a global brain-drain of university and post-graduate students.Now we risk driving them away.
We have all heard about the graduate student Mahmoud Khalil, a Palestinian student from Syria, attending Columbia University and Rumeysa Ozturk, a Turkish female graduate student attending Tufts University. Both were grabbed by immigration authorities in the Northeast and sent to prisons in Louisiana awaiting outcomes of lawsuits filed on their behalf. They are both accused of peacefully protesting against the war in Gaza.
On April 19th CNN reported that thousands of international students across the country were informed by email that their student visas were revoked. Six days later the Trump administration decided to restore 1,400 student visas and let their lives go back to normal. How many students did not have their visas restored is unknown. We do know that Secretary of State Marco Rubio had a list of about 300 students that he planned to expel. The National Immigration Project is challenging the visa cancellations in court.
Apart from the money that these foreign students bring in, why would we care? Because foreign students began many of the successful startups in Silicon Valley. We care because much research in science done at our universities has brought the U.S. to a revered leadership position in the world in medical science research as well as research in other sciences. With a stroke of the president's pen this may all disappear. The best brains in the world will not want to come here anymore.
In the 20th century up to World War II, Germany won about 30% of the Nobel Prizes in science. The winner of the Nobel Prize in science is decided by a group of Swedish scientists. Alfred Nobel was a Swedish scientist who invented dynamite. His fortune funds all Nobel Prizes. The second runner-up was Great Britain with 20% of the Nobel Prizes in science. The U.S. was way down the list with only 6% of the Nobel Prizes in science.
What turned the tide was Adolf Hitler who drove many of the best German scientists, artists and architects (some of them Jewish) to U.S. universities in the 1930s, where they were welcomed. The second German brain drain happened immediately after the war when U.S. intelligence invited physicists like Wernher von Braun (inventor of the German rockets) to the U.S. to work for the space program. World War II destroyed much of Germany and devastated Great Britain and France. The Soviet Union lost nearly 24 million people in that war, while the U.S. emerged from the war economically, technologically and militarily better than the rest of the world.
What really propelled the U.S. into a leadership position was the futuristic vision of what could come, if the U.S. government funded basic research at universities small and large around the country with a promise to keep the government's hands off. The academic freedom and competition created by this decision attracted the best brains from around the world.
Since 2000 the U.S. has won 72 Nobel Prizes in science, of which about 30% were won by immigrants. Great Britain won 16, Germany 7, France 5, Japan 9, Israel 5. Canada, Australia and Norway won three each. China is gaining ground.
This rosy picture will change fast if the Trump administration continues to threaten leading universities with withdrawal of funds and academic freedom. Harvard University, which so far has not backed down, was threatened with withdrawal of their not-for-profit designation, which would make any charitable donations taxable. Foreign students' and researchers' visas are being revoked. Foreigners are being harassed at U.S. entry points and their phones searched for anti-Trump emails.
The Trump administration is now threatening withdrawal of funds from our world-renowned science research facilities, The National Science Foundation, established in 1950, and the National Institutes of Health, established much earlier. A science publication asked its readers if they were affected by government harassment and withdrawal of funds. If so, were they considering moving their research elsewhere? 75% of the 1,600 who responded said they were considering it.
With a stroke of the president's pen, we have lost 75 years of leadership in the sciences.
California, Texas, Illinois, Massachusetts, and New York will see the most economic impact, but Maryland will also suffer.

title: Suicide of a superpower
author: Staff Writer
content:
Suicide of a superpower

 June 14, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Staff Writer | Section: Editors Inbox

 Words

 I'm not sure that it's clear to everyone that one of Trump's cost-cutting measures is doing serious damage to our military power."Suicide of a superpower" is underway, to quote Max Boot in a recent Washington Post column.
Trump's attack on universities and other government-funded research programs is surrendering America's most powerful weapon, our scientific ability. With the help of scientists from abroad (immigrants like Einstein who spent the rest of his career as a physics professor at Princeton), the University of Chicago, Columbia, and Berkeley were major players in developing the atomic bomb that made us a superpower in the first place.
Not only have our scientists given us satellite radio, smart phones and the internet, which we rely on in Talbot County, they have also given us missile shields, drones and other smart weapons. Future conflicts will be fought with high-tech systems — not yesterday's weapons — and we must keep up with their development.
I can understand a certain amount of animosity toward the stereotype professor or scientist, but I can't understand why one would want to harm our research programs and universities, which are the envy of the world. We need to urge Andy Harris and other Eastern Shore leaders to push back against Trump's terrible mistake.
