title: State test scores: Mid-Shore school districts see mixed results
author: Konner Metz
content:
State test scores: Mid-Shore school districts see mixed results

 August 26, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Konner Metz | Section: Local News 
 
 694
 Words 

 Read News Document

 The Maryland Department of Education released English and math test scores Aug. 26, revealing a major jump for one Mid-Shore school district and mixed results for others.Test results from the 2024-2025 Maryland Comprehensive Assessment Program, or MCAP, show that statewide, students made slight gains in both subjects. English proficiency is at 50.8%, up from 48.4% the previous year. Math proficiency is at 26.5%, up from 24.1% last year.
The Mid-Shore's five counties — Caroline, Dorchester, Kent, Queen Anne's and Talbot — didn't always follow those state trends.
In English, Dorchester County outpaced all other counties in year-to-year gains. Dorchester's English proficiency saw the largest increase statewide — up 7.6% to a 41.3% proficiency rate, which ranks Dorchester 19th of 24 districts.
Dorchester Superintendent Jymil Thompson said in a press release that the improvement is a sign the district's work to climb the state rankings is paying off.
"These results show that belief leads to action — and action leads to results," Thompson said. " ... Today, we can proudly say Dorchester is on the rise."
Caroline tied for the fifth highest year-to-year improvement in English proficiency at 3.5%. The district's new English proficiency rate of 49% now ranks it 14th in the state.
Meanwhile, Kent, Queen Anne's and Talbot counties were three of only four districts in Maryland with lower English proficiency rates than last year.
Queen Anne's is still above the state average at 57% proficient, ranking ninth despite a 1.5% drop. Kent dropped 0.5% to 40.7% proficiency, ranking the district 20th statewide.
Talbot is 16th in the state with a 45.4% proficiency rate after a 1.9% year-to-year decrease, the largest decrease in the state. In a statement, Talbot County Public Schools Director of Communications Debbie Gardner said the district is in the process of analyzing MCAP data and will make a presentation to the Board of Education in September.
PROGRESS IN MATH
All 23 counties and Baltimore City are seeing progress in math. No district decreased in its math score from 2023-2024, and over a quarter of Maryland students are proficient in the subject.
Dorchester, again, saw the biggest hike of the Mid-Shore counties at 4.1%. The county is still just 20th statewide at 16.4% proficient. Kent follows at 21st with a 16.3% rate, up 3.7% from last year.
Kent County Superintendent Mary Boswell-McComas said in a statement that the district has worked on professionally developing school principals in math.
"We're seeing the payoff in how our principals coached teachers in developing students' mathematical reasoning and how our teachers incorporated that in their classrooms," the statement read.
Queen Anne's remains the Mid-Shore county most proficient in math at 31.6%, a 2.9% hike from one year ago. The district ranks eighth in the state.
Caroline jumped 2.5% to hit 22.2% proficiency, which ranks the district 15th.
Caroline Superintendent Derek Simmons wrote in a statement that he's "very encouraged" to see the district's growth rate outpace the state's.
"Our sustained focus on what matters, and consistency around evidence-based approaches will continue our growth," Simmons wrote.
Talbot math proficiency remained almost even, going up 0.6% to 18.9% this year. The district ranks 18th in proficiency. Only two other districts had year-to-year changes worse than Talbot.
UP AND DOWN IN SCIENCE
Proficiency rates from the fifth and eighth grade science tests show Queen Anne's schools are well above the rest of the five Mid-Shore counties. In fifth grade, Queen Anne's is 10th of 24 districts with 29.3% proficiency, according to data on the Maryland Report Card.
But Talbot saw the state's second-highest yearly increase, climbing 5.9% to 22.8% and 15th overall.
Kent comes in at 16th in fifth grade science at 20.9%. Caroline is 18th with 19% and Dorchester is 20th with 17.4%.
In eighth grade science, Queen Anne's lost its first-place ranking from last year as other districts made significant jumps. But the county is still third in the state at 44.3%, down slightly from last year.
Caroline's eighth graders were 16th in the state at 23.8%, a 4.5% jump. Dorchester increased by 4.6% to 19.9% proficiency, landing it at 18th.
Talbot tied with Queen Anne's for the worst year-to-year change at -0.8%. It is ranked 19th now with 19.3% of eighth graders proficient on the science test.
Kent comes in at 16.8% proficiency, up from 13.4% last year.ENGLISH SCORES

title: Cellphone pouches are back in Caroline County middle schools
author: AHMAD GARNETT agarnett@chespub.com
content:
Cellphone pouches are back in Caroline County middle schools

 August 29, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: AHMAD GARNETT agarnett@chespub.com | Section: News 
 
 352
 Words

 DENTON — Caroline County Public Schools will be bringing back cellphone pouches in middle schools for the second year.Cellphone pouches were introduced in the 2024-25 school year as a pilot program aimed at keeping students off their phones. Students carry locked pouches during the entire school day, with their phones inside and not accessible.
Each student has their own pouch, which travels with them daily from home to school. Phones are locked into the pouches at the beginning of the school day and unlocked at the end using a magnetic device. If a student leaves the pouch at home, they put their phone in the school office for the day.
According to CCPS, year one of the pilot program was a success.
"We saw it was a good first year with it," said Caroline County Superintendent Derek Simmons.
"The recommendation ... the board accepted was to give it another year at our middle schools. One year does not mean a trend. We saw good good results, but we want to track it for another year before we make any determinations about if we were to move it forward to the high school level."
The cellphone pouches were created by the company Yondr and were tested in both Caroline County middle schools last school year.
During the June Caroline County Board of Education meeting, district staff presented statistics for the school year. Compared to the year prior, CCPS saw 30.6% fewer referrals last school year, with 130 fewer attacks, threats or fights and about 200 fewer instances of disrespect and disruptions.
According to Simmons, student and parents have been receptive of the cellphone pouches.
"Last year it was minimal resistance," Simmons said. "You bring in something new, people are going to have some concern. They ask questions, administrators at the building level handle the questions really well. By and large, everything went well with compliance. It's funny, we've had hardly any asks this year going in the middle because it just has become the expectation."
After one more school year at the middle school level, CCPS will revisit the topic and potentially incorporate the cellphone pouches to the high school level.

title: Dorchester schools climb in state rankings after first year of ambitious reform plan
author: Lily Tierney
content:
Dorchester schools climb in state rankings after first year of ambitious reform plan

 August 29, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Lily Tierney | Section: Dorchester 
 
 509
 Words 

 Read News Document

 Last year, Dorchester County Public Schools Superintendent Jymil Thompson set out on a mission to change the school district's current ranking of 23rd out of 24 in the overall Maryland Comprehensive Assessment Program evaluations. A year later, the results are in, and they look promising.The "23, no more" initiative is a three-year plan to move DCPS from the 23rd spot to 15th. Testing data released by the state this week shows the county has successfully moved up two spots overall, and it improved from 23rd to 19th in English Learning Arts proficiency.
While DCPS' climb in the rankings may not be massive, district leaders say it shows notable progress.
"So we looked at the numbers as to what it would take for us to get to the middle of the pack, and we said, 'Okay, 15. If we move this amount of kids every year, we can at least get to 15. And then if we go higher than 15, that will be just added bonus,'" Thompson said.
The superintendent said key strategies to get to 15 include setting a clear vision, conducting quarterly walkthroughs, focusing on instruction, rallying the team around a goal, supporting teachers, differentiating learning, simplifying processes and putting structures and systems in place.
The district's strategic plan, called "Believe in Us," guides these efforts and emphasizes core values such as joy, putting children first and accountability. This plan has four key priorities: advance academics, optimize operations, pursue partnerships and cultivate conversations.
For Thompson, it is crucial that the community outside of the school system is involved in this process for it to work.
"I think that education is a community issue because I don't think there will be one person that would say that they don't want kids to be educated," Thompson said. "That's the emphasis, that's the nucleus, right there. Everyone wants kids to be educated, so it's everyone's responsibility to ensure that the kids are being educated, not just the school system."
Thompson hopes the school system can act as a catalyst for countywide transformation through incremental progress and innovation.
Efforts are underway to recruit more certified teachers and administrators to improve the attractiveness of Dorchester County Public Schools to parents and families in the area.
Though these early results are promising, Thompson knows there will still be challenges to accomplish his ambitious goal. He said these do not deter him. "There's no challenges that I don't think we can overcome as a district and community working collectively together that can be a hindrance for us to move to 15," he said.
As long as community members are willing to come up with creative solutions, Thompson firmly believes that there is no challenge they won't be able to overcome.
"We're not turning anybody away and we want everyone to be involved in the process because I think at the end of the three year journey, I think people will be happy about our progress as a school system," Thompson said. "But I don't want them to be happy as innocent bystanders. I want them to be happy as active participants in the process."

title: Country Cooking: Welcome back to school and school lunches
author: MARIE SAVAGE Country Cooking
content:
Country Cooking: Welcome back to school and school lunches

 September 9, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: MARIE SAVAGE Country Cooking | Section: Food 
 
 1428
 Words 

 Read News Document

 School bells ringing, doors open, buses pulling up, teachers and other staff waiting for the students to walk the path to enter the building. Over in the "car riders" lane, the parents are assured the kids will have a great day.This all seems familiar, doesn't it? No matter how old your children, grandchildren, great grandchildren or other children may be, this scenario has occurred for decades.
Watching the children in their new school attire, including new shoes, reminds me of my young elementary school days back in Bishopville. On the first day of school, we were waiting for the bus quite uncomfortable in new clothes with the tags freshly cut off. Posture was not a problem — store starch was even worse than Mom's cooked starch. Y'all remember that Argo starch mess.
In a future column, I will include "them new stiff school shoes."
Now, to the lunch boxes. Breakfast was very important on a school morning because the next meal seemed to be "hours" away if you had nothing for breakfast. On a winter morning, there was always a freshly cooked pot of oatmeal or cream of wheat.
If we got up early enough, there could be scrambled eggs, and scrapple or sausage, and/or toast. Suddenly the yell came — "Bus is coming." We grabbed the lunch boxes and out the door we flew.
We all had the same packed lunch so you could not grab the wrong one.
Then came the '60s with those special lunch boxes — Roy Rogers, Lone Ranger, Hop-Along-Cassidy, Cinderella, Alice in Wonderland and many more. My late younger brother would tell you the boxes were made from metal and tin — because I would hit him with mine, so he really did know.
A great occurrence has happened with school lunches — most counties have free school lunches for all students regardless of income. This was long overdue, as buying lunch foods to pack is expensive.
However, many of us have that child or grandchild who insists on a packed lunch. Let us explore foods that are convenient and not very expensive to purchase.
Walking through the grocery store, I see such a variety of foods that kids love. Let's go back to the '50s lunch box and see what we find — a sour pickle wrapped in foil, chunks of sharp cheddar cheese, several crackers — white or Ritz, a bologna and cheese sandwich, leftover chicken wings or legs from supper the night before, or the popular peanut butter and jelly sandwich.
Then comes my children going to school in the 1970s and 1980s. School cafeterias had changed greatly by this time. In middle school, there was a jukebox, round tables as well as the long style, and a "huge" change in school food. Some lunches were spaghetti with meatballs, garlic bread and a salad. There were submarines with small bags of chips, and the ever popular "a la carte" foods. You could purchase candy bars, ice cream, individual sandwiches and add a bowl of soup. Lunch boxes turned into lunch bags or insulated bags. The change was good — and the staff size grew immensely.
At this point, I need to say "hat's off" to the food staff in every school district in every state. Your jobs are very necessary to help the school day be enjoyable for everyone.
Packed lunches in the '80s and '90s included foods like beef jerky, cheese sticks, hot chips and pop-top cans of soups. Lunch had very few sandwiches, as students would buy lunch on "pizza days" and "taco days."
Schools started serving breakfast, lunch and afternoon snacks. What a wonderful addition to our school systems for our most precious and valuable assets to our country.
Now, we are exploring school lunches from 2000 to 2025. There seems to have been a rise in allergens such as peanuts, gluten and dairy in 2025 that makes it more difficult to get a big variety of food on the menus. Most schools are now offering two or three different lunch choices and that ever so popular a la carte menu.
As I close this column today, I realize going back in time brings back so many memories of my school years. Some mornings are calm; others feel like a race against the clock. On the busiest days, a few shortcuts keep me sane. I keep a "lunchbox basket" in the pantry filled with pre-portioned snacks like trail mix, whole grain crackers, or fruit leather, so I can grab and pack without digging. In the fridge, washed and sliced produce goes into small containers or bento compartments right after grocery shopping, so it's ready to drop into the lunchbox.
A community park is now in the spot where Bishopville Elementary School once stood. The playground area is still there, thankfully. As I look at where the school once stood, I am flooded with memories. No matter what type of lunch bag or box you carried. No matter what kind of biscuit or bread you used and no matter what kind of filling was on that sandwich — we were all the same children from a small town.
Let's see what is on the menu for packed lunch. Here are a few recipes from my back-to-school column last year.
BBQ CHICKEN CUPS
1 roll of Pillsbury Grands biscuits (usually the Southern style works best but you can use any flavor your child likes), 3 lbs chicken breast, 1 cup chicken broth, 1 tsp salt, 1 tsp pepper, 1 tsp garlic powder, 1 tsp onion powder, barbecue sauce.
Place chicken breasts in the bottom of the crockpot. Pour chicken broth and seasonings over chicken. Cook on low for 6-8 hours or high for 3-4 hours. Remove chicken from the crockpot and shred with two forks. Mix with your favorite barbecue or hot sauce. Bake the biscuits according to directions, then immediately when they are done tear a biscuit in half and flatten it, place it into a muffin tin, top with chicken and shredded cheese, and bake at 350 degrees for 15-20 minutes.
PB&J APPLES
2 apples, 1/4 cup peanut butter, 1/4 cup jelly.
Slice apples into ¼-inch rounds. Use a small cookie cutter to cut the core from the center of each slice. Spread peanut butter on jelly on half of the slices then cover with the remaining halves. This is one that you'll want to make in the morning so the apples don't brown overnight.
PB&J SUSHI
4 slices white bread, 1/2 cup smooth peanut butter, 1/2 cup grape jelly.
Remove crusts from bread. Using a rolling pin, roll bread until very flat. Spread with peanut butter and jelly and roll tightly. Cut into 2-inch pieces and serve.
PICKLE ROLL UPS
4 slices of your child's favorite lunch meat, mustard or mayo, cheese, pickle wedge.
Spread mustard or mayo on the slices of meat, layer some cheese then another layer of meat. Roll a pickle wedge up and pack tight. You can use any variety of meat, cheese or condiments in this dish.
TURKEY CLUB ROLL UPS
4 slices deli turkey, 2 tsp mayo, 2 slices cheddar (halved or quartered), 1/2 cup shredded or chopped lettuce, 1/2 tomato (sliced), 1/4 red onion (thinly sliced), 1/2 avocado (sliced), 4 slices cooked bacon, kosher salt, freshly ground black pepper.
On a clean work surface, place two slices of deli turkey and spread a thin layer of mayo on top. Top with 1 slice cheddar, half of the lettuce, tomato, red onion and avocado, and 2 slices bacon. Season generously with salt and pepper. Roll up and secure with a toothpick, then repeat with remaining ingredients.
GRILLED CHEESE ROLL UPS
8 thick slices of soft white bread, 1.5 cups finely grated cheddar, 2 tbsp melted butter.
One by one, slice the crusts off of each slice of bread, then use a rolling pin to flatten. Add a pinch of cheese to each slice, making sure you leave a small strip at the end to brush with butter. Tightly but carefully roll up each slice to the end, brush with butter, then roll shut and place seam-side-down. Brush all over with butter. Add roll ups to a dry pan seam-side-down over low-medium heat and fry until golden all over with the cheese starting to leak out. Use your tongs to frequently turn them. You may need to do this in two batches depending on the size of your pan.
NUTELLA BANANA SUSHI
This recipe is by the single serving, so repeat as many times as you need.
Nutella, 1 banana, 1 whole wheat wrap.
Lay your wrap on a breadboard and slather with Nutella, Place the banana on top of your chocolate coating, Roll the wrap as you would sushi or a burrito and carefully slice into rolls.

 DENTON — New bathrooms are coming to the North Caroline High School and Colonel Richardson High School outdoor athletic facilities.The project has been in the works since March of 2024, when Caroline County Commissioners President Travis Breeding and Caroline County Public Schools Director of Operations Bill Mengel worked together to make the bathrooms a priority.
The commissioners included the new bathrooms in the county's fiscal year 2025 budget.
"We had noticed in attending various high school sporting events that we only had Porta Johns, and we didn't have any place for people to wash their hands or you get out of colder temperatures and that kind of stuff when they were going to the restroom," Breeding said.
"We thought that pretty much all the surrounding jurisdictions had facilities at their sporting events, and we wanted to make sure that our students, parent and visitor attendees at sporting events had good bathing facilities to use at our high schools," Breeding said.
Caroline County Public Schools Superintendent Derek Simmons said in a statement that the restrooms will "greatly enhance the experience for students and community members alike as they support our athletic events."
"We sincerely appreciate the Caroline County Commissioners for making new bathrooms at the high school stadiums possible," Simmons said.
After the commissioners budgeted for the new bathrooms, Robin Eaton, public works director for Caroline County, began to go through the process of purchasing equipment for the new bathrooms and work with an engineering team on the design.
For North Caroline High School, Eaton said the new bathrooms facilities will have men's and women's sides with three toilets each.
At Colonel Richardson, the new bathrooms will feature men's and women's sides with two toilets each.
The bathrooms are placed near the baseball and football fields at both high schools, so they will be available for fall, winter and spring sports.
Eaton who has coached at both high schools for more than two decades, said he is excited to have the new bathrooms coming into Caroline County high schools.

title: Gen Z’s lessons on Sept. 11: A generation raised in its shadow calls for deeper lessons
author: ADDISON NOGAR
content:
Gen Z’s lessons on Sept. 11: A generation raised in its shadow calls for deeper lessons

 September 16, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: ADDISON NOGAR | Section: News 
 
 518
 Words 

 Read News Document

 Addison Nogar is a junior at Kent Island High School and contributing writer this semester.In high school today, Sept. 11 is not often taught in detail. Some history teachers mention it briefly, but rarely explore the full impact.
Growing up in the shadow of Sept. 11, piecing together fragmented narratives from stories, documentaries and secondhand accounts, I never fully grasped the enormity of that day until I stood at the 9/11 Memorial — a member of the generation that inherited its aftermath.
My first realization of the tragedy came while eating dinner in 2013. My mom turned on the movie World Trade Center. The graphic image of a man dying under debris was the first thing I saw. I watched the entire film but never again. For years, I looked for it to come on again, but the only outlets covering Sept. 11 were news sources. After that, every year I hoped to learn and hear more stories and perspectives from that day.
The one lesson that stayed with me came from my fifth grade teacher. Most people aren't aware of the story of the Red Bandana Man. I wasn't either until she played a video. Welles Crowther, a 24-year-old volunteer firefighter, lost his life that day. He had played lacrosse at Boston College while studying economics, later finding a job in the South Tower of the World Trade Center.
He wore a red bandana under his helmet while playing lacrosse, a gift from his father when he was younger. Crowther saved more than 18 lives on the seventh floor, carrying injured people down the stairs. He covered their faces with the red bandana to help them breathe through the smoke.
Crowther made one more trip into the building before it collapsed. He never made it back out. Today he is remembered as the Red Bandana Man — a symbol of courage, compassion and selflessness. Thank you to my fifth grade teacher for sharing his inspiring and heroic act.
On April 22, 2023, I visited the National September 11 Memorial and Museum. Reflecting on the names etched on the wall and the site where the twin structures once stood, it was surreal to grasp the transformation over the past two decades.
I took a 90-minute tour of the museum and memorial. The indoor and outdoor experience examined what happened on Sept. 11, explored the history and rebuilding of the site, and highlighted the stories of those affected by the attacks.
The most memorable part was the Survivor Tree — a Callery pear tree that survived the attacks. Severely damaged, it was discovered at ground zero and later removed by the New York City Department. After recovery, the tree returned to the memorial in 2010. New smooth limbs grew from the stumps, showing the connection between the tree's past and present. It now stands as a living reminder of resilience, survival and rebirth.
Sept. 11 deserves our deepest respect and appreciation. Now that we're old enough to grasp the tragedy more fully, it's fitting for teachers to dedicate time to discuss it — sharing narratives from that day and honoring the moment of silence it has earned.

title: Girls lose gains in math and science post-pandemic
author: Lily Tierney
content:
Girls lose gains in math and science post-pandemic

 September 17, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Lily Tierney | Section: Headlines 
 
 894
 Words 

 Read News Document

 Recent data from the Stanford Education Data Archive and the National Center for Education Statistics revealed that girls were making major gains in subjects like math and science before the pandemic. Since, the national trend shows girls declining in these areas at a faster rate than boys.Maryland experienced one of the largest drops in girls' math scores compared with boys'. Between 2019 and 2024, girls fell behind, on average, the equivalent of 49% of a grade level more than boys, according to data analysis from The Associated Press.
"There's a lot of cyclical things happening in education," Maryland's 4-H STEM specialist Mark DeMorra said. "It's kind of like a pendulum in the fact that we swung so far to one side."
Girls on Maryland's Eastern Shore were no exception to the decline in math skills. Talbot, Caroline and Dorchester County all followed this trend, but some districts stood out more than others.
The study compared 2023 National Assessment of Educational Progress test results to the 2019 national average. The results represented grade levels three through eight. A score of 5.5 is equivalent to the national average in 2019. Each whole point represents the equivalent of a grade level.
In Maryland, girls declined 0.92 points, almost an entire grade level, while boys dropped 0.47.
Prior to the pandemic, girls throughout the country were outperforming boys in math and science on average. But AP's analysis found that in 2023, boys outperformed girls in nine out of every 10 school districts.
This was the case in Talbot County, where prior to the pandemic, girls were outperforming boys by 0.24 points. In the 2023-24 school year, boys outperformed girls by 0.17 points.
But girls still outperformed boys in two Mid-Shore districts. In Caroline County, girls scored a 4.51 in 2023-24 while boys scored a 4.44. In Dorchester County, girls scored a 3.14 while boys scored a 2.95.
Dorchester County saw the worst decline of the three counties, with girls dropping 1.05 points, while boys dropped 0.85 points. In Caroline County, girls declined by 1.18 points while boys dropped 0.81 points. Talbot County saw girls declining by 0.96 points and boys by 0.55.
According to the Stanford Education Data Archive, no districts in Maryland have fully recovered their pre-2019 math levels.
The Star Democrat provided the data to local school districts two weeks ago. Talbot County Public Schools and Caroline County Public Schools did not respond to The Star Democrat's requests for comment. District representatives from those two districts requested specific questions, which were provided but not answered.
Dorchester County started at a lower baseline than the other two Mid-Shore counties, falling well below Maryland's state average. Comparing Dorchester County to the average found in the study, both boys and girls are roughly 2 to 2½ grade levels behind in math.
The district's Assistant Superintendent of Academics and Student Services, Jodi Coleman, wrote in an email to The Star Democrat: "While our girls' math scores dipped slightly more than boys' since the pandemic, the overall gap between genders is small. Both groups showed similar trends, and our overall performance has remained fairly consistent with pre-COVID results."
Dorchester County is working to make gains across the board with its "23 no more" initiative. The initiative aims to move Dorchester County Public Schools from 23 out of 23 counties in the state to 15th.
One year after the initiative was introduced, the county has successfully moved up two spots overall in the state rankings and improved from 23 to 19 in English learning arts and from 23 to 20 in math.
"The larger issue is that most of our students — girls and boys — are not yet proficient, which is why our 'Believe in Us: Advancing Our Potential Together' strategic plan focuses on improving achievement for all learners. Addressing any gender differences is embedded in that broader effort," Coleman wrote.
Dorchester schools are zeroing in on teacher training, small-group math support and expanded STEM opportunities, while also boosting dual enrollment and career pathways for female students. Coleman says these steps aim to close learning gaps and raise math and reading achievement.
Coleman wrote that Dorchester is seeing early signs of success.
"Preliminary benchmark data suggest stabilizing math scores for both genders. Schools reintroducing environmental literacy trips, small-group tutoring and STEM enrichment last spring noted increased engagement," Coleman wrote.
Girls' enrollment in advanced math and science are returning to pre-2019 levels, according to Coleman. Some extracurricular programs, like robotics and coding clubs, are still rebuilding but trending upward.
Coleman wrote that opportunities were affected by in-person restrictions during the pandemic. Hands-on enrichment like robotics, STEM field trips and some environmental experiences were paused or scaled back. This was the case for many school districts.
DeMorra, the 4-H STEM specialist, said framing math and science in an approachable and inclusive way is critical to engage students, particularly girls.
The core philosophy of 4-H is "learning by doing." DeMorra said hands-on STEM activities help students, especially those who don't self-identify as "STEM people," realize they are already using math and science through applied projects.
Maryland 4-H partners with schools and community organizations to fill some of the hands-on learning gaps, DeMorra said. However, he said it is critical for all educators to work together.
"We all have the same basic goal. We should helping each other. And that's in general for 4-H too. We are trying to help each other and continue to do the best that we can for our children, our future," he said.

title: Easton, St. Michaels victorious in 1st ever Mid-Shore Constitution Bowl
author: Konner Metz
content:
Easton, St. Michaels victorious in 1st ever Mid-Shore Constitution Bowl

 September 22, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Konner Metz | Section: Local News 
 
 553
 Words 

 Read News Document

 EASTON — High school students squared off in the inaugural Mid-Shore Constitution Bowl on Saturday, putting their knowledge about one of the nation's framework documents to the test.Hosted by the Mid-Shore Constitution Alliance at the Talbot County Free Library, five high schools from around the area entered: Easton and North Caroline in the large division; and St. Michaels, Sts. Peter & Paul and The Gunston School in the small division.
Students from Easton and St. Michaels claimed victory in the hard-fought matches, tackling questions on the amendments, Congress, government-related vocabulary and more.
In a close race in the small division, St. Michaels erased a 10-point deficit by correctly answering the last prompt of the contest: a question on the 20th Amendment, also known as the Lame Duck Amendment, which moved term start dates for the president, vice president and members of Congress up to January.
"We just wanted to represent our school, prove that we were the best," senior Sebastian Cornish said.
The four St. Michaels students attributed their victory to James Kunz, their former AP Government teacher. They said taking his AP class two years ago prepared them for the competition. Some last-minute practice during lunch this year helped, too.
"He let us know about it briefly last year, and it came up again at the beginning of the school year, and we were like, 'We're all still down to do it,'" senior Tyler Murphy said.
Kunz and other teachers, along with family and friends, watched from the crowd in what became an especially competitive environment inside the library's side room.
Students hovered their hands over the answer bell as questions were read aloud in a race to acquire as many points as possible. Wrong answers resulted in deductions.
Easton High School's Constitution Bowl team took down North Caroline High School in Saturday's first match. By scoring the most points across both divisions, Easton High secured the grand prize, which included a plaque and a copy of the U.S. Constitution. Easton's four members signed the Constitution and will take it back to their school.
The event was hosted by the Mid-Shore Constitution Alliance — led by Richard Holman, Michelle Ewing and Julie Quick — in conjunction with the Colonel Tench Tilghman Chapter of the Sons of the American Revolution. It capped off a string of events held during Constitution Week from Sept. 14 to 20.
After the competition concluded, Wes Hagood, president of the Tench Tilghman chapter, thanked the students and families for attending.
"Participation today by all of our competitors really restores my faith in the youth of America," Hagood said.
Members of the winning St. Michaels team said they encourage younger students to participate in the future or learn more about the Constitution itself.
"Even if they don't really know about it, I'd encourage them to come watch," senior Brody McDaniel said. "It teaches them a lot about government and the Constitution."

title: Queen Anne's denies charter school application
author: ANDREA GRABENSTEIN agrabenstein@chespub.com
content:
Queen Anne's denies charter school application

 September 22, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: ANDREA GRABENSTEIN agrabenstein@chespub.com | Section: Local News 
 
 896
 Words 

 Read News Document

 CENTREVILLE — In a 3-2 vote, the Queen Anne's County Public Schools Board of Education voted to uphold the superintendent's recommendation and deny application for what would have been the first classical charter school in Queen Anne's County Sept. 10.Presenting a final report and an overview of the Queen Anne's County Public Schools Charter School Application Review Committee process, charter school liaison and supervisor of instruction Micheal Bell said the committee recommended denial of the Queen Anne's County Classical Charter School application Sept. 3, "due to significant and substantiated deficiencies in academic planning, operational capacity, and demonstrated need."
According to Bell, "the application lacked evidence of innovation, financial and governance readiness, and failed to articulate how it would meet the diverse needs of Queen Anne's County students."
The extensive review process is aligned with Maryland Charter Law, the Code of Maryland Regulations, and precedents established through the Maryland State Board of Education guidance, he said.
Noting the district had not received the in-depth responses necessary, Interim Superintendent Matthew Kibler's recommendation mirrored the Committees citing "major gaps remained despite multiple opportunities to cure deficiencies," including: insufficient evidence of operational readiness, staffing, and facility acquisition planning; a pre-K program plan that is not feasible without Maryland Accreditation and EXCELS Level 4 status; financial assumptions that lack contingency planning for enrollment shortfalls, grant delays, or facility overruns; limited and underdeveloped plans for serving students with disabilities, English learners, and other student groups and an instructional program that remains underdeveloped and not adequately aligned with Maryland College and Career Ready Standards.
The committee acknowledged the charter school's group enthusiasm for the classical charter model, timely responsiveness in communication, and a strong commitment to the idea of school choice, Bell said.
"But the team also noted authorizing a charter school is not simply about approving an idea, it's about assuming full responsibility for students, staff, and the community under our umbrella," Bell said, a level of responsibility that requires readiness, compliance, and sustainability, "none of which were determined to be sufficiently demonstrated within their application."
Following the turbulent meeting Sept. 3 filled with heated discussions in the face of the application's proposed denial, the Queen Anne's County Classical Charter School group returned to the Board Sept 10. to present answer questions and allow for an in depth application review for the Board's decision.
Lead by a Board of Directors with expertise of former teachers and education professionals, the motivation to establish the classical charter school arose to provide options to parents and enhance the current system upon seeing current dropping proficiency rates, founder Audrey Scott said.
Charter Committee Board of Directors President Ashley MacLeay noted that although seeking autonomy through waivers, the proposed classical charter school would ultimately be a public school part of the QACPS system that the Board of Education would oversee.
Student enrollment would be based on a lottery system.
The charter committee claimed it was not afforded opportunities for collaboration and was provided little assistance in certain application aspects, like identifying facilities.
If approved by the Board of Education, the charter school would continually seek collaboration with QACPS in establishing a charter agreement, as "one holistic school system," she said.
To start, the charter school would need six teachers and has already received far more resumes than that of interested teachers, Scott said.
The group claimed interest has been overwhelmingly positive from the community including partners like the Giving the Edge Foundation and letters of support from the Queen Anne's County Commissioners.
While not initiated yet, the committee received support from the county to direct mail to every county home to serve as a first general introduction to parents, Scott said.
While letters of support have been received from the community overall, the QACPS Board of Education questioned student sustainability and a "demonstration of need" and claimed a lack of parent voices interested in enrolling students.
Charter committee officials stated they have personally spoken to multiple families in full support of the program, just without time to write letters of support or a hesitancy to speak up at Board meetings.
With a potential program so monumental looming for the county, Board of Education member Mathew Drayer questioned how parents couldn't find the time to voice their support.
A broad petition of county residents as well as outside of the county collected "well over two hundred signatures," that included parents, MacLeay said.
Although limited with polling data, the committee said it was happy to perform more surveys and was confident in the need.
The charter committee would ensure future marketing to all 8,000 students across the county's districts, Targeting families with elementary age children including homeschooled, the charter school would welcome reaching where families are, including libraries for an active presence and share what the potential school would entail, MacLeay said.
"We are trying to ensure we have viable schools with the right teachers and support and staff and everything they need to be successful," Board of Education President Shannon Bent said, and needed to hear from the community if there were additional needs to address.
Scott credited the above and beyond thoroughness forth by QACPS staff and Board of Education in reviewing the application.
"We are all in this for the children," Kibler said, and encouraged the committee to strengthen their application and resubmit next year.
The applicant retains the right to appeal to the Maryland State Board of Education or to resubmit during the next application window.
The QACPS Board of Education will next meet Oct 1. at 6 p.m.

content:

 Author/Byline: AHMAD GARNETT agarnett@chespub.com | Section: News

 DENTON — On Tuesday, Charles Huester, executive director for Maryland Rural Development Cooperation, discussed Early Head Start funding cuts with the Caroline County Commissioners.MRDC, which runs the Early Head Start programs in Caroline and Cecil counties, announced on Aug. 27 that the Early Head Start program would be ending effective Sept. 2 after it did not receive funding from the Office of Head Start.
The free program supports pregnant women and young children's learning and development.
Huester said they were surprised to hear the program did not receive the necessary funds given that that the MRDC hasn't officially heard back from Office of Head Start about its grant application. Huester said their competitors for the funding told them they didn't receive the grant.
"I'm not really sure the practice of Office of Head Start not replying to anyone. We found out through a third party, direct competitor for funding actually. Maryland Family Network let us know what was going on," Huester said.
Huester explained the funding was cut because of a decision to apply as a direct recipient instead of a subrecipient.
"We have over $1 million in funding. We applied for $3 million in funding, so essentially what we learned is if we continued as a subrecipient with Maryland Family Network, we probably would have had funding, it would have been no issue, but because we chose to apply as a direct recipient, we didn't receive funding," Huester said.
The decision to apply independently was made by the organization's board, but Huester said if MRCD knew that applying as a direct recipient would impacted its funding, MRDC would've made a different choice.
Huester said that MRDC reached out to Rep. Andy Harris (R-Md., 1st), who sent a letter to the Office of Head Start. Harris said he has not received a response.
Addressing concerns from residents about the program's end, Huester said MRDC has explored options to provide for the toddlers of Caroline County.
The options include introducing a Patty Center model, which aims to help the family as a whole, allowing parents to come on site for services like resume building and job searching while their children are looked after. There is also fee structure option, which consist of exploring what residents could afford to pay to keep a center open at spaces in Greensboro and Federalsburg.
Huester also discussed converting existing Head Start spots and a collaboration with the Maryland State Department of Education for classroom models.

title: Talbot school board dives into test score trends
author: Konner Metz
content:
Talbot school board dives into test score trends

 September 24, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Konner Metz | Section: Local News 
 
 695
 Words 

 Read News Document

 EASTON — Talbot school officials took a deeper look at state test scores last week, indicating upward trends in math and English for some grades and dips in others.At a work session on Sept. 15, Helga Einhorn, assistant superintendent of school leadership and student success, presented to Talbot Board of Education members breakdowns of 2024-2025 Maryland Comprehensive Assessment Program scores by grade and student group.
The presentation showed increases from the previous year in English proficiency for third and fourth grades, but drops for fifth and eighth grades. Math proficiency spiked year-to-year for fourth, sixth and seventh grades, but the number of students proficient algebra significantly fell.
The deeper dive came after the state released test score data for the 2024-2025 school year last month. While proficiency rates increased statewide, Talbot County students saw mixed results. English proficiency dropped to 45.4%, 16th in the state and the largest year-to-year decrease (1.9%) of all districts.
In math, 18.9% of students were proficient, 18th in the state and nearly even with the previous year's mark. Other counties, such as Dorchester, saw notable gains, rising spots in the statewide rankings.
Two days after the Sept. 15 work session, Talbot Board of Ed Member Deborah Bridges said at a monthly meeting that the district's results kept her up at night.
"After our work session on Monday night, I couldn't sleep," Bridges said. "Our scores, it upset me so much. And I wondered, what are we missing? What is going on in our schools?"
Board members largely agreed that the results aren't a matter of pointing fingers at teachers or staff. Instead, they are focused finding solutions to fix some of the problem areas.
Board President Emily Jackson said at the work session that she hopes school officials can begin to pinpoint some reasons behind the data trends.
"If I look at us, and we're going down, whereas a neighboring county who has a similar population of kids and they're going up, I want to know why," Jackson said.
Einhorn said while the state tests are an "important measure," it's one of many ways to assess academic achievement and growth.
"This is one assessment given at a single period of time, which does not always accurately reflect what students know and what they're able to do overall," Einhorn said.
ENGLISH
Fifth and tenth grades suffered the largest proficiency drops of 5.6% and 10%, respectively. But fourth grade proficiency rose to 50% in the most recent results. And while third grade proficiency dipped from last year's 47.9% mark, it's still at 43.6%, an improvement over a 35% rate two years ago.
"This really speaks to the work that this board has invested in early literacy, and starting to see that trend move up," Einhorn said at the work session.
Meanwhile, most student groups followed the district's overall trend of slightly decreasing in English proficiency. Asian students fell from 68.9% to 51.2%, while Talbot's multilingual learners dropped from 8.7% to 5.1%.
MATH
One of the sharpest drops came in Algebra II proficiency: 32.8% of students passed the state test in 2023-2024; only 7.1% passed in 2024-2025.
Einhorn acknowledged that as an "area of need." She noted that new math standards for K-8 will go into effect next school year. And in two years, the district will begin integrated algebra courses, infusing geometry concepts, she said.
Fourth grade rose nearly six percentage points to 32% proficiency this past year, while seventh grade had a similar hike from 11% to 17%.
By student group, one result stood out: Black students in the district remain under 5% proficient in math. Einhorn admitted the shortcoming.
"The less than 5% is indicating that we are still underserving our Black students and that we still need to continue looking at strategies that better prepare them to show what they know and are able to do in mathematics," Einhorn said.
Board Member Dyshekia Strawberry said she'd like to see the district work with community partners to specifically tackle the gap in math proficiency for Black students.
Board members thanked Einhorn for presenting the detailed trends, acknowledging that there's work to be done to get some of the numbers going in a positive direction.
"We have to do better, and we're open to hear how we're going to do that," Jackson said.

title: Maryland Supreme Court coming to Easton for first time since 1851
author: Konner Metz
content:
Maryland Supreme Court coming to Easton for first time since 1851

 October 1, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Konner Metz | Section: Local News 
 
 480
 Words 

 Read News Document

 EASTON — The Maryland Supreme Court is taking a field trip to Easton High School this week.The state's highest court is holding a special oral arguments hearing Friday morning inside the Easton High School auditorium, giving students a glimpse at how the Maryland Supreme Court operates.
Two cases, one civil and one criminal, will be heard beginning at 9:30 a.m. Friday. Both are open to the public.
The civil case deals with whether a court, when asked by an unlicensed landlord, can require tenants to pay rent. The criminal case is centered on whether police officers can initiate traffic stops for suspicion of cell phone use "when they observe a driver manipulating a mobile phone," according to the case's online summary.
For each case, lawyers on both sides will have 30 minutes each to make their oral arguments, which build off of their written briefs to the court.
Students from local high schools and Chesapeake College are expected to attend.
Maryland Supreme Court Justice Brynja Booth, of the 1st Appellate Judicial Circuit encompassing the Eastern Shore, said the special hearings are a way for the public to become involved in the judicial process.
"I really do believe that it's critical for the public's confidence in the judiciary," Booth said inside her Washington Street office on Tuesday.
Booth acknowledged a recent "erosion of public confidence," something she hopes can be quelled by the Maryland Supreme Court's off-site trips to places outside its Annapolis building.
Chief Justice Matthew Fader and six other justices, including Booth, comprise the Supreme Court. Formerly the Court of Appeals, the Supreme Court usually hears cases after accepting a petition from a party regarding the Appellate Court of Maryland's decisions.
Booth noted the Supreme Court's trip to Easton as historically significant. From 1805 to 1851, the then-Court of Appeals sat in Annapolis and Easton, Booth wrote. The court hasn't sat in Easton since 1851, she said.
Off-site oral arguments are a relatively new endeavor for Maryland's most prestigious court. They're made possible through an administrative order, Booth said, which facilitates hearings at educational locations across the state. Arguments have been heard in Prince George's, Baltimore, Montgomery and St. Mary's County, she said.
Booth and other Supreme Court of Maryland officials worked with Talbot County Public Schools Superintendent Sharon Pepukayi and Assistant Superintendent Helga Einhorn to coordinate Friday's event.
On Tuesday, Booth said she'd love to see students get involved in the judicial field, especially given what she sees as a lack of attorneys on the Eastern Shore.
Booth, a longtime Easton-based attorney, said the Eastern Shore is a "wonderful place to practice law and raise a family." She hopes Friday's special hearings will encourage students not only to explore law, but consider the Eastern Shore as a place to do so.
"You can be a little fish in the big pond, or you can come back to the Shore," Booth said. "You can be a big fish in a little pond."

title: A day to remember at the library
author: BILL PEAK Talbot County Free Library
content:
A day to remember at the library

 October 3, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: BILL PEAK Talbot County Free Library | Section: Life 
 
 931
 Words 

 Read News Document

 One hundred years ago, in October of 1925, Howard Carter reached Tutankhamun's burial chamber to find the pharaoh's features obscured by a mask of gold and lapis lazuli, Josephine Baker's La Revue Nègre premiered in Paris, and the War of the Stray Dog broke out between Greece and Bulgaria.A tad less dramatic perhaps, but so far as our lives go here on the Eastern Shore, surely the most consequential event of that long ago month took place on the 15th, when the Talbot County Free Library opened its doors for the first time.
From the beginning, our library was a community undertaking. In 1922, a small group of Talbot County women, led by a retired professional children's librarian, Caroline Burnite Walker, began to host parties and seek pledges to raise funds for the effort. Eventually, 40 women pledged $50 apiece toward the project.
Think about that. Forty women, now long gone, reached into their hearts and purses to endow an institution that still serves us 100 years later, an institution devoted to sharing knowledge with their fellow citizens and ours, regardless of station or rank, absolutely free of charge.
Within three years, the ladies had raised $4,149, the first librarian had been hired (salary: $900 a year), two rooms had been rented in the Tred Avon Building ($15 a month), and, on Oct. 15, 1925, the library opened its doors to the public for the first time. The collection size: 800 books. I would love to know what the most popular titles were.
The Talbot County Free Library will celebrate the 100th anniversary of that signal event on Thursday, Oct. 16, with a gala soirée inspired by the decade that gave birth to it, the roaring '20s — flappers, "The Great Gatsby," Prohibition and bootleg gin.
The evening will feature upscale hors d'oeuvres prepared by Royal Oak Catering, a specialty cocktail crafted by Lyon Rum, and wine and beer selected especially for the occasion by Wishing Well Liquors' renowned sommelier Philip Bernot.
Music for the night will be provided by the Julie Parsons Project Jazz Duo with Darrell Parsons. Among aficionados, Parsons is known for his phrasing and skill at bringing new meaning to the great jazz standards. He has performed on stages across the United States, Europe and Asia, appearing in Washington, D.C., and Los Angeles jazz clubs as well as the opera houses and concert halls of Vienna, Milan, Paris and Seoul.
People attending the event are asked to "dress to impress" in cocktail attire — which in my case means the usual white shirt, tie and blue blazer, but I'll bet a lot of folks will really put on the ritz. Josephine Baker would have a ball.
To purchase tickets for the gala, please go to tcfl.org/CentennialTicketsSponsorships/.
As if to showcase all that the library has achieved for our community over the course of its 100 years, a fair amount of the month's library programming will feature Talbot County history.
On Tuesday, Oct. 7, at 6 p.m., along with its community partners, the library will bring Carole Boston Weatherford and Jeffrey Boston Weatherford to the Todd Performing Arts Center at Chesapeake College to talk about this year's One Maryland One Book, "Kin: Rooted in Hope."
Combining remembered family stories with her gift for imagining, Weatherford has brought the lives of her Eastern Shore ancestors to life in verse. And her son, Jeffrey, has illustrated that verse with his luminous scratchboard art. In addition to being a Coretta Scott King Honor Book and this year's One Maryland One Book, "Kin" won the Boston Globe's Horn Book Poetry Award.
And then, on Saturday, Oct. 25, at 11 a.m., as part of our community's celebration of Tench Tilghman Week, the library will sponsor a talk by professor Richard Bell in its Easton branch about one of our county's most important founding fathers.
The Tilghman family's internal conflicts during the Revolution presage those suffered by families during the Civil War. Tilghman was George Washington's most trusted aide-de-camp, while his father, James Tilghman, remained loyal to Great Britain and one of his brothers served in the British Navy. Add to that the fact Tilghman's uncle, Matthew Tilghman, would become known as the "father of the revolution in Maryland," and you've got a recipe for some pretty calamitous family gatherings.
Finally, I'm not sure it really qualifies as Talbot County history, and it won't take place until Dec. 1, but on that date, at 6 p.m. in the Easton library, the official launch of "Adventures in Shelving, Vol. 2" will take place — a collection of my favorite Star Democrat library columns published between June of 2015 and May of 2025.
Actually, now that I think about it, those two dates do bookend an interesting period in our nation's history. Several of the columns consider what our community went through during the pandemic, how we dealt with the limitations placed on our commerce and our social lives, and how, despite those limitations, we managed to reach out and help one another. And a few address the ever-widening political divide in our country at large, and how, once again, as a community, we have tried to rise above that division.
But most of the writing in the book simply celebrates our community library, its collection and the wonderful people who use that collection every day. I hope that, reading it, you will get to share some of the joy I have found in working for the library and serving the good people of Talbot County.
So please, if you can, join us at one or all of these events in celebration of the birth of our beloved Talbot County Free Library.

title: 'Priceless': Students watch Maryland Supreme Court hearings at Easton High
author: Konner Metz
content:
'Priceless': Students watch Maryland Supreme Court hearings at Easton High

 October 3, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Konner Metz | Section: Local News 
 
 837
 Words 

 Read News Document

 EASTON — Instead of a play or concert, the Easton High School auditorium played host to something much different on Friday morning: the Maryland Supreme Court.Seven justices of the state's highest court, along with attorneys and court officials, took to the stage to dive into two separate court cases, one civil and one criminal.
It was a departure from their normal courthouse setting in Annapolis, and they did it in front of hundreds of local high school and college students — part of a new endeavor to periodically travel to educational institutions across the state.
"This was such a unique experience to be able to see the Maryland Supreme Court at my school," said Lorelai Yacks, an Easton High School junior.
Friday was the first time the state's highest court sat in Easton since 1851, back when it was known as the Court of Appeals and regularly alternated between Annapolis and Easton.
Justice Brynja Booth, of the 1st Appellate Judicial Circuit encompassing the Eastern Shore, spearheaded the effort to bring the court to Easton High alongside Talbot County Public Schools Superintendent Sharon Pepukayi and Assistant Superintendent Helga Einhorn.
The goal: expose students to the law field and allow them to interact with the justices through a question-and-answer session and sit-down lunch following the hearings.
Pepukayi beamed in an interview after the event about the rare opportunity students had just received.
"The best thing for me is the real-world examples and experiences that our kids get," she said. "It's one thing to read about it in a textbook, to hear in a lecture from a teacher. To see it in action, priceless."
The court on Friday heard oral arguments for a criminal case involving whether police officers have reasonable suspicion to pull over drivers for touching or manipulating a cell phone while driving. The justices also heard arguments in a civil case dealing with whether a court can require tenants to pay rent when asked by an unlicensed landlord. Opinions from the court are expected at a later date.
Pepukayi said she think the cell phone case will resonate with students and members of the public who attended.
"I think the next time someone reaches for their cell phone while driving, if they were sitting in this room, they're gonna think twice," she said.
Yacks took interest in that case, in particular because the issue at hand of texting and driving was easily understandable. The professionalism and legal vocabulary used by attorneys on both sides of the case impressed her, she said.
Going in, Yacks said she knew the Maryland Supreme Court opening session at the high school was "unprecedented." She left with a lot of useful insight as she considers pursuing a career in the law-adjacent political science field one day.
"It was awesome to see a similar example of what it might look like in the future," Yacks said.
Justices give advice
After the oral arguments concluded, students from Easton High, St. Michaels High, The Gunston School and Chesapeake College lined up behind two microphones to pick the brains of the seven justices on the Maryland Supreme Court for nearly an hour.
Questions ranged from asking about how Supreme Court hearings differed from trials, to how justices check their personal biases at the door, to what cases have stood out as the most interesting.
Justices refrained from naming specific cases as their "favorite," but Justice Stephen Gould said a worthwhile one is usually dependent on the attorneys involved.
"My favorite kind of a case is a case in which we have excellent lawyers before us," Gould said. "Fortunately, because we get to pick our cases, for the most part, we virtually almost always get really, really good lawyers, and I think today was an example of that."
Gould emphasized that lawyers have their own styles and strategies, which were on display for students Friday. Each case had an attorney for the appellant, the side appealing a lower court's decision, and an attorney for the appellee, the side asking the Supreme Court to rule the opposing argument moot or back up the lower court's previous ruling.
But for all attorneys, Gould noted: "They're prepared. They know their stuff."
One student asked the justices what common misconception they often encounter. Justice Angela Eaves said many don't realize that they aren't deciding cases based on personal feelings.
"We resolve based on the factual record and what the law says about it," Eaves said.
The justice for the 2nd Appellate Judicial Circuit (Baltimore and Harford counties) added that the court's job is more than just assessing the specific case before them.
"We're really looking at the broader implications of what the law should be with respect to the type of issues that come before us," Eaves said.
Justices were asked to give advice to students that want to study law.
Chief Justice Matthew Fader emphasized that law isn't a narrow field, meaning people studying it should "keep (their) learning broad." Attorneys are tasked with helping clients who come to them with real-life problems in a variety of areas, he added.
"Anything that happens in the world can end up in a piece of litigation," Fader said.

title: 'Bring people together': Radio station honoring Harriet Tubman launches in Mid-Shore
author: Konner Metz
content:
'Bring people together': Radio station honoring Harriet Tubman launches in Mid-Shore

 October 10, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Konner Metz | Section: Dorchester 
 
 457
 Words 

 Read News Document

 CAMBRIDGE — A new radio station honoring Harriet Tubman's legacy is coming to the Mid-Shore.WFHW 90.3 FM, a joint effort between WHCP 91.7 FM and the Harriet Tubman Museum and Educational Center in Cambridge, will launch Sunday. Its call letters stand for "Find Harriet Within."
Amanda Tilghman, WHCP station manager, and Linda Harris, the museum's director, spearheaded the project, an over two-year effort.
They say the station will educate Mid-Shore residents about Harriet Tubman, the Dorchester County-born abolitionist who escaped slavery and helped others do the same using the Underground Railroad. Harris hopes to read books about Tubman on the air and tape interviews with people who participate in the museum's Underground Railroad walking tours through.
WFHW will also act as a unifier, Tilghman and Harris said.
"There's so many divides right now," Tilghman said. "And we want to just bring people together, and there's got to be a lot of conversation to do that, so that's what we're gonna do."
"Talk it out and play a little music in between," added Harris, who will act as WFHW station manager.
The Harriet Tubman Museum acquired a license from the FCC a while ago, Tilghman said, and transferred it over to WHCP. Recently, the WFHW tower was built off of Route 50 near Trappe. Antennas were placed earlier this week in advance on Sunday's launch party at the Avalon Theatre.
The new FM station will expand the reach of Radio Chesapeake, the entity made up of WHCP and now WFHW. Tilghman said WFHW will have a stronger signal toward the Bay Bridge, making it more accessible to residents on the western side of the Eastern Shore.
Harris plans to host a five-day-a-week, hour-long talk show interviewing local figures. The interviews will dive into the journeys of people, sharing them with listeners and making connections to Tubman's journey.
"Everyone has a story and everyone's on a journey," Harris said.
Programming on WFHW will also include WHCP's two lead news programs as well as nationally syndicated shows.
Building African American Minds, an Easton nonprofit dedicated to education and after-school programs for at-risk and minority youth, is a partner in the launch of WFHW. Kids in BAAM's programs will host their own shows, either in Radio Chesapeake's Easton studio or from a remote studio inside the BAAM facility.
Tilghman said it's been great to prep the kids to produce, host or DJ a radio show.
"The young people, we need that," Harris said.
Discussing the potential of WFHW to reach a new and diverse audience, Harris and Tilghman continued to come back the theme of bringing the community together.
"We gotta reel people in and show them it's all about love and community and compassion and empathy," Harris said. "(That's) what we want to convey over the airwaves. We need that now more than ever."

 This week, Oct. 5-11, marks the 43rd year of celebrating the freedom to read with the American Library Association's Banned Book Week.It started in 1982, in response to a surge in book challenges and inspired by the landmark Supreme Court case, Island Trees School District v. Pico, which ruled that school officials cannot ban books solely based on their content (ala.org/advocacy). Now, decades later, we are experiencing a similar increase in censorship attempts across the country.
In their latest report, PEN America found that 6,870 books bans were enacted during the 2024-25 school year, across 23 states and 87 public school districts. And everywhere, more often than not, it is the books that have long fought for a place on the shelf that are being targeted: Books by authors of color, by LGBTQ+ authors and books by women. Books about racism, sexuality, gender and history also top the list.
Public library collections, too, are being attacked: the number of titles challenged in public libraries increased by 92% in 2023 alone. This increase is largely driven by organized groups and politicians, rather than isolated incidents, with groups demanding the censorship of multiple titles, sometimes dozens at a time (pen.org/book-bans).
Libraries provide free access to information and resources that are vital to a functioning democracy. Banning books and censoring materials not only denies citizens their fundamental right to free speech but is a slippery slope to greater infringements and abuses of power, examples of which are in the news almost daily.
It's fitting that the theme for this year's Banned Books Week is "Censorship is So 1984," as the world we are living in seems increasingly Orwellian. In the book we are warned, "who controls the past, controls the future: who controls the present controls the past." Who will control our future? Who is controlling our present? Banned Books Week is the perfect time to reflect on these questions and take action against censorship in all its forms because, in a democratic society, free people read freely.
MARY PELLICANO
Talbot County Free Library Trustee
Easton

title: Talbot Board of Ed digs into student discipline trends
author: Konner Metz
content:
Talbot Board of Ed digs into student discipline trends

 October 14, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Konner Metz | Section: Local News 
 
 561
 Words 

 Read News Document

 EASTON — Talbot County Public Schools officials grappled with the state's guidelines on student discipline during a Board of Education work session Monday.Reviewing the district's data on suspensions, expulsions and more, Darlene Spurrier, director of student services, explained that according to state regulations, administrators must indicate an "imminent threat" in order to expel a student.
Expelling a student is a last resort, Spurrier said, adding that standard came as part of a "sweeping change" of the regulation around 10 years ago.
In the last three full school years and so far this year, there have been no expulsions of Talbot County students, according to data presented Monday.
"It is a very difficult standard to meet," Spurrier said. She said that at times it can feel like a crystal ball is needed to determine whether a student poses an imminent threat.
Suspensions can range anywhere from one to 44 days, Spurrier said. Any mark at 45 days or above is considered an expulsion.
Out-of-school suspensions have been largely steady. Data presented by Spurrier showed there were 334, 355 and 344 such suspensions in school years 2022-2023, 2023-2024 and 2024-2025, respectively. This year, there have been 46 out-of-school suspensions so far.
In the same three-year span, TCPS had 60, 52 and 51 student arrests, and 12, 14 and 32 reportable offenses. Arrests are on school grounds either delivered by paper warrants or physical arrests, while reportable offenses occur off-school grounds and result in action by the school district.
Compared to neighboring counties, Spurrier pointed out that TCPS has a relatively low rate of students suspended or expelled. In 2023-2024, 5% of Talbot students were suspended or expelled. Queen Anne's County came in at 3.1%, while Caroline (6.4%), Kent (7.1%), Dorchester (16.2%) and Somerset (17.4%) were all higher.
Bullying reports have hovered around the same mark in recent years: 72 in 2022-2023, 73 in 2023-2024 and 65 in 2024-2025.
Board President Emily Jackson asked if the district is encouraging students and families to fill out the bullying reports when appropriate.
"I know for a while there was both an understanding in the community and kind of a prevailing attitude of, don't fill out the report," Jackson said.
Spurrier said the district never wants "to discourage a family or a student" from filling out the report paperwork. Jackson agreed.
"Even if it doubles our numbers, even if it looks bad," she said.
Superintendent Sharon Pepukayi asked Spurrier if the state has certain red flags when assessing disciplinary data. For the most part, Spurrier said the state does not, though she noted the state does track if there is "disproportionate disciplinary practices," especially for Black students and students with disabilities.
The student services director said the district is aware it needs to "make sure that we are being equitable in how we're imposing discipline."
Board Member Ann O'Connor expressed some concern.
"Isn't it just a matter of who's breaking the rules and who's not?" she said. O'Connor later added: "I just hope we are not not disciplining students because it looks like we are disciplining more of the Black or underserved (students)."
Jackson emphasized it's important for the district to consider its discipline interventions for underserved students and whether more funding should be allocated to those groups to proactively solve disciplinary issues.
Spurrier said it comes down to making sure two different students in two different subgroups are receiving similar discipline.
"Are we responding differently to students who have the same offense?" Spurrier said.

title: Students experience Farm to School eating
author: Riley Dauber rdauber@somdnews.com
content:
Students experience Farm to School eating

 October 14, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Riley Dauber rdauber@somdnews.com | Section: State News 
 
 477
 Words 

 Read News Document

 When the teachers and volunteers led students to the field outside of Mechanicsville Elementary School recently, they were excited to find several stations dedicated to teaching them about farm animals, fruits and vegetables, and healthy eating.The St. Mary's public school system has hosted Farm to School events for 16 years. School nutrition specialist Kaitlin Fraer organized events at three different elementary schools in the county this October, which is National Farm to School Month. At the first station, guided by youth nutritionist specialist Beth Palumbo from the American Dairy Association, students learned about cows and fresh milk. Palumbo and her team were excited to share that milk — yes, even chocolate milk — can keep you hydrated after physical activities.
Christine Allred, a former project leader and nutrition educator, and Deon Littles from the University of Maryland's College of Agriculture and Natural Resources showed the kids where their fruits and vegetables come from at the University of Maryland Extension station.
Allred read a picture book called "Up, Down, and Around" and instructed the kids to stand up, sit down, and spin around as the seeds were planted.
Each student received a plastic toy version of a fruit or vegetable to throw in the "fruit salad" — a colorful parachute that they raised in the air to mix the fruits and vegetables together.
Farmers from Beagle Hill Farm, located near the elementary school, brought tractors to show the students while also teaching them about growing sweet potatoes.
Adrian Hill and Greg Butterfield from Beagle Hill Farm assisted at the station.
"A lot of kids just don't have that connection of where their food comes from, or their clothing, or what agriculture can mean to them," said Butterfield, who has helped with the event for the last four years. "Maybe we'll make the next generation of farmers because I feel like it is getting less and less every year."
The students were invited to plant sweet potatoes, pull fresh vegetables out of the dirt and use a planter to plant seeds.
The youngsters had a chance to meet farm animals, including horses, pigs, goats and bunnies.
St. Mary's Farm Bureau Ambassadors Susannah Wathen and Sam Wathen introduced the students to a horse named Willa, who the kids were intrigued to learn is blind in one eye.
After moving through the stations, the students were served hamburgers and cheeseburgers with ground beef from Deere View Farm and Meats, Russell Bros LLC and Part Green Hill Farm.
"Living in a farming community, many people take advantage of the fact that they can get local produce most of the year, but it takes hard work to make that a reality," Fraer said.
Students will continue to engage with healthy eating thanks to curriculum provided by the University of Maryland Extension Program. The Food and Nutrition Services' dietitian is preparing marinated vegetables, roasted carrot fries and cheesy cauliflower for the students' lunches this month.

author: Konner Metz

Talbot Board of Ed OKs contracts for EHS auditorium, Chapel Elementary windows

 October 16, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Konner Metz | Section: Local News

 EASTON — The Talbot Board of Education on Wednesday approved contracts for two upcoming projects: auditorium lights at Easton High School and windows at Chapel District Elementary School.New auditorium lights at Easton High will be installed in the summer of 2026, Director of Operations Kevin Shafer told board members. The $1.1 million contract was passed unanimously.
Shafer said some preliminary work will be done this spring before school ends. The school play and other concerts or events won't be impacted, Shafer said.
Over in Cordova, the under-renovation Chapel District Elementary School will receive glazing for its new windows. The window glazing is a security film, Shafer said, a safety measure that "prevents easy access to the school building."
All other schools in the district have the window glazing.
Chapel District Elementary is currently under renovation, a multimillion endeavor expected to be done sometime in 2026.
The contract is through a Maryland Center for School Safety grant in the amount of $132,000 for the window glazing. Shafer said the district couldn't move forward with it during construction of the renovated school building due to cost limits during the bidding process.
Shafer said he hopes the window security upgrades can be completed this summer. The board unanimously approved the contract.
Board President Emily Jackson added that she has "slight hesitations about privacy" as it relates to windows in classrooms and libraries at Chapel District Elementary and other schools.
Jackson asked that the board hear more about potential school safety grants in the future, particularly "in the privacy arena to provide more screening for our students."
