title: 'This place impacts lives': Talbot County Free Library celebrates 100th birthday
author: Konner Metz
content:
'This place impacts lives': Talbot County Free Library celebrates 100th birthday

 October 17, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Konner Metz | Section: Local News 
 
 798
 Words 

 Read News Document

 EASTON — Two books missing from the shelves of the Talbot County Free Library for 50 years were finally returned to their home on Thursday.Johnny Mautz, the state senator and St. Michaels resident and businessman, fondly remembered using the library as a child, getting shushed as he walked into what was a much smaller space than it is today.
Mautz called the library "an anchor" of the community, thanking the staff and volunteers for their dedication to growing the library as it celebrated 100 years on Thursday evening.
But before he could finish his praises, Mautz had two special surprises for library staff. "The Ugly Duckling," last checked out June 7, 1975; and "The Steadfast Tin Soldier," last checked out Aug. 26, 1975.
"Johnny Mautz, you are in trouble," the senator joked.
Mautz's return of the children's books was just one of many moments where community leaders and residents smiled and chuckled on Thursday during the Talbot County Free Library's centennial celebration.
Board of Trustees President Susan Sherman blew out the candles on the 100th birthday cake. Dana Newman, the library's director, said the century mark wouldn't be possible without Caroline Burnite Walker, the founder of the library in 1925.
In its first year, the library paid $15 monthly rent to use two rooms at the Avon Realty Building on South Washington Street in Easton. Now, the library is a full-fledged community hub, stocked full with books, computers and research rooms, offering residents access to the internet, community events, children's festivals, wellness services and much more.
Talbot County Council Vice President Pete Lesher remembers his son biking to the library at 9 years old. One of his son's proudest moments was getting a library card.
Lesher, chief historian at the Chesapeake Bay Maritime Museum, reflected on the how the library has guided his research projects and skills.
"Are you a better person, are you a better version of yourself because of the library?" Lesher asked a crowd of over 100 people at Thursday's gala.
In unison, they clapped and exclaimed, "Yes!"
"I know that I am," Lesher continued. "And I know that thousands of people in this county alone are, as well. There are something like 200 people here this evening. Multiply that number by 100, and you're looking at roughly the number of cardholders for this library. There may be more cardholders for this library than there are licensed drivers in Talbot County."
He added: "It will continue to serve the next generation of children up to our citizens who are over 100, all of whom use this library. Rich and poor, all ages. This place impacts lives and must continue to do so."
Local authors gathered to reflect on how the library helped their journeys. Tim Young, founder of the Chesapeake Children's Book Festival, recalled how the library allowed him to bring esteemed children's authors to Talbot County for a festival now running on 10 years.
Carole Boston Weatherford, an author and former professor, said the Talbot County Free Library was her go-to place for borrowing DVDs, grading papers, internet access and research.
She used the library's expansive Maryland Room for "Kin: Rooted in Hope," a 2023 book reimagining the lives of her ancestors, who were slaves in Talbot County.
"This library is very close to my heart," Weatherford said.
While the library's main branch is in Easton, a St. Michaels branch provides key access for residents in many other parts of the county. The St. Michaels location is currently undergoing renovations to expand and add more children's spaces, a project that will be finished in early 2026.
Newman, the library's director, thanked county officials for their continued financial support that has made the St. Michaels expansion possible.
State officials shared heartfelt words for the library and its leaders during Thursday's centennial gala.
In a video message, Comptroller Brooke Lierman said the library is so critical as a place for people to apply for jobs or file tax returns, among many other uses.
"Consider the child who became a reader here, the entrepreneur who built their business plan at your computers, the senior who found community in your programs, and the immigrant who learned English," Lierman said.
Joy Moore, the mother of Gov. Wes Moore, attended the gala and read her son's citation to the Talbot County Free Library aloud.
Maryland State Librarian Morgan Miller, acknowledged the Talbot library as an inspiration to other rural libraries on the Eastern Shore. Miller, former director of the Cecil County library, said Talbot's children's book festival inspired her to implement a similar program up in Cecil.
"When I think about all of the stories in this library — and not just on our shelves — we're looking at 100 years," Miller said. "The stories of generations, and the generational impact of libraries, that just can't be captured in a night. But it is captured so well in your community here every day."

author: Lily Tierney

Empowerment Center offers after-school education

 October 20, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Lily Tierney | Section: Dorchester 
 
 298

 CAMBRIDGE — The kids were dropped off by school bus and greeted by Miss Tammy who knew each child by name. On this particular afternoon, the children were making Halloween decorations and doing arts and crafts.The Cambridge Empowerment Center is a non-profit located on historic Pine Street, offers after school, summer learning and pre-school programs, hosts food drives, clothing drives, food distributions, senior health and enrichment programs, learning seminars and more.
Director of Children's Programs Tammy Washington oversees programs from pre-kindergarden through 13 years old. The pre-K program is free and runs from 9 a.m. to noon. Washington said there are slots available for this program. Those interested may sign up on the website.
The after-school programming runs from 3-6 p.m. with themed days including math, art and IXL, a subscription-based learning site. In addition to the educational programming, the children get a meal and a snack after school.
The summer program costs $125 for six weeks and offers breakfast and lunch, field trips, education and a tennis program and an additional cost with licensed child care providers.
One of the third grade children who attends the after-school program said she loves coming to the center and enjoys multiplication, reading, painting and learning about Harriet Tubman. Her favorite book is "Llama Llama Mad at Mama."
The center opened in 2003 and has been licensed for child care for two years. Previous to the pandemic, the empowerment center solely operated through donations and via volunteers. Now, it runs on grant funding in addition to donations. Staff are paid and certified to work with children though they still welcome volunteers.
"After the pandemic, we started all over again," board member Julia Barker said. "We had to reinvent ourselves."
The center is hosting an open house on Nov. 9 for community members to check out this reinvention.

title: Rotarian from Uganda talks about life
author: PHIL REED
content:
Rotarian from Uganda talks about life

 October 21, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: PHIL REED | Section: News 
 
 239
 Words 

 Read News Document

 Robin Kibuka recently spoke to members of the Rotary Club of Cambridge about life growing up in Uganda, Africa. He shared some of the experiences and obstacles that led him to Yale University for his undergraduate education, Harvard University, where he received his Ph. D in economics and, ultimately, to a career at the International Monetary Fund (IMF). He told the members that life at the IMF found him traveling extensively around the world.Upon retirement, his life direction became focused on "how to give back." He said that life had been good to him, and he wanted to share with others. He felt his legacy was an important part of his life and what most people would remember. One thing he stressed was the importance of listening. In his opinion, listening makes you a better leader and improves your empathy. His most recent book, "Build Legacy Not Inheritance: Embracing the Journey of Building a Lasting Impact," reinforces his work post retirement.
His life continues having him travel, serving on a variety of professional boards in the U.S. and abroad. He has served as an adjunct faculty member at Strathmore Business School in Nairobi.
As a member of the Muyenga Rotary Club in Kampala, Uganda, Robin said the service work of Rotary serves as one way he gives back. During his talk, Kibuka presented Angie Hengst, president of the Rotary Club of Cambridge, with a banner from his Club in Uganda.
